column19: bibcode = 1989PNAS...86.7049M }}</ref> Most [[prokaryote]]s, having circular chromosomes rather than linear, do not have telomeres.<ref>{{Cite book
column35: url=https://archive.org/details/lehningerprincip00lehn_1}}</ref> Telomeres compensate for incomplete semi-conservative DNA replication at chromosomal ends.<ref name=pmid23732473>{{cite journal
column36: vauthors = Webb CJ, Wu Y, Zakian VA
column37: title = DNA repair at telomeres: keeping the ends intact
column38: journal = Cold Spring Harbor Perspectives in Biology
column45: doi = 10.1101/cshperspect.a012666 }}</ref> A protein complex known as [[shelterin]] serves to protect the ends of telomeres from being recognised as [[double-strand breaks]] by inhibiting [[homologous recombination]] (HR) and [[non-homologous end joining]] (NHEJ).<ref name=\"pmid20569239\">{{cite journal
column47: title = Role of shelterin in cancer and aging

column4: Telomeres are found at the termini of chromosomes. The end of a telomere inserts back into the main body of the telomere to form a T-loop]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In most prokaryotes, chromosomes are circular and thus do not have ends to suffer premature [[DNA replication
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: replication]] termination. A small fraction of [[bacteria]]l chromosomes (such as those in ''[[Streptomyces]]'', ''[[Agrobacterium]]'', and ''[[Borrelia]]'') are linear and possess telomeres, which are very different from those of the eukaryotic chromosomes in structure and functions. The known structures of bacterial telomeres take the form of [[proteins]] bound to the ends of linear chromosomes, or hairpin loops of single-stranded DNA at the ends of the linear chromosomes.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": While replicating DNA, the eukaryotic [[DNA replication]] enzymes (the [[DNA polymerase]] protein complex) cannot replicate the sequences present at the ends of the chromosomes (or more precisely the [[chromatid]] fibres). Hence, these sequences and the information they carry may get lost. This is the reason telomeres are so important in context of successful cell division: They \"cap\" the end-sequences and themselves get lost in the process of DNA replication. But the cell has an enzyme called telomerase, which carries out the task of adding repetitive nucleotide sequences to the ends of the DNA. Telomerase \"replenishes\" the telomere \"cap.\" In most multicellular eukaryotic organisms, telomerase is active only in [[germ cell]]s, some types of [[stem cell]]s such as [[embryonic stem cells]], and certain [[white blood cell]]s. Telomerase can be reactivated and telomeres reset back to an embryonic state by somatic cell nuclear transfer.<ref>{{cite journal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: vauthors = Lanza RP, Cibelli JB, Blackwell C, Cristofalo VJ, Francis MK, Baerlocher GM, Mak J, Schertzer M, Chavez EA, Sawyer N, Lansdorp PM, West MD
column4: title = Extension of cell life-span and telomere length in animals cloned from senescent somatic cells
column13: url = https://semanticscholar.org/paper/e4fed29bebe817a10fceb103b9b39c262852edf4 }}</ref> The steady shortening of telomeres with each replication in somatic (body) cells may have a role in [[senescence]] and in the prevention of [[cancer]].<ref>{{cite journal
column15: title = Senescence and immortalization: role of telomeres and telomerase
column25: title = Telomeres, telomerase, and tumorigenesis--a review
column32: pmc = 1435592 }}</ref> This is because the telomeres act as a sort of time-delay \"fuse\", eventually running out after a certain number of cell divisions and resulting in the eventual loss of vital genetic information from the cell's chromosome with future divisions.<ref>{{cite journal

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Telomere length varies greatly between species, from approximately 300 [[base pair]]s in yeast<ref>{{cite journal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: vauthors = Shampay J, Szostak JW, Blackburn EH
column3: title = DNA sequences of telomeres maintained in yeast
column11: bibcode = 1984Natur.310..154S }}</ref> to many kilobases in humans, and usually is composed of arrays of [[guanine]]-rich, six- to eight-base-pair-long repeats. Eukaryotic telomeres normally terminate with [[Sticky and blunt ends#Overhangs and sticky ends
column12: 3′ single-stranded-DNA overhang]], which is essential for telomere maintenance and capping. Multiple proteins binding single- and double-stranded telomere DNA have been identified.<ref>{{cite journal
column13: vauthors = Williams TL, Levy DL, Maki-Yonekura S, Yonekura K, Blackburn EH
column14: title = Characterization of the yeast telomere nucleoprotein core: Rap1 binds independently to each recognition site
column15: journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry
column22: doi = 10.1074/jbc.M110.170167 }}</ref> These function in both telomere maintenance and capping. Telomeres form large loop structures called telomere loops, or T-loops. Here, the single-stranded DNA curls around in a long circle, stabilized by [[telomere-binding protein]]s.<ref>{{cite journal
column23: vauthors = Griffith JD, Comeau L, Rosenfield S, Stansel RM, Bianchi A, Moss H, de Lange T
column24: title = Mammalian telomeres end in a large duplex loop
column31: doi = 10.1016/S0092-8674(00)80760-6 }}</ref> At the very end of the T-loop, the single-stranded telomere DNA is held onto a region of double-stranded DNA by the telomere strand disrupting the double-helical DNA, and base pairing to one of the two strands. This triple-stranded structure is called a [[displacement loop]] or D-loop.<ref>{{cite journal
column32: vauthors = Burge S, Parkinson GN, Hazel P, Todd AK, Neidle S
column33: title = Quadruplex DNA: sequence, topology and structure

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Role of telomeres in the cell cycle}}

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Telomere shortening in humans can induce replicative senescence, which blocks cell division. This mechanism appears to prevent genomic instability and development of cancer in human aged cells by limiting the number of cell divisions. However, shortened telomeres impair immune function that might also increase cancer susceptibility.<ref name=\"10.1002/ajhb.21127\">{{cite journal
column3: title = An evolutionary review of human telomere biology: the thrifty telomere hypothesis and notes on potential adaptive paternal effects
column4: journal = American Journal of Human Biology
column11: url = https://semanticscholar.org/paper/e1b4e9742b2fe7c6ee86baa8ea60df570a69440a }}</ref> If telomeres become too short, they have the potential to unfold from their presumed closed structure. The cell may detect this uncapping as DNA damage and then either stop growing, enter cellular old age ([[Cellular senescence
column12: senescence]]), or begin programmed cell self-destruction ([[apoptosis]]) depending on the cell's genetic background ([[p53]] status). Uncapped telomeres also result in chromosomal fusions. Since this damage cannot be repaired in normal somatic cells, the cell may even go into apoptosis. Many aging-related diseases are linked to shortened telomeres. Organs deteriorate as more and more of their cells die off or enter cellular senescence.

column4: Shelterin co-ordinates the T-loop formation of telomeres]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": At the very distal end of the telomere is a 300 base pair single-stranded portion, which forms the T-loop. This loop is analogous to a knot, which stabilizes the telomere, preventing the telomere ends from being recognized as break points by the DNA repair machinery. Should non-homologous end joining occur at the telomeric ends, chromosomal fusion will result. The T-loop is held together by several proteins, the most notable ones being TRF1, TRF2, POT1, TIN1, and TIN2, collectively referred to as the shelterin complex. In humans, the shelterin complex consists of six proteins identified as TRF1, TRF2, TIN2, POT1, TPP1, and RAP1.<ref name=\"pmid20569239\" />

Telomeres shorten in part because of the ''end replication problem'' that is exhibited during DNA replication in [[eukaryote]]s only. Because DNA replication does not begin at either end of the DNA strand, but starts in the center, and considering that all known [[DNA polymerase]]s read the template strand in the 3' to 5' direction, one finds a leading and a lagging strand on the DNA molecule being replicated.

On the leading strand, DNA polymerase can make a complementary DNA strand without any difficulty because it reads the template strand from 3' to 5'. However, there is a problem going in the other direction on the lagging strand. To counter this, short sequences of [[RNA]] acting as [[primer (molecular biology)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: primer]]s attach to the lagging strand a short distance ahead of where the initiation site was. The DNA polymerase can start replication at that point and go to the end of the initiation site. This causes the formation of [[Okazaki fragment]]s. More RNA primers attach further on the DNA strand and DNA polymerase comes along and continues to make a new DNA strand.[[File:Dnareplication.svg
column5: Lagging strand during DNA replication]]Eventually, the last RNA primer attaches, and DNA polymerase, RNA nuclease, and [[DNA ligase]] come along to convert the RNA (of the primers) to DNA and to seal the gaps in between the Okazaki fragments. But, in order to change RNA to DNA, there must be another DNA strand in front of the RNA primer. This happens at all the sites of the lagging strand, but it does not happen at the end where the last RNA primer is attached. Ultimately, that RNA is destroyed by enzymes that degrade any RNA left on the DNA. Thus, a section of the telomere is lost during each cycle of replication at the 5' end of the lagging strand's daughter.

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: test-tube]] studies have shown that telomeres are highly susceptible to [[oxidative stress]]. There is evidence that oxidative stress-mediated DNA damage is an important determinant of telomere shortening.<ref>{{cite journal
column3: vauthors = Richter T, von Zglinicki T
column4: title = A continuous correlation between oxidative stress and telomere shortening in fibroblasts
column11: doi = 10.1016/j.exger.2007.08.005 }}</ref> Telomere shortening due to free radicals explains the difference between the estimated loss per division because of the end-replication problem (c. 20 bp) and actual telomere shortening rates (50–100 bp), and has a greater absolute impact on telomere length than shortening caused by the end-replication problem. Population-based studies have also indicated an interaction between anti-oxidant intake and telomere length. In the Long Island Breast Cancer Study Project (LIBCSP), authors found a moderate increase in breast cancer risk among women with the shortest telomeres and lower dietary intake of beta carotene, vitamin C or E.<ref>{{cite journal
column12: vauthors = Shen J, Gammon MD, Terry MB, Wang Q, Bradshaw P, Teitelbaum SL, Neugut AI, Santella RM
column14: title = Telomere length, oxidative damage, antioxidants and breast cancer risk
column22: doi = 10.1002/ijc.24105 }}</ref> These results <ref name=\"Mathur MB 2016\">{{cite journal

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Telomere shortening is associated with aging, mortality and aging-related diseases. Normal aging is associated with telomere shortening in both humans and mice, and studies on [[genetically modified animal]] models suggest causal links between telomere erosion and aging.<ref>{{cite journal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: vauthors = López-Otín C, Blasco MA, Partridge L, Serrano M, Kroemer G
column11: doi = 10.1016/j.cell.2013.05.039 }}</ref> However, it is not known whether short telomeres are just a sign of cellular age or actually contribute to the aging process themselves.<ref>{{cite book
column12: vauthors = Alberts B, Johnson A, Lewis J, Morgan D, Raff M, Roberts K, Walter P

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The age of a father plays a role in the length of a child’s telomeres, which has evolutionary implications. Although leukocyte telomeres shorten with age, sperm telomeres lengthen with age. Shorter telomeres are theorized to impose lower energy costs (due to less replication) but also have immune system-related and other aging- and disease-related costs, so the effect of paternal age on telomere length might be an adaptation to increase the chances that the child will be fit for the environment they’re born into.<ref>{{cite journal
column3: title = An evolutionary review of human telomere biology: the thrifty telomere hypothesis and notes on potential adaptive paternal effects
column4: journal = American Journal of Human Biology

column13: title = Divergence of sperm and leukocyte age-dependent telomere dynamics: implications for male-driven evolution of telomere length in humans

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Meta-analyses]] found that increased perceived [[psychological stress]] was associated with a small decrease in telomere length--but that these associations attenuate to no significant association when accounting for [[publication bias]]. It is also stated, that the literature concerning telomeres as integrative biomarkers of exposure to stress and adversity is dominated by cross-sectional and correlational studies which makes causal interpretation problematic. <ref name=\"Mathur MB 2016\"/><ref>{{cite journal

column3: The average cell will divide between 50 and 70 times before cell death. As the cell divides the telomeres on the end of the chromosome get smaller. The [[Hayflick limit]] is the theoretical limit to the number of times a cell may divide until the telomere becomes so short that division is inhibited and the cell enters senescence.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The phenomenon of limited cellular division was first observed by [[Leonard Hayflick]], and is now referred to as the [[Hayflick limit]].<ref name=\"pmid13905659\">{{cite journal
column3: title = The serial cultivation of human diploid cell strains
column12: title = The limited in vitro lifetime of human diploid cell strains

Telomerase was demonstrated in a 1998 publication in ''[[Science (journal)
column13: Science]]'' to be capable of extending cell lifespan, and now is well-recognized as capable of immortalizing human somatic cells.<ref>{{cite journal

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": It is becoming apparent that reversing shortening of telomeres through temporary activation of telomerase may be a potent means to slow aging. The reason that this would extend human life is because it would extend the Hayflick limit. Three routes have been proposed to reverse telomere shortening: drugs, gene therapy, or metabolic suppression, so-called, torpor/hibernation. So far these ideas have not been proven in humans, but it has been demonstrated that telomere shortening is reversed in hibernation and aging is slowed (Turbill, ''et al.'' 2012 & 2013) and that hibernation prolongs life-span (Lyman ''et al.'' 1981). It has also been demonstrated that telomere extension has successfully reversed some signs of aging in laboratory mice <ref>{{cite news
column8: title=Harvard scientists reverse the ageing process in mice – now for humans
column10: vauthors = Jaskelioff M, Muller FL, Paik JH, Thomas E, Jiang S, Adams AC, Sahin E, Kost-Alimova M, Protopopov A, Cadiñanos J, Horner JW, Maratos-Flier E, Depinho RA
column12: title = Telomerase reactivation reverses tissue degeneration in aged telomerase-deficient mice
column21: bibcode = 2011Natur.469..102J }}</ref> and the [[nematode]] worm species ''[[Caenorhabditis elegans]]''.<ref>{{cite journal
column22: vauthors = Joeng KS, Song EJ, Lee KJ, Lee J
column23: title = Long lifespan in worms with long telomeric DNA
column31: doi-access = free }}</ref> It has been hypothesized that longer telomeres and especially telomerase activation might cause increased cancer (e.g. [[Bret Weinstein
column34: title = The reserve-capacity hypothesis: evolutionary origins and modern implications of the trade-off between tumor-suppression and tissue-repair
column41: doi = 10.1016/S0531-5565(02)00012-8 }}</ref>). However, longer telomeres might also protect against cancer, because short telomeres are associated with cancer. It has also been suggested that longer telomeres might cause increased energy consumption.<ref name=\"10.1002/ajhb.21127\" />

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Techniques to extend telomeres could be useful for [[tissue engineering]], because they might permit healthy, noncancerous mammalian cells to be cultured in amounts large enough to be engineering materials for biomedical repairs.

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: date=April 2020}} studies on long-lived [[seabird]]s demonstrate that the role of telomeres is far from being understood. In 2003, scientists observed that the telomeres of [[Leach's storm-petrel]] (''Oceanodroma leucorhoa'') seem to lengthen with chronological age, the first observed instance of such behaviour of telomeres.<ref>{{cite journal
column3: vauthors = Nakagawa S, Gemmell NJ, Burke T
column4: title = Measuring vertebrate telomeres: applications and limitations
column13: vauthors = Juola FA, Haussmann MF, Dearborn DC, Vleck CM
column14: title = Telomere shortening in a long-lived marine bird: cross-sectional analysis and test of an aging tool.
column22: jstor=4090554 }}</ref> reported that in another unrelated, long-lived seabird species, the [[great frigatebird]] (''Fregata minor''), telomere length did decrease until at least c. 40 years of age (i.e. probably over the entire lifespan), but the speed of decrease slowed down massively with increasing ages, and that rates of telomere length decrease varied strongly between individual birds. They concluded that in this species (and probably in [[frigatebird]]s and their relatives in general), telomere length could not be used to determine a bird's age sufficiently well. Thus, it seems that there is much more variation in the behavior of telomere length than initially believed.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Most research on telomere length and regulation, and its relationship to cancer and ageing, has been performed on mammals, especially humans, which have little or no somatic telomerase production. [[Ectotherm]]s are significantly more likely than endotherms to have variation in somatic telomerase expression. For instance, in many fish, telomerase occurs throughout the body (and associated with this, telomere length is roughly the same across all its tissue). Studies on ectotherms, and other non-mammalian organisms, show that there’s no single universal model of telomere erosion; rather, there is wide variation in relevant dynamics across Metazoa, and even within smaller taxonomic groups these patterns appear diverse. Due to the different reproductive timelines of some ectotherms, selection on disease is relevant for a much larger fraction of these creatures’ lives than it is for mammals, so early- and late-life telomere length, and their possible links to cancer, seem especially important in these species from a [[life history theory]] point of view.<ref>{{cite journal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: vauthors = Olsson M, Wapstra E, Friesen C
column3: title = Ectothermic telomeres: it's time they came in from the cold
column4: journal = Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological Sciences

column3: RNA primers]] attaching ahead on the lagging strand). The telomeres are disposable buffers at the ends of chromosomes which are truncated during cell division; their presence protects the [[gene]]s before them on the chromosome from being truncated instead. The telomeres themselves are protected by a complex of [[shelterin]] proteins, as well as by the RNA that telomeric DNA encodes ([[TERRA (biology)

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Over time, due to each cell division, the telomere ends become shorter.<ref>Passarge, Eberhard.  ''Color atlas of genetics'', 2007.</ref> They are replenished by an enzyme, [[telomerase reverse transcriptase]].<ref>{{Cite web

In the early 1970s, Russian theorist [[Alexei Olovnikov]] first recognized that chromosomes could not completely replicate their ends. Building on this, and to accommodate [[Leonard Hayflick]]'s idea of limited [[somatic cell]] division, Olovnikov suggested that DNA sequences are lost every time a cell replicates until the loss reaches a critical level, at which point cell division ends.<ref>{{cite journal

In 1975–1977, [[Elizabeth Blackburn]], working as a postdoctoral fellow at Yale University with [[Joseph G. Gall]], discovered the unusual nature of telomeres, with their simple repeated DNA sequences composing chromosome ends.<ref>{{cite journal
column3: title = A tandemly repeated sequence at the termini of the extrachromosomal ribosomal RNA genes in Tetrahymena
column10: doi = 10.1016/0022-2836(78)90294-2 }}</ref> Blackburn, [[Carol Greider]], and [[Jack Szostak]] were awarded the [[List of Nobel laureates in Physiology or Medicine#2001–current
column11: 2009]] [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine]] for the discovery of how chromosomes are protected by telomeres and the enzyme telomerase.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Elizabeth H. Blackburn, Carol W. Greider, Jack W. Szostak: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 2009

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In most prokaryotes, chromosomes are circular and thus do not have ends to suffer premature [[DNA replication
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: replication]] termination. A small fraction of [[bacteria]]l chromosomes (such as those in ''[[Streptomyces]]'', ''[[Agrobacterium]]'', and ''[[Borrelia]]'') are linear and possess telomeres, which are very different from those of the eukaryotic chromosomes in structure and functions. The known structures of bacterial telomeres take the form of [[proteins]] bound to the ends of linear chromosomes, or hairpin loops of single-stranded DNA at the ends of the linear chromosomes.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": While replicating DNA, the eukaryotic [[DNA replication]] enzymes (the [[DNA polymerase]] protein complex) cannot replicate the sequences present at the ends of the chromosomes (or more precisely the [[chromatid]] fibres). Hence, these sequences and the information they carry may get lost. This is the reason telomeres are so important in context of successful cell division: They \"cap\" the end-sequences and themselves get lost in the process of DNA replication. But the cell has an enzyme called telomerase, which carries out the task of adding repetitive nucleotide sequences to the ends of the DNA. Telomerase \"replenishes\" the telomere \"cap.\" In most multicellular eukaryotic organisms, telomerase is active only in [[germ cell]]s, some types of [[stem cell]]s such as [[embryonic stem cells]], and certain [[white blood cell]]s. Telomerase can be reactivated and telomeres reset back to an embryonic state by somatic cell nuclear transfer.<ref>{{cite journal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: vauthors = Lanza RP, Cibelli JB, Blackwell C, Cristofalo VJ, Francis MK, Baerlocher GM, Mak J, Schertzer M, Chavez EA, Sawyer N, Lansdorp PM, West MD

column13: url = https://semanticscholar.org/paper/e4fed29bebe817a10fceb103b9b39c262852edf4 }}</ref> The steady shortening of telomeres with each replication in somatic (body) cells may have a role in [[senescence]] and in the prevention of [[cancer]].<ref>{{cite journal
column15: title = Senescence and immortalization: role of telomeres and telomerase
column25: title = Telomeres, telomerase, and tumorigenesis--a review
column32: pmc = 1435592 }}</ref> This is because the telomeres act as a sort of time-delay \"fuse\", eventually running out after a certain number of cell divisions and resulting in the eventual loss of vital genetic information from the cell's chromosome with future divisions.<ref>{{cite journal

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Telomere length varies greatly between species, from approximately 300 [[base pair]]s in yeast<ref>{{cite journal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: vauthors = Shampay J, Szostak JW, Blackburn EH
column3: title = DNA sequences of telomeres maintained in yeast
column11: bibcode = 1984Natur.310..154S }}</ref> to many kilobases in humans, and usually is composed of arrays of [[guanine]]-rich, six- to eight-base-pair-long repeats. Eukaryotic telomeres normally terminate with [[Sticky and blunt ends#Overhangs and sticky ends
column12: 3′ single-stranded-DNA overhang]], which is essential for telomere maintenance and capping. Multiple proteins binding single- and double-stranded telomere DNA have been identified.<ref>{{cite journal
column13: vauthors = Williams TL, Levy DL, Maki-Yonekura S, Yonekura K, Blackburn EH
column14: title = Characterization of the yeast telomere nucleoprotein core: Rap1 binds independently to each recognition site
column15: journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry
column22: doi = 10.1074/jbc.M110.170167 }}</ref> These function in both telomere maintenance and capping. Telomeres form large loop structures called telomere loops, or T-loops. Here, the single-stranded DNA curls around in a long circle, stabilized by [[telomere-binding protein]]s.<ref>{{cite journal
column23: vauthors = Griffith JD, Comeau L, Rosenfield S, Stansel RM, Bianchi A, Moss H, de Lange T
column24: title = Mammalian telomeres end in a large duplex loop
column31: doi = 10.1016/S0092-8674(00)80760-6 }}</ref> At the very end of the T-loop, the single-stranded telomere DNA is held onto a region of double-stranded DNA by the telomere strand disrupting the double-helical DNA, and base pairing to one of the two strands. This triple-stranded structure is called a [[displacement loop]] or D-loop.<ref>{{cite journal
column32: vauthors = Burge S, Parkinson GN, Hazel P, Todd AK, Neidle S
column33: title = Quadruplex DNA: sequence, topology and structure

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Role of telomeres in the cell cycle}}

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Telomere shortening in humans can induce replicative senescence, which blocks cell division. This mechanism appears to prevent genomic instability and development of cancer in human aged cells by limiting the number of cell divisions. However, shortened telomeres impair immune function that might also increase cancer susceptibility.<ref name=\"10.1002/ajhb.21127\">{{cite journal
column3: title = An evolutionary review of human telomere biology: the thrifty telomere hypothesis and notes on potential adaptive paternal effects
column4: journal = American Journal of Human Biology
column11: url = https://semanticscholar.org/paper/e1b4e9742b2fe7c6ee86baa8ea60df570a69440a }}</ref> If telomeres become too short, they have the potential to unfold from their presumed closed structure. The cell may detect this uncapping as DNA damage and then either stop growing, enter cellular old age ([[Cellular senescence
column12: senescence]]), or begin programmed cell self-destruction ([[apoptosis]]) depending on the cell's genetic background ([[p53]] status). Uncapped telomeres also result in chromosomal fusions. Since this damage cannot be repaired in normal somatic cells, the cell may even go into apoptosis. Many aging-related diseases are linked to shortened telomeres. Organs deteriorate as more and more of their cells die off or enter cellular senescence.

column4: Shelterin co-ordinates the T-loop formation of telomeres]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": At the very distal end of the telomere is a 300 base pair single-stranded portion, which forms the T-loop. This loop is analogous to a knot, which stabilizes the telomere, preventing the telomere ends from being recognized as break points by the DNA repair machinery. Should non-homologous end joining occur at the telomeric ends, chromosomal fusion will result. The T-loop is held together by several proteins, the most notable ones being TRF1, TRF2, POT1, TIN1, and TIN2, collectively referred to as the shelterin complex. In humans, the shelterin complex consists of six proteins identified as TRF1, TRF2, TIN2, POT1, TPP1, and RAP1.<ref name=\"pmid20569239\" />

Telomeres shorten in part because of the ''end replication problem'' that is exhibited during DNA replication in [[eukaryote]]s only. Because DNA replication does not begin at either end of the DNA strand, but starts in the center, and considering that all known [[DNA polymerase]]s read the template strand in the 3' to 5' direction, one finds a leading and a lagging strand on the DNA molecule being replicated.

On the leading strand, DNA polymerase can make a complementary DNA strand without any difficulty because it reads the template strand from 3' to 5'. However, there is a problem going in the other direction on the lagging strand. To counter this, short sequences of [[RNA]] acting as [[primer (molecular biology)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: primer]]s attach to the lagging strand a short distance ahead of where the initiation site was. The DNA polymerase can start replication at that point and go to the end of the initiation site. This causes the formation of [[Okazaki fragment]]s. More RNA primers attach further on the DNA strand and DNA polymerase comes along and continues to make a new DNA strand.[[File:Dnareplication.svg
column5: Lagging strand during DNA replication]]Eventually, the last RNA primer attaches, and DNA polymerase, RNA nuclease, and [[DNA ligase]] come along to convert the RNA (of the primers) to DNA and to seal the gaps in between the Okazaki fragments. But, in order to change RNA to DNA, there must be another DNA strand in front of the RNA primer. This happens at all the sites of the lagging strand, but it does not happen at the end where the last RNA primer is attached. Ultimately, that RNA is destroyed by enzymes that degrade any RNA left on the DNA. Thus, a section of the telomere is lost during each cycle of replication at the 5' end of the lagging strand's daughter.

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: test-tube]] studies have shown that telomeres are highly susceptible to [[oxidative stress]]. There is evidence that oxidative stress-mediated DNA damage is an important determinant of telomere shortening.<ref>{{cite journal
column3: vauthors = Richter T, von Zglinicki T
column4: title = A continuous correlation between oxidative stress and telomere shortening in fibroblasts
column11: doi = 10.1016/j.exger.2007.08.005 }}</ref> Telomere shortening due to free radicals explains the difference between the estimated loss per division because of the end-replication problem (c. 20 bp) and actual telomere shortening rates (50–100 bp), and has a greater absolute impact on telomere length than shortening caused by the end-replication problem. Population-based studies have also indicated an interaction between anti-oxidant intake and telomere length. In the Long Island Breast Cancer Study Project (LIBCSP), authors found a moderate increase in breast cancer risk among women with the shortest telomeres and lower dietary intake of beta carotene, vitamin C or E.<ref>{{cite journal
column12: vauthors = Shen J, Gammon MD, Terry MB, Wang Q, Bradshaw P, Teitelbaum SL, Neugut AI, Santella RM
column14: title = Telomere length, oxidative damage, antioxidants and breast cancer risk
column22: doi = 10.1002/ijc.24105 }}</ref> These results <ref name=\"Mathur MB 2016\">{{cite journal
column23: vauthors = Mathur MB, Epel E, Kind S, Desai M, Parks CG, Sandler DP, Khazeni N
column24: title = Perceived stress and telomere length: A systematic review, meta-analysis, and methodologic considerations for advancing the field
column31: doi = 10.1016/j.bbi.2016.02.002 }}</ref> suggest that cancer risk due to telomere shortening may interact with other mechanisms of DNA damage, specifically oxidative stress.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Telomere shortening is associated with aging, mortality and aging-related diseases. Normal aging is associated with telomere shortening in both humans and mice, and studies on [[genetically modified animal]] models suggest causal links between telomere erosion and aging.<ref>{{cite journal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: vauthors = López-Otín C, Blasco MA, Partridge L, Serrano M, Kroemer G
column11: doi = 10.1016/j.cell.2013.05.039 }}</ref> However, it is not known whether short telomeres are just a sign of cellular age or actually contribute to the aging process themselves.<ref>{{cite book
column12: vauthors = Alberts B, Johnson A, Lewis J, Morgan D, Raff M, Roberts K, Walter P

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The age of a father plays a role in the length of a child’s telomeres, which has evolutionary implications. Although leukocyte telomeres shorten with age, sperm telomeres lengthen with age. Shorter telomeres are theorized to impose lower energy costs (due to less replication) but also have immune system-related and other aging- and disease-related costs, so the effect of paternal age on telomere length might be an adaptation to increase the chances that the child will be fit for the environment they’re born into.<ref>{{cite journal
column3: title = An evolutionary review of human telomere biology: the thrifty telomere hypothesis and notes on potential adaptive paternal effects
column4: journal = American Journal of Human Biology
column12: vauthors = Aston KI, Hunt SC, Susser E, Kimura M, Factor-Litvak P, Carrell D, Aviv A
column13: title = Divergence of sperm and leukocyte age-dependent telomere dynamics: implications for male-driven evolution of telomere length in humans

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Meta-analyses]] found that increased perceived [[psychological stress]] was associated with a small decrease in telomere length--but that these associations attenuate to no significant association when accounting for [[publication bias]]. It is also stated, that the literature concerning telomeres as integrative biomarkers of exposure to stress and adversity is dominated by cross-sectional and correlational studies which makes causal interpretation problematic. <ref name=\"Mathur MB 2016\"/><ref>{{cite journal
column3: vauthors = Pepper GV, Bateson M, Nettle D
column4: title = Telomeres as integrative markers of exposure to stress and adversity: a systematic review and meta-analysis

column3: The average cell will divide between 50 and 70 times before cell death. As the cell divides the telomeres on the end of the chromosome get smaller. The [[Hayflick limit]] is the theoretical limit to the number of times a cell may divide until the telomere becomes so short that division is inhibited and the cell enters senescence.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The phenomenon of limited cellular division was first observed by [[Leonard Hayflick]], and is now referred to as the [[Hayflick limit]].<ref name=\"pmid13905659\">{{cite journal
column3: title = The serial cultivation of human diploid cell strains
column12: title = The limited in vitro lifetime of human diploid cell strains

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Significant discoveries were subsequently made by a group of scientists organized at [[Geron Corporation]] by Geron's founder [[Michael D. West]] that tied telomere shortening with the Hayflick limit.<ref name=\"pmid7544491\">{{cite journal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: vauthors = Feng J, Funk WD, Wang SS, Weinrich SL, Avilion AA, Chiu CP, Adams RR, Chang E, Allsopp RC, Yu J
column4: title = The RNA component of human telomerase
column12: bibcode = 1995Sci...269.1236F }}</ref> The cloning of the catalytic component of telomerase enabled experiments to test whether the expression of telomerase at levels sufficient to prevent telomere shortening was capable of immortalizing human cells. Telomerase was demonstrated in a 1998 publication in ''[[Science (journal)
column13: Science]]'' to be capable of extending cell lifespan, and now is well-recognized as capable of immortalizing human somatic cells.<ref>{{cite journal
column14: vauthors = Bodnar AG, Ouellette M, Frolkis M, Holt SE, Chiu CP, Morin GB, Harley CB, Shay JW, Lichtsteiner S, Wright WE
column16: title = Extension of life-span by introduction of telomerase into normal human cells

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": It is becoming apparent that reversing shortening of telomeres through temporary activation of telomerase may be a potent means to slow aging. The reason that this would extend human life is because it would extend the Hayflick limit. Three routes have been proposed to reverse telomere shortening: drugs, gene therapy, or metabolic suppression, so-called, torpor/hibernation. So far these ideas have not been proven in humans, but it has been demonstrated that telomere shortening is reversed in hibernation and aging is slowed (Turbill, et al. 2012 & 2013) and that hibernation prolongs life-span (Lyman et al. 1981). It has also been demonstrated that telomere extension has successfully reversed some signs of aging in laboratory mice <ref>{{cite news
column8: title=Harvard scientists reverse the ageing process in mice – now for humans
column10: vauthors = Jaskelioff M, Muller FL, Paik JH, Thomas E, Jiang S, Adams AC, Sahin E, Kost-Alimova M, Protopopov A, Cadiñanos J, Horner JW, Maratos-Flier E, Depinho RA
column12: title = Telomerase reactivation reverses tissue degeneration in aged telomerase-deficient mice
column21: bibcode = 2011Natur.469..102J }}</ref> and the [[nematode]] worm species ''[[Caenorhabditis elegans]]''.<ref>{{cite journal
column22: vauthors = Joeng KS, Song EJ, Lee KJ, Lee J
column23: title = Long lifespan in worms with long telomeric DNA
column31: doi-access = free }}</ref> It has been hypothesized that longer telomeres and especially telomerase activation might cause increased cancer (e.g. [[Bret Weinstein
column34: title = The reserve-capacity hypothesis: evolutionary origins and modern implications of the trade-off between tumor-suppression and tissue-repair
column41: doi = 10.1016/S0531-5565(02)00012-8 }}</ref>). However, longer telomeres might also protect against cancer, because short telomeres are associated with cancer. It has also been suggested that longer telomeres might cause increased energy consumption.<ref name=\"10.1002/ajhb.21127\" />

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Techniques to extend telomeres could be useful for [[tissue engineering]], because they might permit healthy, noncancerous mammalian cells to be cultured in amounts large enough to be engineering materials for biomedical repairs.

Two recent studies on long-lived [[seabird]]s demonstrate that the role of telomeres is far from being understood. In 2003, scientists observed that the telomeres of [[Leach's storm-petrel]] (''Oceanodroma leucorhoa'') seem to lengthen with chronological age, the first observed instance of such behaviour of telomeres.<ref>{{cite journal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: vauthors = Nakagawa S, Gemmell NJ, Burke T
column3: title = Measuring vertebrate telomeres: applications and limitations
column12: vauthors = Juola FA, Haussmann MF, Dearborn DC, Vleck CM
column13: title = Telomere shortening in a long-lived marine bird: cross-sectional analysis and test of an aging tool.
column21: jstor=4090554 }}</ref> reported that in another unrelated, long-lived seabird species, the [[great frigatebird]] (''Fregata minor''), telomere length did decrease until at least c. 40 years of age (i.e. probably over the entire lifespan), but the speed of decrease slowed down massively with increasing ages, and that rates of telomere length decrease varied strongly between individual birds. They concluded that in this species (and probably in [[frigatebird]]s and their relatives in general), telomere length could not be used to determine a bird's age sufficiently well. Thus, it seems that there is much more variation in the behavior of telomere length than initially believed.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Furthermore, Gomes et al. found, in a study of the comparative biology of mammalian telomeres, that telomere length of different mammalian species correlates inversely, rather than directly, with lifespan, and they concluded that the contribution of telomere length to lifespan remains controversial.<ref>{{cite journal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: vauthors = Gomes NM, Ryder OA, Houck ML, Charter SJ, Walker W, Forsyth NR, Austad SN, Venditti C, Pagel M, Shay JW, Wright WE
column4: title = Comparative biology of mammalian telomeres: hypotheses on ancestral states and the roles of telomeres in longevity determination
column12: doi = 10.1111/j.1474-9726.2011.00718.x }}</ref> Harris et al. found little evidence that, in humans, telomere length is a significant biomarker of normal aging with respect to important cognitive and physical abilities.<ref>{{cite journal
column13: vauthors = Harris SE, Martin-Ruiz C, von Zglinicki T, Starr JM, Deary IJ
column14: title = Telomere length and aging biomarkers in 70-year-olds: the Lothian Birth Cohort 1936
column21: doi = 10.1016/j.neurobiolaging.2010.11.013 }}</ref> Gilley and Blackburn tested whether cellular senescence in [[paramecium]] is caused by telomere shortening, and found that telomeres were not shortened during senescence.<ref>{{cite journal
column23: title = Lack of telomere shortening during senescence in Paramecium
column24: journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Known, up-to-date telomere [[nucleotide]] sequences are listed in [http://telomerase.asu.edu/sequences_telomere.html Telomerase Database] website.

column3: vauthors = Peška V, Fajkus P, Fojtová M, Dvořáčková M, Hapala J, Dvořáček V, Polanská P, Leitch AR, Sýkorová E, Fajkus J
column5: title = Characterisation of an unusual telomere motif (TTTTTTAGGG)n in the plant Cestrum elegans (Solanaceae), a species with a large genome

column5: title = Human-like telomeres in Zostera marina reveal a mode of transition from the plant to the human telomeric sequences

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Telomeres are critical for maintaining genomic integrity and may be factors for age-related diseases.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite journal
column13: title=Telomeres and Early-Life Stress: An Overview
column23: pmid=22831981}}</ref> Laboratory studies show that telomere dysfunction or shortening is commonly acquired due process of cellular aging and tumor development.<ref name=\":0\" /><ref>{{cite journal
column24: vauthors = Raynaud CM, Sabatier L, Philipot O, Olaussen KA, Soria JC
column25: title = Telomere length, telomeric proteins and genomic instability during the multistep carcinogenic process
column32: doi = 10.1016/j.critrevonc.2007.11.006 }}</ref> Short telomeres can lead to genomic instability, chromosome loss and the formation of non-reciprocal translocations; and telomeres in tumor cells and their precursor lesions are significantly shorter than surrounding normal tissue.<ref>{{cite journal
column33: vauthors = Blasco MA, Lee HW, Hande MP, Samper E, Lansdorp PM, DePinho RA, Greider CW
column34: title = Telomere shortening and tumor formation by mouse cells lacking telomerase RNA
column42: vauthors = Artandi SE, Chang S, Lee SL, Alson S, Gottlieb GJ, Chin L, DePinho RA
column43: title = Telomere dysfunction promotes non-reciprocal translocations and epithelial cancers in mice

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Observational studies have found shortened telomeres in many types of experimental cancers.<ref name=\"armanios\">{{cite journal
column4: title=Telomeres and age-related disease: how telomere biology informs clinical paradigms
column11: pmid=23454763}}</ref> In addition, people with  cancer have been found to possess shorter leukocyte telomeres than healthy controls.<ref name=\"pmid20606151\">{{cite journal
column12: vauthors = Willeit P, Willeit J, Mayr A, Weger S, Oberhollenzer F, Brandstätter A, Kronenberg F, Kiechl S
column14: title = Telomere length and risk of incident cancer and cancer mortality
column22: doi-access = free }}</ref> Recent meta-analyses suggest 1.4 to 3.0 fold increased risk of cancer for those with the shortest vs. longest telomeres.<ref>{{cite journal
column23: vauthors = Ma H, Zhou Z, Wei S, Liu Z, Pooley KA, Dunning AM, Svenson U, Roos G, Hosgood HD, Shen M, Wei Q
column25: title = Shortened telomere length is associated with increased risk of cancer: a meta-analysis
column35: vauthors = Wentzensen IM, Mirabello L, Pfeiffer RM, Savage SA
column36: title = The association of telomere length and cancer: a meta-analysis
column44: doi = 10.1158/1055-9965.epi-11-0005 }}</ref> However, the increase in risk varies by age, sex, tumor type, and differences in lifestyle factors.<ref name=armanios/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Several techniques are currently employed to assess average telomere length in eukaryotic cells. One method is the Terminal Restriction Fragment (TRF) southern blot.<ref>{{cite journal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: vauthors = Allshire RC, Dempster M, Hastie ND
column3: title = Human telomeres contain at least three types of G-rich repeat distributed non-randomly
column13: vauthors = Rufer N, Dragowska W, Thornbury G, Roosnek E, Lansdorp PM
column14: title = Telomere length dynamics in human lymphocyte subpopulations measured by flow cytometry
column23: PCR]] assay for telomere length involves determining the Telomere-to-Single Copy Gene (T/S)ratio, which is demonstrated to be proportional to the average telomere length in a cell.<ref>{{cite journal
column25: title = Telomere measurement by quantitative PCR

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": While multiple companies offer telomere length measurement services, the utility of these measurements for widespread clinical or personal use has been questioned.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=A Blood Test Offers Clues to Longevity}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal
column5: title = Will your telomeres tell your future?
column11: doi = 10.1136/bmj.e1727 }}</ref> Nobel Prize winner [[Elizabeth Blackburn]], who was co-founder of one company, promoted the clinical utility of telomere length measures.<ref>{{cite journal
column13: title=Spit test offers guide to health

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Most research on telomere length and regulation, and its relationship to cancer and ageing, has been performed on mammals, especially humans, which have little or no somatic telomerase production. [[Ectotherm]]s are significantly more likely than endotherms to have variation in somatic telomerase expression. For instance, in many fish, telomerase occurs throughout the body (and associated with this, telomere length is roughly the same across all its tissue). Studies on ectotherms, and other non-mammalian organisms, show that there’s no single universal model of telomere erosion; rather, there is wide variation in relevant dynamics across Metazoa, and even within smaller taxonomic groups these patterns appear diverse. Due to the different reproductive timelines of some ectotherms, selection on disease is relevant for a much larger fraction of these creatures’ lives than it is for mammals, so early- and late-life telomere length, and their possible links to cancer, seem especially important in these species from a [[life history theory]] point of view.<ref>{{cite journal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: vauthors = Olsson M, Wapstra E, Friesen C
column3: title = Ectothermic telomeres: it's time they came in from the cold
column4: journal = Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological Sciences

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": *[http://nobelprize.org/mediaplayer/index.php?id=1214 Telomeres and Telomerase: The Means to the End] Nobel Lecture by [[Elizabeth Blackburn]], which includes a reference to the impact of stress, and pessimism on telomere length
*[http://nobelprize.org/mediaplayer/index.php?id=1216 Telomerase and the Consequences of Telomere Dysfunction] Nobel Lecture by [[Carol Greider]]
*[http://nobelprize.org/mediaplayer/index.php?id=1218 DNA Ends: Just the Beginning] Nobel Lecture by [[Jack Szostak]]
