→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": A 1961–62 National Housing Institute survey estimated that 13.8 percent of Belgian dwellings were unfit and incapable of improvement. A further 19.5 percent were unfit but had the potential to be improved, and 54 percent were considered suitable (without alteration or improvement) for modern living standards. Seventy-four percent of dwellings lacked a shower or bath, 19 percent had inadequate sewage disposal, and 3.6 percent lacked a drinking-water supply; 36.8 percent had an indoor [[Flush toilet
column9: date=August 2019}}</ref> According to a 1964 study, 13 percent of Belgium's housing consisted of [[slum]]s.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Between 1954 and 1973, the percentage of French homes with a shower or bath increased from 10 to 65 percent. During that period, the percentage of homes without flush toilets fell from 73 to 30 percent; homes without running water fell from 42 to 3.4 percent. A 1948 law permitted gradual, long-term rent increases for existing flats on the condition that part of the money was spent on repairs. According to [[John Ardagh]], the law, \"vigorously applied, was partly successful in its twofold aim: to encourage both repairs and new building.\"<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=The New France: A Society in Transition, 1945–1977

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Postwar housing conditions in the United Kingdom}}United Kingdom ===

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": After [[World War II]], a large percentage of British housing was single-family housing. Seventy-eight percent of housing in 1961 consisted of single-family homes, compared to 56 percent in the Netherlands, 49 percent in West Germany and 32 percent in France.<ref name=\"google4\">{{cite book
column6: title=Family Life in the Twentieth Century
column10: isbn=978-0-300-09494-7}}</ref> In England and Wales in 1964, 6.6 percent of housing units had two or fewer  rooms; 5.8 percent had seven or more rooms, 15.2 percent had six rooms, 35.1 percent had five rooms, 26.3 percent had four rooms, and 11.1 percent had three rooms. These figures included kitchens when they were used for eating meals. Fifty percent of 1964 housing had three bedrooms; 1.9 percent had five or more bedrooms, 6.2 percent had four bedrooms, 10.5 percent had one bedroom or none, and 31.3 percent had two bedrooms. A 1960 social survey estimated that 0.6 percent of households in England and Wales exceeded the statutory overcrowding standard; the 1964 percentage was 0.5 percent. In 1964, 6.9 of all households exceeded one person per room. The 1960 figure was 11 percent, with 1.75 percent having two or more bedrooms below the standard and 9.25 percent having one bedroom below the standard. This declined slightly by 1964 to 9.4 percent of households below the standard, with 8.1 percent having one bedroom below the standard and 1.3 percent having two bedrooms or more below the standard. According to local authorities in 1965, five percent of the housing stock in England and Wales was unfit for habitation.<ref>{{cite book
column16: publisher=Bedford Square P. of the National Council of Social Service

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Housing conditions in Canada and the United States of America}}U.S. and Canada ===

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Housing conditions improved in Canada and the U.S. after World War II. In the U.S., 35.4 percent of all 1950 dwellings did not have complete plumbing facilities; the figure fell to 16.8 percent in 1960 and 8.4 percent in 1968. In Canada from 1951 to 1971, the percentage of dwellings with a bath or shower increased from 60.8 to 93.4 percent; the percentage of dwellings with hot and cold running water increased from 56.9 to 93.5 percent.<ref name=\"ReferenceB\" /> In the United States from 1950 to 1974, the percentage of housing without full plumbing fell from 34 to three percent; during that period, the percentage of housing stock considered dilapidated fell from nine percent to less than four.<ref>{{cite book
* [[List of countries by number of households]]
* ''The Economist Book Of Vital World Statistics: A Complete Guide To The World In Figures'' (introduction by [[Claus Moser, Baron Moser
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Claus Moser]]). The Economist Books, fourth reprint, paperback edition, October 1992. Contains a section, \"Consumer Durables\", with estimates of household ownership of a wide range of consumer durables in [[OECD]] and East European countries.

column4: alt= Painting of a man feeding a baby, two women and another child

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": A '''household''' consists of one or several persons who live in the same [[dwelling]] and share meals. It may also consist of a single [[family]] or another group of people.<ref>{{cite book
column8: isbn=978-0-534-61020-3}}</ref> The household is the basic unit of analysis in many social, [[microeconomic]] and government models, and is important to [[economics]] and [[inheritance]].<ref>{{cite book

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: location    = Upper Saddle River, New Jersey 07458
shared housing]], [[group home]]s, [[boarding house]]s, [[house in multiple occupation
column3: houses of multiple occupancy]] (UK), and [[single room occupancy]] (US). In [[feudalism
column4: feudal]] societies, the [[Royal Household]] and [[medieval household]]s of the wealthy included [[Domestic worker

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": For statistical purposes in the [[United Kingdom]], a household is defined as \"one person or a group of people who have the accommodation as their only or main residence and for a group, either share at least one [[meal]] a day or share the living accommodation, that is, a [[living room]] or sitting room\".<ref>{{cite web
column7: archivedate=2008-06-26}}</ref> The introduction of legislation to control houses of multiple occupation in the UK Housing Act (2004)<ref name=\"Housing Act 2004\">{{cite web
column9: title=UK Housing Act 2004}} See section 258 on p. 201.</ref> required a tighter definition of a single household. People can be considered a household if they are related: full- or half-blood, foster, step-parent/child, in-laws (and equivalent for unmarried couples), a married couple or unmarried but \"living as ...\" (same- or different-sex couples).<ref name=\"www.getrentback.org\">{{cite web
column11: title=Single Household: brief summary of HA 2004 definition
column12: work=Flat Justice: Helping Tenants to Get Rent Back}}</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The [[United States Census]] definition also hinges on \"separate living quarters\": \"those in which the occupants live and eat separately from any other persons in the building.\"<ref>{{cite web
column9: archivedate=2015-04-27 }}</ref> According to the U.S. census, a householder is the \"person (or one of the people) in whose name the housing unit is owned or rented (maintained)\"; if no person qualifies, any adult resident of a housing unit is considered a householder. The U.S. government formerly used \"head of the household\" and \"head of the family\", but those terms were replaced with \"householder\" in 1980.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=U.S. Census: Current Population Survey – Definitions and Explanations
column16: archivedate=2012-03-22 }}</ref> In the census definition of a household, it

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: ... includes all the persons who occupy a housing unit. A housing unit is a house, an apartment, a mobile home, a group of rooms, or a single room that is occupied (or if vacant, is intended for occupancy) as separate living quarters. Separate living quarters are those in which the occupants live and eat separately from any other persons in the building and which have direct access from the outside of the building or through a common hall. The occupants may be a single family, one person living alone, two or more families living together, or any other group of related or unrelated persons who share living arrangements. (People not living in households are classified as living in group quarters.)<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Households, Persons Per Household, and Households with Individuals Under 18 Years, 2000

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": On July 15, 1998, [[Statistics Canada]] said: \"A household is generally defined as being composed of a person or group of persons who co-reside in, or occupy, a dwelling.\"<ref>{{cite web

Although a one-income-stream economic theory simplifies modeling, it does not necessarily reflect reality. Many, if not most, households have several income-earning members. Most economic models do not equate households and traditional families, and there is not always a one-to-one relationship between households and families.
In [[social work]], a household is defined similarly: a residential group in which [[Homemaking
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: housework]] is divided and performed by householders. [[Carer
column3: Care]] may be delivered by one householder to another, depending upon their respective needs, abilities, and (perhaps) [[Disability
column4: disabilities]]. Household composition may affect life and health expectations and outcomes for its members.<ref>{{cite book
column7: title = The role of household environment on health outcomes for female adolescents in Kenya
column15: title= A study of Nepalese families' paid and unpaid work after migration to Australia
column21: community services]] and [[welfare]] benefits may depend upon household composition.<ref>{{cite book
column26: title = Collins dictionary of social work

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In [[sociology]], household work strategy (a term coined by [[Ray Pahl]] in his 1984 book, ''Divisions of Labour'')<ref>{{cite web
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: title = Tributes paid to Professor Ray Pahl
column17: url = https://archive.org/details/divisionsoflabou0000pahl }}</ref> is the [[division of labour]] among members of a household. Household work strategies vary over the life cycle as household members age, or with the economic environment; they may be imposed by one person, or be decided collectively.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=household work strategy – Dictionary definition of household work strategy | Encyclopedia.com: FREE online dictionary

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": [[Feminism]] examines how [[gender role]]s affect the division of labour in households. In ''[[The Second Shift]]'' and ''The Time Bind'', sociologist [[Arlie Russell Hochschild]] presents evidence that in two-career couples men and women spend about equal amounts of time working; however, women spend more time on housework.<ref name=\"Hochschild1\">{{Cite book
column7: title = The second shift: working families and the revolution at home
column16: title = The time bind: when work becomes home and home becomes work
column21: 9780805066432}}</ref> [[Cathy Young]] (another feminist writer) says that in some cases, women may prevent the equal participation of men in housework and parenting.<ref>{{Cite web
column25: title = The Mama Lion at the Gate

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Household models in the [[English-speaking world]] include traditional and blended families, shared housing, and [[group home]]s for people with support needs. Other models which may meet definitions of a household include [[boarding house]]s, houses in multiple occupation (UK), and [[single room occupancy]] (US).

column3: aristocratic]] societies, a household may include servants or retainers who derive their income from the household's principal income.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": A 1961–62 National Housing Institute survey estimated that 13.8 percent of Belgian dwellings were unfit and incapable of improvement. A further 19.5 percent were unfit but had the potential to be improved, and 54 percent were considered suitable (without alteration or improvement) for modern living standards. Seventy-four percent of dwellings lacked a shower or bath, 19 percent had inadequate sewage disposal, and 3.6 percent lacked a drinking-water supply; 36.8 percent had an indoor [[Flush toilet
column9: date=August 2019}}</ref> According to a 1964 study, 13 percent of Belgium's housing consisted of [[slum]]s.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Between 1954 and 1973, the percentage of French homes with a shower or bath increased from 10 to 65 percent. During that period, the percentage of homes without flush toilets fell from 73 to 30 percent; homes without running water fell from 42 to 3.4 percent. A 1948 law permitted gradual, long-term rent increases for existing flats on the condition that part of the money was spent on repairs. According to [[John Ardagh]], the law, \"vigorously applied, was partly successful in its twofold aim: to encourage both repairs and new building.\"<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=The New France: A Society in Transition, 1945–1977

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Postwar housing conditions in the United Kingdom}}United Kingdom ===

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": After [[World War II]], a large percentage of British housing was single-family housing. Seventy-eight percent of housing in 1961 consisted of single-family homes, compared to 56 percent in the Netherlands, 49 percent in West Germany and 32 percent in France.<ref name=\"google4\">{{cite book
column6: title=Family Life in the Twentieth Century
column10: isbn=978-0-300-09494-7}}</ref> In England and Wales in 1964, 6.6 percent of housing units had two or fewer  rooms; 5.8 percent had seven or more rooms, 15.2 percent had six rooms, 35.1 percent had five rooms, 26.3 percent had four rooms, and 11.1 percent had three rooms. These figures included kitchens when they were used for eating meals. Fifty percent of 1964 housing had three bedrooms; 1.9 percent had five or more bedrooms, 6.2 percent had four bedrooms, 10.5 percent had one bedroom or none, and 31.3 percent had two bedrooms. A 1960 social survey estimated that 0.6 percent of households in England and Wales exceeded the statutory overcrowding standard; the 1964 percentage was 0.5 percent. In 1964, 6.9 of all households exceeded one person per room. The 1960 figure was 11 percent, with 1.75 percent having two or more bedrooms below the standard and 9.25 percent having one bedroom below the standard. This declined slightly by 1964 to 9.4 percent of households below the standard, with 8.1 percent having one bedroom below the standard and 1.3 percent having two bedrooms or more below the standard. According to local authorities in 1965, five percent of the housing stock in England and Wales was unfit for habitation.<ref>{{cite book
column16: publisher=Bedford Square P. of the National Council of Social Service

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Housing conditions in Canada and the United States of America}}U.S. and Canada ===

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Housing conditions improved in Canada and the U.S. after World War II. In the U.S., 35.4 percent of all 1950 dwellings did not have complete plumbing facilities; the figure fell to 16.8 percent in 1960 and 8.4 percent in 1968. In Canada from 1951 to 1971, the percentage of dwellings with a bath or shower increased from 60.8 to 93.4 percent; the percentage of dwellings with hot and cold running water increased from 56.9 to 93.5 percent.<ref name=\"ReferenceB\" /> In the United States from 1950 to 1974, the percentage of housing without full plumbing fell from 34 to three percent; during that period, the percentage of housing stock considered dilapidated fell from nine percent to less than four.<ref>{{cite book
* [[List of countries by number of households]]
* ''The Economist Book Of Vital World Statistics: A Complete Guide To The World In Figures'' (introduction by [[Claus Moser, Baron Moser
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Claus Moser]]). The Economist Books, fourth reprint, paperback edition, October 1992. Contains a section, \"Consumer Durables\", with estimates of household ownership of a wide range of consumer durables in [[OECD]] and East European countries.

column3: Arguably the most famous custom car in the classic style, the [[Hirohata Merc]]<ref>{{cite book

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: vehicle]] that has been either substantially altered to [[engine tuning
column3: improve its performance]], often by altering or replacing the [[engine]] and [[transmission (mechanics)
column4: transmission]]; made into a personal \"styling\" statement, using paint work and [[Aftermarket (automotive)
column5: aftermarket]] accessories to make the car look unlike any car as delivered from the factory; or some combination of both. A desire among some automotive enthusiasts in the United States is to push \"styling and performance a step beyond the showroom floor - to truly craft an automobile of one's own.\"<ref>{{cite book
column14: accessdate=24 February 2019}}</ref> A custom car in British according to ''[[Collins English Dictionary]]'' is built to the buyer's own specifications.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Custom car definition and meaning: Collins English Dictionary

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Although the two are related, custom cars are distinct from [[hot rod]]s. The extent of this difference has been the subject of debate among customizers and rodders for decades. Additionally, a [[street rod (car)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: street rod]] can be considered a custom.{{citation needed

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Custom cars are not to be confused with [[coachbuilder
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: coachbuilt]] automobiles, historically [[rolling chassis]] fitted with luxury bodywork by specialty body builders.

column3: The iconic \"[[T-bucket]]\" custom, with characteristic exposed engine, flat windshield, headers, and open pipes. Soft top (shown) is optional. Also features chrome five-spoke wheels, dropped tube axle, transverse front [[leaf spring]], front [[disc brake]]s, open-face [[air filter
column4: aircleaner]], Weiand [[valve cover]]s, and single [[carburetor#Multiple carburetor barrels
column6: QJ]]).]]<!--And don't go taking this out & claiming you can't see it; I shot the pictures myself!-->

column5: head]] and chrome carb hats on late-model [[Ford V8

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": A development of hot rodding, the change in name corresponded to the change in the [[design]] of the cars being modified. The first hot rods were pre-[[World War II]] cars, with [[running board]]s and simple fenders over the wheels. Early model cars (1929 to 1934) were modified by removing the running boards and either removing the fenders entirely or replacing them with light cycle fenders. Later models usually had fender skirts installed. The \"gow job\" morphed into the hot rod in the early to middle 1950s.<ref name=\"Shelton, Chris 2017, p.16\">Shelton, Chris. \"Then, Now, and Forever\" in ''Hot Rod'', March 2017, p.16.</ref> Typical of builds from before World War II were 1935 Ford [[wire wheel]]s.<ref>Shelton, Chris. \"Then, Now, and Forever\" in ''Hot Rod'', March 2017, p.18.</ref>

Many cars were \"hopped up\" with engine modifications such as adding additional carburetors, high compression heads, and dual exhausts. [[Engine swap]]s were often done, with the objective of placing the most powerful engine in the lightest possible frame and body combination.<ref name=\"Custom history\">{{cite web
column4: accessdate=2016-10-11}}</ref> The suspension was usually altered, initially by lowering the rear end as much as possible using lowering blocks on the rear springs. Later cars were given a rake job by either adding a dropped front axle or heating front coil springs to make the front end of the car much lower than the rear. Immediately postwar, most rods would change from mechanical to hydraulic (\"juice\") brakes and from bulb to sealed-beam headlights.<ref name=\"Shelton, Chris 2017, pp.18\">Shelton, Chris. \"Then, Now, and Forever\" in ''Hot Rod'', March 2017, pp.18 and 20.</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The mid-1950s and early 1960s custom Deuce was typically fenderless and steeply chopped, and almost all Ford (or Mercury, with the {{convert
column5: abbr=on}} flatty, introduced in 1939<ref name=\"Shelton, p.20\">Shelton, p.20.</ref>); a [[Halibrand]] quick-change rearend was also typical, and an [[Edelbrock]] [[intake manifold]] or Harman and Collins [[ignition magneto]] would not be uncommon.<ref>Shelton, pp.17-18.</ref> Reproduction spindles, brake drums, and backing based on the 1937s remain available today.<ref name=\"Shelton, p.20\"/> Aftermarket flatty heads were available from Barney Navarro,<ref name=\"Shelton, p.20 caption\">Shelton, p.20 caption.</ref> [[Edelbrock
column6: Vic Edelbrock]], and [[Offenhauser]]. The first intake manifold Edelbrock sold was a \"slingshot\" design for the flatty.<ref name=\"Shelton, p.20 caption\"/> Front suspension hairpins were adapted from [[sprint car]]s, such as the [[Kurtis Kraft]]s.<ref>Shelton, p.24 and p.26 caption.</ref> The first Jimmy [[Supercharging
column7: supercharger]] on a V8 may have been by Navarro in 1950.<ref>Shelton, p.26 caption.</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Much later, rods and customs swapped the old solid rear axle for an independent rear, often from [[Jaguar (car)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Jaguar]]. Sometimes the grille of one make of car replaced another; the 1937 [[Buick]] grille was often used on a [[Ford Motor Company
column3: Ford]]. In the 1950s and 1960s, the grille swap of choice was the 1953 [[DeSoto (automobile)
column4: DeSoto]]. The original hot rods were plainly painted like the [[Ford Model A (1927-1931)
column5: Model A Fords]] from which they had been built up, and only slowly begun to take on colors, and eventually fancy orange-yellow flamed hoods or \"candy-like\" deep acrylic finishes in the various colors.<ref name=\"Custom history\" />

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": With the change in automobile design to encase the wheels in fenders and to extend the hood to the full width of the car, the former practices were no longer possible. In addition, tremendous automotive advertising raised public interest in the new models in the 1950s. Thus, custom cars came into existence, swapping [[headlamp]] rings, grilles, bumpers, [[Chrome plating
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: chrome]] side strips, and taillights as well as [[Frenching (automobile)
column3: frenching]] and tunnelling head- and taillights. The bodies of the cars were changed by cutting through the sheet metal, removing bits to make the car lower, welding it back together, and adding [[lead]] to make the resulting form smooth (hence the term [[lead sled]]; [[Bondo (putty)
column4: Bondo]] has since largely replaced lead.) [[Chopped and channeled#Chopping
column5: Chopping]] made the roof lower<ref>''Rod Action'', 2/78, p.64.</ref> while [[Chopped and channeled#Sectioning
column6: sectioning]]<ref>''Street Rodder'', 2/78, p.15; ''Custom Rodder'' 1/97, p.29.</ref> made the body thinner from top to bottom. [[Chopped and channeled#Channeling
column7: Channeling]]<ref>Jezek, George. \"The All Deuce Round-Up\", in ''Street Rodder'', 2/78, p.58.</ref> was cutting notches in the floorpan where the body touches the frame to lower the whole body. Fins were often added from other cars, or made up from sheet steel. In the custom car culture, someone who merely changed the appearance without also substantially improving the performance was looked down upon. ''[[Juxtapoz Magazine]]'', founded by the artist [[Robert Williams (artist)
column8: Robert Williams]], has covered [[Kustom Kulture]] art.

column3: '55-7 Chevy with fuzzy dice]] <!--fuzzy dice are practically required-->

column4: 'Big Daddy' Roth]] 'bloodshot eyeball' [[shift knob]] was a 1960s craze.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Custom cars are distinct from cars in stock condition. Builders may adopt the visual and performance characteristics of some relevant modification styles, and combine these as desired. There are now several different custom themes, including:
* [[Rat rod]]: imitates (or exaggerates) the \"unfinished\" and amateur-built appearance of hot rods of the 1930s, 1940s, and 1950s

* Restomod - restored and modernized. Safety and convenience upgrades, such as disc brakes, AC, etc., but can include fuel injection and overdrive upgrades, etc. Externally might resemble a stock car with period correct mods rather than customs.
* Street machines: Typically American cars with large-displacement engines modified for speed and often appearance.
* Street rod - consist largely of period specific vehicles and components, or emulate visual characteristics of cars through the'40s vintage. There is a great deal of overlap here with [[hot rod]]s.

column3: '32 three-window with a classic-style flame job and [[Dean Moon

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Paint was an important concern. Once bodywork was done, the cars were painted unusual colors. Transparent but wildly colored candy-apple paint, applied atop a metallic undercoat, and [[metalflake]] paint, with aluminum glitter within candy-apple paint, appeared in the 1960s. These took many coats to produce a brilliant effect – which in hot climates had a tendency to flake off. This process and style of paint job was invented by Joe Bailon, a customizer from Northern California.

Customizers also continued the habit of adding decorative paint after the main coat was finished, of flames extending rearward from the front wheels, scallops, and hand-painted pinstripes of a contrasting color. The base color, most often a single coat, would be expected to be of a simpler paint. [[Flame job (painting technique)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Flame jobs]] later spread to the hood, encompassing the entire front end, and have progressed from traditional reds and yellows to blues and greens and body-color \"ghost\" flames. One particular style of flames, called \"crab claw flames\", which is still prevalent today, is attributed to Dean Jeffries.<ref>Hotrod magazine, 1999.</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Painting has become such a part of the custom car scene that now in many custom car competitions, awards for custom paint are as highly sought after as awards for the cars themselves.
Engine swaps have always been commonplace. Once, the [[Ford flathead V8 engine]] was the preference, supplanted by the [[Chrysler FirePower engine
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: early hemi]] in the 1950s and 1960s. By the 1970s, the [[Chevrolet small-block engine#Small block Chevrolet V8 (1955–1998)
column3: small-block Chevy]] was the most common option, and since the 1980s, the {{convert
column8: abbr=on}} Chevy has been almost ubiquitous.<ref>See any issue of ''Street Rodder'', for instance.</ref> The {{convert
column14: Chevrolet LS]] has begun replacing the 350.{{citation needed
column15: date=July 2015}} Flatheads and early hemis have not entirely disappeared, but ready availability, ease of maintenance, and low cost of parts make the Chevrolet V8, in particular the first and third generation small block, the most frequent engine of choice.{{citation needed

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Once customizing post-war cars caught on, some of the practices were extended to pre-war cars, which would have been called fendered rods, with more body work done on them. An alternate rule for disambiguation developed: hot rods had the engine behind the front suspension, while customs had the engine over the front suspension. The clearest example of this is [[Ford Motor Company
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Fords]] prior to 1949 had [[Henry Ford]]'s old transverse front suspension, while 1949 models had a more modern suspension with the engine moved forward. However, an American museum has what could be the first true custom, built by [[Cletus Clobes]] in 1932, among its exhibits.<ref>{{cite web
column9: archivedate=2008-09-28 }}</ref> With the coming of the muscle car, and further to the high-performance luxury car, customization declined. One place where it persisted was the U.S. Southwest, where [[lowrider]]s were built similar in concept to the earlier customs, but of post-1950s cars.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": As the supply of usable antique steel bodies has decreased, companies such [[Westcott Auto Restyling
column3: Harwood]], [[Gibbon Fiberglass]]<ref name=\"%2526quot%253BStreet Rodder, 2/78, p.43\">''Street Rodder'', 2/78, p. 43.</ref> and [[Speedway Motors]]<ref name=\"%2526quot%253BStreet Rodder, 2/78, p.43\"/> have begun to fabricate new [[fiberglass]] copies,<ref>See, for instance, ''Street Rodder'', 8/99, p.183.</ref> while [[Classic Manufacturing and Supply]], for one example, has been making a variety of new steel bodies since the 1970s.<ref>''Street Rodder'', 7/94, pp.132-4.</ref> California's \"junker\" (or \"crusher\") law, which pays a nominal sum to take \"gross polluters\" off the road, has been criticized by enthusiasts (and by SEMA) for accelerating this trend.<ref>See, for instance, Dick Wells column \"SRMA Update\", ''Street Rodder'', 8/99, p.234.</ref> Starting in the 1950s, it became popular among customizers to display their vehicles at drive-in restaurants, such as [[Johnie's Broiler]] in [[Downey, California]]. The practice continues in Southern California.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Examples of notable customizers include [[George Barris (auto customizer)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: George Barris]], [[Vini Bergeman]], [[Bill Cushenberry]], the [[The Alexander Brothers
column3: Alexander Brothers]], [[Gil Ayala]],<ref>''Rod & Custom'', 8/89, p.60.</ref> [[Darryl Starbird]],<ref name=\"Street Rodder, 1/85, p.56\">''Street Rodder'', 1/85, p.56.</ref> [[Roy Brizio]], [[Troy Trepanier]] (of [[Rad Rides by Troy]]), [[Boyd Coddington]], [[Darryl Hollenbeck]] (working out of at Vintage Color Studios; winner of the 2016 [[America's Most Beautiful Roadster]] (AMBR) trophy with a custom Deuce)<ref name=\"Shelton, Chris 2017, p.16\"/> [[Harry Westergaard]],<ref>''Rod & Custom'', 8/89, p.55.</ref> [[Dave Stuckey]],<ref name=\"Street Rodder, 1/85, p.56\"/> [[Dean Jeffries]], [[Barry Lobeck]], [[Phil Cool]] (who won the 1978 AMBR trophy with a bright orange Deuce, cover car for the July 1978 issue of ''Hot Rod''),<ref>Shelton, Chris. \"Then, Now, and Forever\" in ''Hot Rod'', March 2017, p.23.</ref> [[Troy Ladd]] of [[Hollywood Hot Rods]], [[Doane Spencer]] (builder of a 1940s Deuce considered the template for the hiboy),<ref>Shelton, p.29.</ref> [[Ken Fenical
column6: Bob Kaiser]] (of [[Clarkaiser Custom]]s),<ref>Fetherston, David, \"Detroit Dreams\", in ''Rod & Custom'', 7/95, p.58.</ref> [[Joe Bailon]]<ref name=\"Street Rodder, 1/85, p.56\"/> (inventor of candy apple paint),<ref>Ganahl, Pat, \"The Candy Man\", in ''Rod & Custom'', 7/95, p.81.</ref> [[Gene Winfield]], [[Rick Dore]]<ref>{{Cite web
column14: \"Magoo\"]],<ref>''Street Rodder'', 12/98, p.206.</ref> [[Chip Foose]],<ref>Bishop, Mike, \"The 45th Grand National Roadster Show\", in ''American Rodder'', 6/94, p.27.</ref> and [[Pete Chapouris]].

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Von Dutch]], are best known as custom painters. Several customizers have become famous beyond the automobile community, including Barris, Jeffries, and Coddington, thanks to their proximity to [[Hollywood]]; Barris designed TV's [[Batmobile]], while Chapouris built the [[The California Kid (custom car)
column3: flamed '34 three-window coupé]] in the eponymous [[television film
column4: telefilm]] \"[[The California Kid]]\". Another Barris creation, [[Ala Kart (custom car)
column6: Model A]] roadster pickup), made numerous appearances in film (usually in the background of diner scenes and such), after taking two AMBR wins in a row. Some customizers have become well-enough known to be referred to by given name alone. These include Boyd (Coddington), Pete (Chapouris), and Jake (Jim Jacobs).

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The highest award for customizers is the AMBR ([[America's Most Beautiful Roadster]]) trophy, presented annually at the Grand National Roadster Show since 1948 (also known within the customizer community as the Oakland Roadster Show until it was moved to Southern California in 2003). This competition has produced famous, and radical, customs.

Another is the [[Ridler Award]], presented at the [[Detroit Autorama]] since 1964 in honor of show promoter Don Ridler. With one of the most unusual of car show entry requirements, winners of the prestigious Ridler Award are selected as the most outstanding from among cars being shown for the first time. This prompts builders of many high-end roadsters to first enter the Autorama first and then the Grand National show in order to have the chance to win top honors at both shows. Few cars and owners can claim this achievement.
Some customs gained attention for winning the AMBR trophy, or for their outlandish styling. Notable among these is [[Silhouette (show car)
column3: ''Mysterion'']]. Some of these more unusual projects turned into [[Hot Wheels]] cars, among them [[The Red Baron (custom car)

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Other custom cars became notable for appearances in film (such as ''Ala Kart'' {1958},<ref>''Hot Rod'', 12/86, p.29 sidebar.</ref> ''The California Kid'' three-window {1973},<ref>''Hot Rod'', 12/86, p.29.</ref> or the yellow deuce from \"[[American Graffiti]]\" {1973}) or television (such as ''The [[Monkeemobile]]'', the [[The Munsters
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: \"Munsters\"]] hearse, or, more recently, Boyd's full-custom [[Home Improvement (TV series)
column3: ''Tool Time'']] '34, or [[Don Thelan]]'s<ref>Gingerelli, Dain. \"Jake's '34\". Written on June 23, 2005 [http://www.hotrod.com/features/history/articles/0009sr-1934-ford-three-window-coupe-milestone/ ''Hot Rod'' Magazine online] (retrieved 19 June 2015)</ref> '33 three-window, ''Eliminator'', built for the [[ZZ Top]] video<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=The ZZ Top Eliminator: Profile of a Hot Rod
column9: accessdate=2010-10-31}}</ref>). Specialist vehicles, such as the [[Pontiac Trans-Am
column11: ''Knight Rider'']], are not usually considered customs, but movie or TV cars, because they retain a mostly stock exterior.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Still others exemplified a trend. One of these is the '51 Merc built by the Barris brothers for Bob Hirohata in 1953, known forever after as the [[Hirohata Merc]]. Even without an appearance in film (\"Runnin' Wild\"), it is iconic of 1950s customs, and of how to do a Merc right.<ref>''Rod & Custom'', 8/89, pp.8 & 10.</ref> The same year, [[Neil Emory]] and [[Clayton Jensen]] of [[Valley Custom Shop]] built [[Polynesian (custom car)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: ''Polynesian'']] for Jack Stewart, starting with a '50 [[Oldsmobile 88#First generation (1949–1953)
column3: Holiday 88 sedan]].<ref>[http://www.customrodder.com/features/0609cr_1950_oldsmobile_polynesian/index.html%7C_new ''Custom Rodder'' online] (retrieved 28 July 2018)</ref> ''Polynesian'' made the cover of [[Hot Rod Magazine
column4: ''Hot Rod'']] in August, and saw 54 pages of construction details in ''[[Motor Trend]] Custom Car Annual'' in 1954.<ref>''Rod & Custom'', 8/89, p.68.</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Certain linguistic conventions are followed among rodders and customizers:

* The [[model year]] is rarely given in full,<ref>For instance, ''Street Rodder'', 8/99, ''passim''; ''Rod Action'', 2/78, ''passim''; ''Hot Rod'', October 1987, pp,8, 10, 18, 20, & 22.</ref> except when it might be confused, so a 1934 model is a '34, while a 2005 might be an '05 or not.
** A '32 is usually a Deuce and most often a roadster, unless [[coupé]] is specified, and almost always a Ford, now commonly on [[Ford Model A (1927–1931)
column3: frame rails]].<ref name=\"Fortier, Rob p.136\">Fortier, Rob. \"\"A Little Pinch Here, A Little Tuck There\", in ''Street Rodder'', 8/99, p.136.</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": ** A 1955, 1956, or 1957 is usually a Chevrolet.
** A 1955, 1956, or 1957 Chevrolet is often called a [[Tri-Five]].
* A 3- or 5-window is usually a Ford, unless specified.
* A flatty is a [[Ford flathead V8 engine
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: flathead V8]]<ref>''American Rodder'', 6/94, pp.45 & 93.</ref> (always Ford, unless specified); a late (or late model) flatty is probably a [[Mercury (automobile)

hemi]] (\"''hem'' ee\") is always a 426, unless displacement (331, 354, or 392) is specified;<ref>Geisert, Eric. \"Tom's Fun Run\", in ''Street Rodder'', 8/99, p.149cap.</ref> a 426 is a hemi, unless [[Chrysler RB engine#426
column3: Wedge]] is specified. See baby hemi.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": ** A 331 or 354 is known to be an (early) hemi, but rarely referred to as such

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": * Units are routinely dropped, unless they are unclear, so a 426 cubic inch (in<sup>3</sup>) displacement engine is simply referred to as a 426, a 5-liter (litre) displacement engine is a 5.0 (\"five point oh\"), and a 600 [[cubic feet per minute]] (cfm) carburetor is a 600. Engine displacement can be described in cubic inches or liters (for example, a 5.7-liter engine is also known as a 350 {\"three fifty\"}); this frequently depends on which units the user is most comfortable or familiar with.<ref name=\"Freiburger, David 1993, p.45\">Freiburger, David. \"Hot Rod Dictionary\", in ''Hot Rod'', July 1993, p.45.</ref>
The \"cutoff year\" as originally promoted by the ''National Street Rod Association'' ([[National Street Rod Association
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: NSRA]]) is 1949. Many custom car shows will only accept 1948 and earlier models as entries, and many custom car organizations will not admit later model cars or trucks (also with some imports - this has been a gray area of what's acceptable e.g. an aircooled VW Beetle, a Big Three product manufactured overseas e.g. a [[Ford Capri]] built in the UK or a [[Holden
column3: General Motors - Holden's]] product, not to mention [[captive imports
column4: captives]]), and/or a vintage import automobile with an American driveline transplant but this practice is subject to change. Modern day custom car shows which allow the inclusion of [[muscle car]]s have used the 1972 model year as the cutoff since it is considered the end of the muscle car era prior to the introduction of the [[catalytic converter]]. The NSRA has announced that starting in 2011 it will switch to a shifting year method where any owner with a car 30 years or older will be allowed membership. So in 2011 the owner of a 1981 model year vehicle will qualify, then in 2012 the owner of a 1982 model year vehicle will quality, and so on. Additionally, the Goodguys car show organization has moved the year limit for its \"rod\" shows from 1949 to 1954 in recent years.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": A development of hot rodding, the change in name corresponded to the change in the [[design]] of the cars being modified. The first hot rods were pre-[[World War II]] cars, with [[running board]]s and simple fenders over the wheels. Early model cars (1929 to 1934) were modified by removing the running boards and either removing the fenders entirely or replacing them with light cycle fenders. Later models usually had fender skirts installed. The \"gow job\" morphed into the hot rod in the early to middle 1950s.<ref name=\"Shelton, Chris 2017, p.16\">Shelton, Chris. \"Then, Now, and Forever\" in ''Hot Rod'', March 2017, p.16.</ref> Typical of builds from before World War II were 1935 Ford [[wire wheel]]s.<ref>Shelton, Chris. \"Then, Now, and Forever\" in ''Hot Rod'', March 2017, p.18.</ref>

Many cars were \"hopped up\" with engine modifications such as adding additional carburetors, high compression heads, and dual exhausts. [[Engine swap]]s were often done, with the objective of placing the most powerful engine in the lightest possible frame and body combination.<ref name=\"Custom history\">{{cite web
column4: accessdate=2016-10-11}}</ref> The suspension was usually altered, initially by lowering the rear end as much as possible using lowering blocks on the rear springs. Later cars were given a rake job by either adding a dropped front axle or heating front coil springs to make the front end of the car much lower than the rear. Immediately postwar, most rods would change from mechanical to hydraulic (\"juice\") brakes and from bulb to sealed-beam headlights.<ref name=\"Shelton, Chris 2017, pp.18\">Shelton, Chris. \"Then, Now, and Forever\" in ''Hot Rod'', March 2017, pp.18 and 20.</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The mid-1950s and early 1960s custom Deuce was typically fenderless and steeply chopped, and almost all Ford (or Mercury, with the {{convert
column5: abbr=on}} flatty, introduced in 1939<ref name=\"Shelton, p.20\">Shelton, p.20.</ref>); a [[Halibrand]] quick-change rearend was also typical, and an [[Edelbrock]] [[intake manifold]] or Harman and Collins [[ignition magneto]] would not be uncommon.<ref>Shelton, pp.17-18.</ref> Reproduction spindles, brake drums, and backing based on the 1937s remain available today.<ref name=\"Shelton, p.20\"/> Aftermarket flatty heads were available from Barney Navarro,<ref name=\"Shelton, p.20 caption\">Shelton, p.20 caption.</ref> [[Edelbrock
column6: Vic Edelbrock]], and [[Offenhauser]]. The first intake manifold Edelbrock sold was a \"slingshot\" design for the flatty.<ref name=\"Shelton, p.20 caption\"/> Front suspension hairpins were adapted from [[sprint car]]s, such as the [[Kurtis Kraft]]s.<ref>Shelton, p.24 and p.26 caption.</ref> The first Jimmy [[Supercharging
column7: supercharger]] on a V8 may have been by Navarro in 1950.<ref>Shelton, p.26 caption.</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Much later, rods and customs swapped the old solid rear axle for an independent rear, often from [[Jaguar (car)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Jaguar]]. Sometimes the grille of one make of car replaced another; the 1937 [[Buick]] grille was often used on a [[Ford Motor Company
column3: Ford]]. In the 1950s and 1960s, the grille swap of choice was the 1953 [[DeSoto (automobile)
column4: DeSoto]]. The original hot rods were plainly painted like the [[Ford Model A (1927-1931)
column5: Model A Fords]] from which they had been built up, and only slowly begun to take on colors, and eventually fancy orange-yellow flamed hoods or \"candy-like\" deep acrylic finishes in the various colors.<ref name=\"Custom history\" />

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": With the change in automobile design to encase the wheels in fenders and to extend the hood to the full width of the car, the former practices were no longer possible. In addition, tremendous automotive advertising raised public interest in the new models in the 1950s. Thus, custom cars came into existence, swapping [[headlamp]] rings, grilles, bumpers, [[Chrome plating
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: chrome]] side strips, and taillights as well as [[Frenching (automobile)
column3: frenching]] and tunnelling head- and taillights. The bodies of the cars were changed by cutting through the sheet metal, removing bits to make the car lower, welding it back together, and adding [[lead]] to make the resulting form smooth (hence the term [[lead sled]]; [[Bondo (putty)
column4: Bondo]] has since largely replaced lead.) [[Chopped and channeled#Chopping
column5: Chopping]] made the roof lower<ref>''Rod Action'', 2/78, p.64.</ref> while [[Chopped and channeled#Sectioning
column6: sectioning]]<ref>''Street Rodder'', 2/78, p.15; ''Custom Rodder'' 1/97, p.29.</ref> made the body thinner from top to bottom. [[Chopped and channeled#Channeling
column7: Channeling]]<ref>Jezek, George. \"The All Deuce Round-Up\", in ''Street Rodder'', 2/78, p.58.</ref> was cutting notches in the floorpan where the body touches the frame to lower the whole body. Fins were often added from other cars, or made up from sheet steel. In the custom car culture, someone who merely changed the appearance without also substantially improving the performance was looked down upon. ''[[Juxtapoz Magazine]]'', founded by the artist [[Robert Williams (artist)
column8: Robert Williams]], has covered [[Kustom Kulture]] art.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Custom cars are distinct from cars in stock condition. Builders may adopt the visual and performance characteristics of some relevant modification styles, and combine these as desired. There are now several different custom themes, including:
* [[Rat rod]]: imitates (or exaggerates) the \"unfinished\" and amateur-built appearance of hot rods of the 1930s, 1940s, and 1950s

* Restomod - restored and modernized. Safety and convenience upgrades, such as disc brakes, AC, etc., but can include fuel injection and overdrive upgrades, etc. Externally might resemble a stock car with period correct mods rather than customs.
* Street machines: Typically American cars with large-displacement engines modified for speed and often appearance.
* Street rod - consist largely of period specific vehicles and components, or emulate visual characteristics of cars through the'40s vintage. There is a great deal of overlap here with [[hot rod]]s.

column3: '32 three-window with a classic-style flame job and [[Dean Moon

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Paint was an important concern. Once bodywork was done, the cars were painted unusual colors. Transparent but wildly colored candy-apple paint, applied atop a metallic undercoat, and [[metalflake]] paint, with aluminum glitter within candy-apple paint, appeared in the 1960s. These took many coats to produce a brilliant effect – which in hot climates had a tendency to flake off. This process and style of paint job was invented by Joe Bailon, a customizer from Northern California.

Customizers also continued the habit of adding decorative paint after the main coat was finished, of flames extending rearward from the front wheels, scallops, and hand-painted pinstripes of a contrasting color. The base color, most often a single coat, would be expected to be of a simpler paint. [[Flame job (painting technique)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Flame jobs]] later spread to the hood, encompassing the entire front end, and have progressed from traditional reds and yellows to blues and greens and body-color \"ghost\" flames. One particular style of flames, called \"crab claw flames\", which is still prevalent today, is attributed to Dean Jeffries.<ref>Hotrod magazine, 1999.</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Painting has become such a part of the custom car scene that now in many custom car competitions, awards for custom paint are as highly sought after as awards for the cars themselves.
Engine swaps have always been commonplace. Once, the [[Ford flathead V8 engine]] was the preference, supplanted by the [[Chrysler FirePower engine
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: early hemi]] in the 1950s and 1960s. By the 1970s, the [[Chevrolet small-block engine#Small block Chevrolet V8 (1955–1998)
column3: small-block Chevy]] was the most common option, and since the 1980s, the {{convert
column8: abbr=on}} Chevy has been almost ubiquitous.<ref>See any issue of ''Street Rodder'', for instance.</ref> The {{convert
column14: Chevrolet LS]] has begun replacing the 350.{{citation needed
column15: date=July 2015}} Flatheads and early hemis have not entirely disappeared, but ready availability, ease of maintenance, and low cost of parts make the Chevrolet V8, in particular the first and third generation small block, the most frequent engine of choice.{{citation needed

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Once customizing post-war cars caught on, some of the practices were extended to pre-war cars, which would have been called fendered rods, with more body work done on them. An alternate rule for disambiguation developed: hot rods had the engine behind the front suspension, while customs had the engine over the front suspension. The clearest example of this is [[Ford Motor Company
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Fords]] prior to 1949 had [[Henry Ford]]'s old transverse front suspension, while 1949 models had a more modern suspension with the engine moved forward. However, an American museum has what could be the first true custom, built by [[Cletus Clobes]] in 1932, among its exhibits.<ref>{{cite web
column9: archivedate=2008-09-28 }}</ref> With the coming of the muscle car, and further to the high-performance luxury car, customization declined. One place where it persisted was the U.S. Southwest, where [[lowrider]]s were built similar in concept to the earlier customs, but of post-1950s cars.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": As the supply of usable antique steel bodies has decreased, companies such [[Westcott Auto Restyling
column3: Harwood]], [[Gibbon Fiberglass]]<ref name=\"%2526quot%253BStreet Rodder, 2/78, p.43\">''Street Rodder'', 2/78, p. 43.</ref> and [[Speedway Motors]]<ref name=\"%2526quot%253BStreet Rodder, 2/78, p.43\"/> have begun to fabricate new [[fiberglass]] copies,<ref>See, for instance, ''Street Rodder'', 8/99, p.183.</ref> while [[Classic Manufacturing and Supply]], for one example, has been making a variety of new steel bodies since the 1970s.<ref>''Street Rodder'', 7/94, pp.132-4.</ref> California's \"junker\" (or \"crusher\") law, which pays a nominal sum to take \"gross polluters\" off the road, has been criticized by enthusiasts (and by SEMA) for accelerating this trend.<ref>See, for instance, Dick Wells column \"SRMA Update\", ''Street Rodder'', 8/99, p.234.</ref> Starting in the 1950s, it became popular among customizers to display their vehicles at drive-in restaurants, such as [[Johnie's Broiler]] in [[Downey, California]]. The practice continues in Southern California.

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: George Barris]], [[Bill Cushenberry]], the [[The Alexander Brothers

column6: Bob Kaiser]] (of [[Clarkaiser Custom]]s),<ref>Fetherston, David, \"Detroit Dreams\", in ''Rod & Custom'', 7/95, p.58.</ref> [[Joe Bailon]]<ref name=\"Street Rodder, 1/85, p.56\"/> (inventor of candy apple paint),<ref>Ganahl, Pat, \"The Candy Man\", in ''Rod & Custom'', 7/95, p.81.</ref> [[Gene Winfield]], [[Rick Dore]]<ref>{{Cite web

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Von Dutch]], are best known as custom painters. Several customizers have become famous beyond the automobile community, including Barris, Jeffries, and Coddington, thanks to their proximity to [[Hollywood]]; Barris designed TV's [[Batmobile]], while Chapouris built the [[The California Kid (custom car)
column3: flamed '34 three-window coupé]] in the eponymous [[television film
column4: telefilm]] \"[[The California Kid]]\". Another Barris creation, [[Ala Kart (custom car)
column6: Model A]] roadster pickup), made numerous appearances in film (usually in the background of diner scenes and such), after taking two AMBR wins in a row. Some customizers have become well-enough known to be referred to by given name alone. These include Boyd (Coddington), Pete (Chapouris), and Jake (Jim Jacobs).

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The highest award for customizers is the AMBR ([[America's Most Beautiful Roadster]]) trophy, presented annually at the Grand National Roadster Show since 1948 (also known within the customizer community as the Oakland Roadster Show until it was moved to Southern California in 2003). This competition has produced famous, and radical, customs.

Another is the [[Ridler Award]], presented at the [[Detroit Autorama]] since 1964 in honor of show promoter Don Ridler. With one of the most unusual of car show entry requirements, winners of the prestigious Ridler Award are selected as the most outstanding from among cars being shown for the first time. This prompts builders of many high-end roadsters to first enter the Autorama first and then the Grand National show in order to have the chance to win top honors at both shows. Few cars and owners can claim this achievement.
Some customs gained attention for winning the AMBR trophy, or for their outlandish styling. Notable among these is [[Silhouette (show car)
column3: ''Mysterion'']]. Some of these more unusual projects turned into [[Hot Wheels]] cars, among them [[The Red Baron (custom car)

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: \"Munsters\"]] hearse, or, more recently, Boyd's full-custom [[Home Improvement (TV series)

Written on June 23, 2005 [http://www.hotrod.com/features/history/articles/0009sr-1934-ford-three-window-coupe-milestone/ ''Hot Rod'' Magazine online] (retrieved 19 June 2015)</ref> '33 three-window, ''Eliminator'', built for the [[ZZ Top]] video<ref>{{cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Still others exemplified a trend. One of these is the '51 Merc built by the Barris brothers for Bob Hirohata in 1953, known forever after as the [[Hirohata Merc]]. Even without an appearance in film (\"Runnin' Wild\"), it is iconic of 1950s customs, and of how to do a Merc right.<ref>''Rod & Custom'', 8/89, pp.8 & 10.</ref> The same year, [[Neil Emory]] and [[Clayton Jensen]] of [[Valley Custom Shop]] built [[Polynesian (custom car)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: ''Polynesian'']] for Jack Stewart, starting with a '50 [[Oldsmobile 88#First generation (1949–1953)
column3: Holiday 88 sedan]].<ref>[http://www.customrodder.com/features/0609cr_1950_oldsmobile_polynesian/index.html%7C_new ''Custom Rodder'' online] (retrieved 28 July 2018)</ref> ''Polynesian'' made the cover of [[Hot Rod Magazine
column4: ''Hot Rod'']] in August, and saw 54 pages of construction details in ''[[Motor Trend]] Custom Car Annual'' in 1954.<ref>''Rod & Custom'', 8/89, p.68.</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Certain linguistic conventions are followed among rodders and customizers:

* The [[model year]] is rarely given in full,<ref>For instance, ''Street Rodder'', 8/99, ''passim''; ''Rod Action'', 2/78, ''passim''; ''Hot Rod'', October 1987, pp,8, 10, 18, 20, & 22.</ref> except when it might be confused, so a 1934 model is a '34, while a 2005 might be an '05 or not.
** A '32 is usually a Deuce and most often a roadster, unless [[coupé]] is specified, and almost always a Ford, now commonly on [[Ford Model A (1927–1931)
column3: frame rails]].<ref name=\"Fortier, Rob p.136\">Fortier, Rob. \"\"A Little Pinch Here, A Little Tuck There\", in ''Street Rodder'', 8/99, p.136.</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": ** A 1955, 1956, or 1957 is usually a Chevrolet.
** A 1955, 1956, or 1957 Chevrolet is often called a [[Tri-Five]].
* A 3- or 5-window is usually a Ford, unless specified.
* A flatty is a [[Ford flathead V8 engine
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: flathead V8]]<ref>''American Rodder'', 6/94, pp.45 & 93.</ref> (always Ford, unless specified); a late (or late model) flatty is probably a [[Mercury (automobile)

hemi]] (\"''hem'' ee\") is always a 426, unless displacement (331, 354, or 392) is specified;<ref>Geisert, Eric. \"Tom's Fun Run\", in ''Street Rodder'', 8/99, p.149cap.</ref> a 426 is a hemi, unless [[Chrysler RB engine#426
column3: Wedge]] is specified. See baby hemi.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": ** A 331 or 354 is known to be an (early) hemi, but rarely referred to as such
* A 270 \"Jimmy\" was a 270 cubic inch [[Chevrolet Straight-6 engine#270
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: GMC truck engine]] often used to replace a smaller displacement Chevrolet six cylinder.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": * Units are routinely dropped, unless they are unclear, so a 426 cubic inch (in<sup>3</sup>) displacement engine is simply referred to as a 426, a 5-liter (litre) displacement engine is a 5.0 (\"five point oh\"), and a 600 [[cubic feet per minute]] (cfm) carburetor is a 600. Engine displacement can be described in cubic inches or liters (for example, a 5.7-liter engine is also known as a 350 {\"three fifty\"}); this frequently depends on which units the user is most comfortable or familiar with.<ref name=\"Freiburger, David 1993, p.45\">Freiburger, David. \"Hot Rod Dictionary\", in ''Hot Rod'', July 1993, p.45.</ref>
The \"cutoff year\" as originally promoted by the ''National Street Rod Association'' ([[National Street Rod Association
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: NSRA]]) is 1949. Many custom car shows will only accept 1948 and earlier models as entries, and many custom car organizations will not admit later model cars or trucks (also with some imports - this has been a gray area of what's acceptable e.g. an aircooled VW Beetle, a Big Three product manufactured overseas e.g. a [[Ford Capri]] built in the UK or a [[Holden
column3: General Motors - Holden's]] product, not to mention [[captive imports
column4: captives]]), and/or a vintage import automobile with an American driveline transplant but this practice is subject to change. Modern day custom car shows which allow the inclusion of [[muscle car]]s have used the 1972 model year as the cutoff since it is considered the end of the muscle car era prior to the introduction of the [[catalytic converter]]. The NSRA has announced that starting in 2011 it will switch to a shifting year method where any owner with a car 30 years or older will be allowed membership. So in 2011 the owner of a 1981 model year vehicle will qualify, then in 2012 the owner of a 1982 model year vehicle will quality, and so on. Additionally, the Goodguys car show organization has moved the year limit for its \"rod\" shows from 1949 to 1954 in recent years.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": * Trailer queen — pejorative term for pure show cars which are never driven<ref name=\"Freiburger, David 1993, p.45\"/>
* Tuck-and-roll — upholstery technique creating a \"pleated\" look<ref>Tann, Jeff, \"Two-Timer\" in ''Rod & Custom'', 9/00, p.58.</ref>
* Tunneled — deeply sunken into fender<ref name=\"%2526quot%253BStreet Rodder, 12/98, p.212\"/>
* V-butted (or vee-butted) — with windshield center post deleted, original panes meeting in the middle<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Kustoms and Hot Rods Gallery: Hirohata Merc
column8: archivedate=2011-07-07 }}</ref> (distinct from fitting a one-piece windshield), or to make such a change (\"the windshield was vee-butted\", \"he vee-butted the windshield\")

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": * Vicky — Victoria body style<ref>''Hot Rod'', 4/95, p.36.</ref>

* Wide whites — wide-stripe [[whitewall tire]]s,<ref>Fortier, Rob. \"25th Salt Lake City Autorama\", in ''Street Rodder'', 8/99, p.51cap, ''Rod & Custom'',  7/95, p.143cap.</ref> typical of the 1950s, as opposed to modern ones.
* Woodie — Typically a station wagon manufactured by most of the major manufacturers where much of the body behind the firewall was replaced with wood construction.
Some terms have an additional, different meaning among [[hot rod]]ders than among customizers: NOS, for instance, is a reference to [[nitrous oxide]], rather than new old stock.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": '''Penn Dayton Badgley''' (born November 1, 1986) is an American actor and musician. He has received wide media attention, including for his roles as [[Dan Humphrey]] in [[The CW]] teen drama series ''[[Gossip Girl]]'' (2007–2012), and as [[Joe Goldberg]] in the [[Netflix]] thriller series ''[[You (TV series)
Badgley has appeared in a number of films, including

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: The Stepfather]]'' (2009), ''[[Easy A]]'' (2010),  ''[[Margin Call]]'' (2011), and ''[[Greetings from Tim Buckley]]'' (2012). He is also the lead singer for [[Brooklyn]]-based [[indie music
column3: indie]] band [[MOTHXR]], whose studio album, ''[[Centerfold]]'', was released in 2016.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": he is oficially dating maria simões

<!--NO MATERIAL ADDED WITHOUT RELIABLE SOURCE. THIS IS NOT ABOUT YOUR PERSONAL KNOWLEDGE (THAT IS PROHIBITED BY WP:ORIGINAL RESEARCH), AND IT IS NOT ABOUT PLAGIARISM, WHAT CAN BE TAKEN FROM OTHERS' KNOWLEEDGE WITHOUT GIVING CREDIT (THAT IS PROHIBITED BY WP:VERIFY).-->
Badgley was born Penn Dayton Badgley on born November 1, 1986,<ref>{{cite web
column11: archivedate=October 19, 2012 }}</ref> in [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]], the son of Duff and Lynne Murphy Badgley.<ref name = SwansonVulture20130428>{{cite web
column14: title=Penn Badgley's Mission to Reclaim His Own Celebrity With Greetings From Tim Buckley
column23: title=Gossip Girl Jewelry, Mama knows best when it comes to gorgeous baubles...
column30: url-status=live }}</ref> His father had worked as a newspaper reporter and then as a carpenter and home builder, and was the [[Green Party of the United States
column31: Green Party]] candidate for governor of [[State of Washington
column32: Washington]] in 2008.<ref name = SwansonVulture20130428/> An only child,<ref name = SwansonVulture20130428/> Badgley split his childhood years between [[Woodlake, Virginia]], and [[Seattle, Washington]].{{cn
column33: date=March 2020}} He attended Woolridge Elementary (where his mother served as a PTA president),{{cn
column34: date=March 2020}} before he transferred to [[St. Christopher's School, Richmond
column36: date=March 2020}} He attended Charles Wright Academy in [[Tacoma, Washington]],{{cn
column37: date=March 2020}} and was involved with the [[Seattle Children's Theatre]].{{cn
column38: date=March 2020}} He soon began doing [[voiceover]]s for children's radio stations.{{where
column40: date=March 2020}} His mother supported his acting efforts, and worked various jobs (later, beginning a business in jewelry design with Badgley's godmother, Jan Sneed).<ref name = HarrisDetails20080930>{{cite web
column52: quote = [Gossip girl] is his fourth prime-time series... Ironically, in real life Penn skipped high school altogether. He took a proficiency exam at 14 and entered Santa Monica College soon after... Penn... was home-schooled with Blake a decade ago, when both were child actors, calls the relationship 'wonderful...'... He didn't grow up poor, but his parents divorced when he was 12, and there were lean-ish times after he and his mother, who'd worked at Home Depot, left Washington State for California so that he could pursue acting. For him, acting is work it's how you make sure you can pay for your own car and make your rent... He talks about his love for writing music... 'I hope in five years... I no longer look at acting as a job but as a creative passion. That's how I want to be different.'}}</ref><ref name = HaverFoS20081207/><ref>{{cite web
column55: title=Blake Lively Steps Out with Penn Badgley's Family

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Badgley and his mother relocated to California so that he could pursue an acting career,<ref name = HarrisDetails20080930/> and he recalls in interview departing for [[Los Angeles, California
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Los Angeles]] at age 11.<ref name=\"guardian\">{{cite web
column4: title=Penn Badgley: 'Gossip Girl was an endurance test'
column11: url-status=live }}</ref> In that period, he is said to have been [[home schooling
column12: home schooled]] alongside [[Blake Lively]], his future co-star and partner.<ref name = HarrisDetails20080930/> His parents divorced when he was 12.<ref name = HarrisDetails20080930/> He recalls having \"wanted to make music... as a 12-year-old\", and recorded an unreleased pop single in 1998, referring in interview to the effort as \"terrible\" and \"misguided\".<ref name=\"guardian\"/> Badgely, whose acting work has included several long stints playing high school characters, actually \"skipped high school altogether\"; at age 14, he took a proficiency exam and began attending [[Santa Monica College]].<ref name = HarrisDetails20080930/><ref>There is a degree of discrepancy in the accounts of his secondary schooling, whether advancing by high school equivalence or by graduation; the account presented is the one most specific. He has otherwise replied to a question whose preface included, \"You... graduated from high school at 13\", saying \"You end up doing all of this... graduating high school, spending your life on sets.\" See Iqbal & Badgley, 2013, ''op. cit.''</ref> He was later accepted to the [[University of Southern California]], but deferred admission due to contractual obligations,{{cn
column13: date=March 2020}} later enrolling for two years at [[Lewis & Clark College]] in [[Portland, Oregon]].{{cn

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Badgley's first credit was voice work for the video games ''[[Mario Golf (Nintendo 64)
column3: Mario Tennis 64]]'' in 1999 and 2000.<ref name=\"guardian\"/> His first screen acting credit was on an episode of ''[[Will & Grace]]'' and he subsequently appeared on shows such as ''[[Daddio]]'', ''[[The Brothers García]]'', and ''[[What I Like About You (TV series)
column4: What I Like About You]]''.<ref name=\"CWBio2008\">{{cite web
column11: access-date=January 3, 2018}}</ref> His first noticeable role was as [[Chance Chancellor
column12: Phillip Chancellor IV]] on the soap opera ''[[The Young and the Restless]]'', from 2000 to 2001. He was nominated for a 2001 [[Young Artist Award]] for Best Performance in a Daytime Series for his work.<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=Where Are They Now? Penn Badgley

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In 2002, he starred in [[The WB]]'s comedy-drama series ''[[Do Over]]'' as Joel Larsen, a 34-year-old man who gets a second chance to get his life right, thanks to a freakish accident that catapults him back to 1980, as a 14-year-old. Badgley went on to star in two other WB series: ''[[The Mountain (TV series)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: The Mountain]]'' (2004–2005) and ''[[The Bedford Diaries]]'' (2006).<ref name=\"CWBio2008\"/>

column11: url-status=live }}</ref> In its opening weekend, the film grossed a total of $14.3 million, ranking third in the US [[box office]] results for that weekend.<ref>{{cite web

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: the book series of the same name]] by [[Cecily von Ziegesar]]. He initially turned down the role, but accepted after the producers struggled finding someone to fill the role.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Penn Badgley Speaks Candidly About His Jeff Buckley Movie and the End of Gossip Girl
column12: url-status=live }}</ref> In 2009, he starred in thriller film ''[[The Stepfather (2009)
column13: The Stepfather]]'', a remake of the [[The Stepfather (1987 film)
column14: 1987 film]], as the stepson of the serial killer.<ref>{{cite web
column24: url-status=live }}</ref> Badgley then played Todd, the love interest of [[Emma Stone]]'s character, in the teen comedy film ''[[Easy A]]'' (2010).

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In 2011, he was named one of [[People (magazine)
column3: title=25 Beauties (and Hotties) at 25 - Penn Badgley
column10: url-status=live}}</ref> and [[BuddyTV]] ranked him number 75 on its \"TV's 100 Sexiest Men of 2011\" list.<ref>{{cite web
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> He also appeared in the financial thriller drama ''[[Margin Call]]'' (2011).<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Penn Badgley Interview EASY A; Plus Updates on MARGIN CALL and GOSSIP GIRL
column27: url-status=live }}</ref> In late June of that year,  Badgley reportedly would portray [[Jeff Buckley]] in ''[[Greetings from Tim Buckley]]''. The movie follows the journey Jeff Buckley took in grappling with the legacy of his late musician father, Tim, leading up to and culminating with his 1991 performance of his father's songs.<ref>{{cite web
column28: title=Penn Badgley To Play Jeff Buckley In 'Greetings From Tim Buckley' Film
column35: url-status=live}}</ref> For the role, Badgley said he took guitar and vocal lessons.<ref>{{cite web
column36: title=Penn Badgley Knows There's Skepticism About His Ability to Play Jeff Buckley
column45: url-status=live}}</ref> Badgley joined the cast of ''[[Parts per Billion]]'' in December 2012, opposite [[Alexis Bledel]] and [[Teresa Palmer]].<ref>{{cite web
column47: title=Penn Badgley & 'CSI: NY's Hill Harper Join 'Parts Per Billion'
column55: url-status=live }}</ref> The film was released in 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column57: title=Love May Not Survive in Parts Per Billion Home Entertainment Release

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Cymbeline]]'' as the orphan Posthumus.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Penn Badgley Added To Shakespeare Adaptation 'Cymbeline'

column61: title=Greg Berlanti's ''You'' Moves to Netflix as Lifetime Bails on Season 2

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": During the [[2008 United States presidential election]], Badgley supported [[Barack Obama]].{{cn
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: date=March 2020}} He and [[Blake Lively]] appeared in an Obama commercial as part of [[MoveOn]]'s Youth Vote program.{{cn
column3: date=March 2020}} The commercial, directed by [[Doug Liman]], aired during ''Gossip Girl'' on The CW, [[MTV]], and [[Comedy Central]].<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Blake Lively & Penn Badgley Go for Laughs in Pro-Obama Ad
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> In March 2010, the [[American Red Cross]] announced Badgley as a member of the National Celebrity Cabinet, a group of celebrities who promote Red Cross services.<ref>{{cite press release
column12: title=American Red Cross Adds Eight New Members to its Celebrity Cabinet
column20: url-status=dead}}</ref> A \"huge soccer fan\", Badgley joined forces with [[Brad Pitt]] to bring the [[FIFA World Cup]] to the United States in 2018 or 2022.<ref name=\"guardian\"/><ref>{{cite web
column22: title=Brad Pitt Kicks in For U.S. World Cup Bid

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Badgley is a friend of Baltimore activist [[DeRay McKesson]],<ref>{{cite tweet
column4: title=throwback pic from my birthday dinner, w/ @Travon, @PennBadgley and David.
column6: access-date=January 4, 2018}}</ref> whom he met during the Occupy Wall Street movement, and considers himself an ally of the [[Black Lives Matter]] movement.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Penn Badgley joins the fight to end racism
column20: publisher=Facebook}}</ref> Badgley wants the police brutality dialogue to include female victims.<ref>{{cite tweet
column23: title=Keep peeling layers off, see misogyny runs deep thru racism like an inflamed nerve. We gotta talk abt the women too
column26: access-date=January 4, 2018}}</ref> He also supports LGBT rights.<ref>{{cite web
column33: access-date=January 4, 2018}}</ref> Badgley began a search for spirituality in 2010, while shooting an early season of Gossip Girl.{{cn
column34: date=March 2020}} In an interview with Shadi Toloui-Wallace, Penn describes how the [[BP oil spill]] prompted his exploration into the connection between justice and spirituality, and led him to the rainforests of Colombia and the teaching of [[Baháʼu'lláh]] and the [[Baháʼí Faith]].<ref name = TolouiWallaceBahaiTeachings>{{cite web
column37: title=How the Baha’i Faith Changed Penn Badgley’s Life
column42: date=March 2020}} In the interview, Badgley shares how Baha’u’llah's \"[[The Seven Valleys]]\", and Baha’i faith's \"[[The Promise of World Peace]]\" were important in his spiritual pursuits.<ref name = TolouiWallaceBahaiTeachings/>{{verification needed
column43: date=March 2020}} Badgley has been a member of the Baha'i faith since 2015 and is an outspoken activist against the [[persecution of Baháʼís]] by [[Iran]].<ref>{{Cite web
column45: title=Penn Badgley talks Baha’i faith and religious discrimination

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Badgley began dating singer [[Domino Kirke]] in 2014.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=‘Gossip Girl’ Alum Penn Badgley Returns To Television In Greg Berlanti’s Thriller ‘You’
column7: url-status=live }}</ref> Badgley married Kirke in a New York courthouse on February 27, 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Gossip Girl Alum Penn Badgley Is Married to Domino Kirke
column16: url-status=live }}</ref> He is the stepfather of Kirke's son, Cassius.{{cn
column17: date=March 2020}} In February 2020, Kirke and Badgley announced they are expecting their first child together, after suffering two miscarriages.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Penn Badgley and Wife Domino Kirke Expecting First Child After 'Two Miscarriages in a Row'
column24: accessdate=February 11, 2020}}</ref> As a teenager, Badgley dated Seneca Rice,{{when
column26: date=March 2020}} and later, ''[[Gossip Girl]]'' co-star Blake Lively (for four years), and actress [[Zoë Kravitz]].{{cn

column12: home schooled]] alongside [[Blake Lively]], his future co-star and partner.<ref name = HarrisDetails20080930/> His parents divorced when he was 12.<ref name = HarrisDetails20080930/> He recalls having \"wanted to make music... as a 12-year-old\", and recorded an unreleased pop single in 1998, referring in interview to the effort as \"terrible\" and \"misguided\".<ref name=\"guardian\"/> Badgely, whose acting work has included several long stints playing high school characters, actually \"skipped high school altogether\"; at age 14, he took a proficiency exam and began attending [[Santa Monica College]].<ref name = HarrisDetails20080930/><ref>There is a degree of discrepancy in the accounts of his secondary schooling, whether advancing by high school equivalence or by graduation; the account presented is the one most specific. He has otherwise replied to a question whose preface included, \"You... graduated from high school at 13\", saying \"You end up doing all of this... graduating high school, spending your life on sets.\" See Iqbal & Badgley, 2013, ''op. cit.''</ref> He was later accepted to the [[University of Southern California]], but deferred admission due to contractual obligations,{{cn
column13: date=March 2020}} later enrolling for two years at [[Lewis & Clark College]] in [[Portland, Oregon]].{{cn

column3: Mario Tennis 64]]'' in 1999 and 2000.<ref name=\"guardian\"/> His first screen acting credit was on an episode of ''[[Will & Grace]]'' and he subsequently appeared on shows such as ''[[Daddio]]'', ''[[The Brothers García]]'', and ''[[What I Like About You (TV series)
column4: What I Like About You]]''.<ref name=\"CWBio2008\">{{cite web

column14: title=Where Are They Now? Penn Badgley

Badgley went on to star in two other WB series: ''[[The Mountain (TV series)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: The Mountain]]'' (2004–2005) and ''[[The Bedford Diaries]]'' (2006).<ref name=\"CWBio2008\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": During the [[2008 United States presidential election]], Badgley supported [[Barack Obama]].{{cn
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: date=March 2020}} He and [[Blake Lively]] appeared in an Obama commercial as part of [[MoveOn]]'s Youth Vote program.{{cn
column3: date=March 2020}} The commercial, directed by [[Doug Liman]], aired during ''Gossip Girl'' on The CW, [[MTV]], and [[Comedy Central]].<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Blake Lively & Penn Badgley Go for Laughs in Pro-Obama Ad
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> In March 2010, the [[American Red Cross]] announced Badgley as a member of the National Celebrity Cabinet, a group of celebrities who promote Red Cross services.<ref>{{cite press release
column12: title=American Red Cross Adds Eight New Members to its Celebrity Cabinet
column20: url-status=dead}}</ref> A \"huge soccer fan\", Badgley joined forces with [[Brad Pitt]] to bring the [[FIFA World Cup]] to the United States in 2018 or 2022.<ref name=\"guardian\"/><ref>{{cite web
column22: title=Brad Pitt Kicks in For U.S. World Cup Bid

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Badgley is a friend of Baltimore activist [[DeRay McKesson]],<ref>{{cite tweet
column4: title=throwback pic from my birthday dinner, w/ @Travon, @PennBadgley and David.
column6: access-date=January 4, 2018}}</ref> whom he met during the Occupy Wall Street movement, and considers himself an ally of the [[Black Lives Matter]] movement.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Penn Badgley joins the fight to end racism
column20: publisher=Facebook}}</ref> Badgley wants the police brutality dialogue to include female victims.<ref>{{cite tweet
column23: title=Keep peeling layers off, see misogyny runs deep thru racism like an inflamed nerve. We gotta talk abt the women too
column26: access-date=January 4, 2018}}</ref> He also supports LGBT rights.<ref>{{cite web
column33: access-date=January 4, 2018}}</ref> Badgley began a search for spirituality in 2010, while shooting an early season of Gossip Girl.{{cn
column34: date=March 2020}} In an interview with Shadi Toloui-Wallace, Penn describes how the [[BP oil spill]] prompted his exploration into the connection between justice and spirituality, and led him to the rainforests of Colombia and the teaching of [[Baháʼu'lláh]] and the [[Baháʼí Faith]].<ref name = TolouiWallaceBahaiTeachings>{{cite web
column37: title=How the Baha’i Faith Changed Penn Badgley’s Life
column42: date=March 2020}} In the interview, Badgley shares how Baha’u’llah's \"[[The Seven Valleys]]\", and Baha’i faith's \"[[The Promise of World Peace]]\" were important in his spiritual pursuits.<ref name = TolouiWallaceBahaiTeachings/>{{verification needed
column43: date=March 2020}} Badgley has been a member of the Baha'i faith since 2015 and is an outspoken activist against the [[persecution of Baháʼís]] by [[Iran]].<ref>{{Cite web
column45: title=Penn Badgley talks Baha’i faith and religious discrimination

column3: title=‘Gossip Girl’ Alum Penn Badgley Returns To Television In Greg Berlanti’s Thriller ‘You’
column7: url-status=live }}</ref> Badgley married Kirke in a New York courthouse on February 27, 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Gossip Girl Alum Penn Badgley Is Married to Domino Kirke
column16: url-status=live }}</ref> He is the stepfather of Kirke's son, Cassius.{{cn
column17: date=March 2020}} In February 2020, Kirke and Badgley announced they are expecting their first child together, after suffering two miscarriages.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Penn Badgley and Wife Domino Kirke Expecting First Child After 'Two Miscarriages in a Row'
column24: accessdate=February 11, 2020}}</ref> As a teenager, Badgley dated Seneca Rice,{{when
column26: date=March 2020}} and later, ''[[Gossip Girl]]'' co-star Blake Lively (for four years), and actress [[Zoë Kravitz]].{{cn
