image_map_caption      = The Ajuuraan Sultanate in the 15th century

column3: دولة الأجورانيون}}), also spelled '''Ajuuraan Sultanate''',<ref name=\"His 40\">{{cite book
column12: page=40}}</ref> and often simply as '''Ajuran''',<ref>{{Cite web
column16: Somali]] [[empire]] in the medieval times that dominated the Indian ocean trade. They belonged to the [[Somali people
column21: title=Somali Sultanate: the Geledi city-state over 150 years
column26: page=17}}</ref><ref>Luc Cambrézy, Populations réfugiées: de l'exil au retour, p.316</ref><ref>{{cite journal
column29: title=The Emergence and Role of Political Parties in the Inter-River Region of Somalia from 1947–1960
column35: year=1989 }}</ref> that ruled over large parts of the [[Horn of Africa]] in the [[Medieval
column36: Middle Ages]]. Through a strong centralized administration and an aggressive military stance towards invaders, the Ajuran Sultanate successfully resisted an [[Oromo people
column38: invasion]] from the west and a [[Portuguese Empire
column39: Portuguese]] incursion from the east during the Gaal Madow and the [[Ajuran Sultanate#Ajuran-Portuguese wars
column40: Ajuran-Portuguese wars]]. Trading routes dating from the ancient and early medieval periods of [[Maritime history of Somalia
column41: Somali maritime enterprise]] were strengthened or re-established, and foreign trade and commerce in the coastal provinces flourished with ships sailing to and coming from many kingdoms and empires in [[East Asia]], [[South Asia]], [[Europe]], the [[Near East]], [[North Africa]] and [[East Africa]].<ref name=\"Shapes\">{{cite book
column44: title=Nation Shapes: The Story behind the World's Borders

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The sultanate left an extensive [[Somali architecture
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: architectural legacy]], being one of the major medieval Somali powers engaged in castle and [[fortress]] building. Many of the ruined fortifications dotting the landscapes of southern Somalia today are attributed to the Ajuran Sultanate's engineers,<ref name=\"Shs\">{{cite book
column6: title=The Shaping of Somali Society: Reconstructing the History of a Pastoral People, 1600–1900
column11: url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mlhyAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA101}}</ref> including a number of the [[pillar tomb]] fields, [[necropolis]]es and [[ruin
column12: ruined cities]] built in that era. During the Ajuran period, many regions and people in the southern part of the [[Horn of Africa]] converted to [[Islam]] because of the [[theocratic]] nature of the government.<ref name=\"Cultural\">{{cite encyclopedia
column16: title=Cultural Sociology of the Middle East, Asia, and Africa: An Encyclopedia
column20: isbn=978-1-4129-8176-7}}</ref> The [[royal family]], the House of Garen, expanded its territories and established its hegemonic rule through a skillful combination of [[warfare]], [[trade

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": As an [[hydraulic empire]], the Ajuran monopolized the [[water resources]] of the [[Shebelle River
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Shebelle]] and [[Jubba river]]s. Through [[hydraulic engineering]], it also constructed many of the [[limestone]] [[Water well
column3: wells]] and [[cistern]]s of the state that are still operative and in use today. The rulers developed new systems for agriculture and taxation, which continued to be used in parts of the [[Horn of Africa]] as late as the 19th century.<ref name=\"His 40\"/> The rule of the later Ajuran rulers caused multiple rebellions to break out in the sultanate, and at the end of the 17th century, the [[Ajuran Sultanate#Decline and successor states
column4: Ajuran state disintegrated]] into several successor kingdoms and states, the most prominent being the [[Geledi Sultanate]].{{sfnp

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Ajuran Sultanate's sphere of influence in the [[Horn of Africa]] was one of the largest in the region. The sultanate covered much of southern [[Somalia]],<ref name=\"Shapes\"/><ref name=\"Michigan\">{{cite book
column6: publisher=African Studies Center, Michigan State University
column7: page=115}}</ref> with its domain extending from [[Mareeg]] in the north, to [[Kelafo
column8: Qelafo]] in the west, to [[Kismayo]] in the south.{{sfnp

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The House of Garen was the ruling hereditary [[dynasty]] of the Ajuran Sultanate.<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=A Modern History of Somalia: Nation and State in the Horn of Africa
column14: title=Horn and Crescent: Cultural Change and Traditional Islam on the East African Coast, 800–1900
column21: isbn=9780521523097 }}</ref> Its origin lies in the Garen Kingdom that during the 13th century ruled parts of the [[Ogaden]], the [[Somali region]] of [[Ethiopia]]. With the migration of Somalis from the northern half of the Horn region to the southern half, new cultural and religious orders were introduced that influenced the administrative structure of the [[dynasty]], a system of governance which began to evolve into an [[Sharia
column23: Baraka]], which came from the saint Balad (who was known to have come from outside the Garen Kingdom),<ref name=\"Dic 35\">{{cite book
column32: page=35}}</ref> the Garen rulers claimed supremacy and religious legitimacy over other groups in the Horn of Africa. Balad's ancestors are said to have come from the historical northern region of [[Barbara (region)

column5: The city of [[Merca]] was one of several prominent [[administrative center]]s of the Ajurans.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Ajuran nobility used many of the typical [[Somali aristocratic and court titles]], with the Garen rulers styled [[Somali aristocratic and court titles#Rulers
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Imam]]. These leaders were the sultanate's highest authority, and counted multiple [[Sultan]]s, [[Emir]]s, and [[Monarch
column3: Kings]] as clients or [[vassal]]s. The Garen rulers also had seasonal palaces in [[Mareeg]], [[Kelafo
column4: Qelafo]] and [[Merca]], which they would periodically visit to practice ''[[primae noctis]]''.<ref name=\"Crescent\" /> Other important cities in the Sultanate were Mogadishu and [[Barawa]]. The state religion was [[Islam]], and thus law was based on [[Sharia]].

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Through their control of the region's wells, the Garen rulers effectively held a monopoly over their [[nomadic]] subjects as they were the only [[hydraulic empire]] in Africa during their reign. Large wells made out of [[limestone]] were constructed throughout the state, which attracted [[Somali people
column3: Oromo]] nomads with their livestock. The centralized regulations of the wells made it easier for the nomads to settle disputes by taking their queries to government officials who would act as mediators. Long distance caravan trade, a long-time practice in the Horn of Africa, continued unchanged in Ajuran times. Today, numerous ruined and abandoned towns throughout the interior of Somalia and the Horn of Africa are evidence of a once-booming inland trade network dating from the medieval period.{{sfnp

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": With the centralized supervision of the Ajuran, farms in [[Afgooye]], [[Kismayo]] and other areas in the [[Jubba Valley
column3: Shabelle]] valleys increased their productivity. A system of irrigation ditches known locally as ''Kelliyo'' fed directly from the [[Shebelle River
column4: Shebelle]] and [[Jubba river]]s into the plantations where [[sorghum]], [[maize]], beans, grain and cotton were grown during the ''gu'' ([[Spring (season)
column5: Spring]] in Somali) and ''xagaa'' ([[Summer]] in Somali) seasons of the [[Somali calendar]]. This irrigation system was supported by numerous [[Levee
column6: dikes]] and dams. To determine the average size of a farm, a land measurement system was also invented with ''moos'', ''taraab'' and ''guldeed'' being the terms used.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The State collected [[tribute]] from the farmers in the form of harvested products like [[durra]], sorghum and bun, and from the nomads, cattle, camels and goats. The collecting of tribute was done by a [[Vizier
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: wazir]]. Luxury goods imported from foreign lands were also presented as gifts to the Garen rulers by the coastal [[sultan]]s of the state.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": A political device that was implemented by the Garen rulers in their realm was a form of ''[[ius primae noctis]]'',{{Citation needed
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: date=October 2016}} which enabled them to create marriages that enforced their [[Hegemony
column3: hegemonic]] rule over all the important groups of the empire. The rulers would also claim a large portion of the bride's wealth, which at the time was 100 camels.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": For trade, the Ajuran Sultanate minted its own [[Ajuran currency]].<ref name=\"Stgi\"/> It also utilized the [[Mogadishu currency
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Mogadishan currency]] originally minted by the [[Sultanate of Mogadishu]], which later became incorporated into the Ajuran sultanate.<ref name=\"Cites\">{{cite book
column10: title=Cities of the Middle East and North Africa: A Historical Encyclopedia
column15: page=253}}</ref> Mogadishan coins have been found as far away as the present-day country of the [[United Arab Emirates]] in the [[Middle East]].<ref name=\"Ncaaroth\">{{cite book
column18: title=An Archaeological Reconnaissance in the Horn: The British-Somali Expedition, 1975

column5: Medieval [[Kismayo]] was used by Ajuuran state to utilize the [[Jubba River]] for its plantations.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The urban centers of [[Merca]], [[Mogadishu]], [[Barawa]], and their respective ports became profitable trade outlets for commodities originating from the interior of the State. The farming communities of the hinterland brought their products to the coastal cities, where they were sold to local merchants who maintained a lucrative foreign commerce with ships sailing to and coming from [[Arabia]], [[India]], [[Venetian Republic
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Venice]],<ref>Journal of African History pg.50 by John Donnelly Fage and Roland Anthony Oliver{{Full citation needed
column3: date=October 2016}}</ref> [[Persia]], [[Egypt]], [[Portugal]], and as far away as [[China]]. [[Vasco Da Gama]], who passed by Mogadishu in the 15th century, noted that it was a large city with houses of four or five storeys high and big palaces in its centre and many mosques with cylindrical minarets.<ref>Da Gama's First Voyage pg.88{{Full citation needed
column4: date=October 2016}}</ref> In the 16th century, [[Duarte Barbosa]] noted that many ships from the Kingdom of [[History of Gujarat#Muslim Period
column5: Cambaya]] sailed to Mogadishu with cloths and spices for which they in return received [[gold]], [[wax]] and [[ivory]]. Barbosa also highlighted the abundance of meat, wheat, barley, horses, and fruit on the coastal markets, which generated enormous wealth for the merchants.<ref>East Africa and its Invaders pg.38{{Full citation needed
column6: date=October 2016}}</ref> Mogadishu, the center of a thriving weaving industry known as ''toob benadir'' (specialized for the markets in Egypt and [[Syria]]),<ref>{{cite journal
column8: title=Gujarat and the Trade of East Africa, c. 1500–1800
column11: journal=The International Journal of African Historical Studies
column17: jstor=217389}}</ref> together with Merca and Barawa also served as transit stops for [[Swahili people
column18: Swahili]] merchants from [[Mombasa]] and [[Malindi]] and for the gold trade from [[Kilwa Kisiwani
column22: title=The Return of Cosmopolitan Capital: Globalization, the State and War
column28: Hormuz]] also brought their Indian textile and fruit to the Somali coast in exchange for [[grain]] and wood.<ref>{{cite book
column31: title=The Arabian Seas: The Indian Ocean World of the Seventeenth Century: The Indian Ocean World of the Seventeenth Century

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Trading relations were established with [[Malacca]] in the 15th century,{{sfnp
column4: page=30}} with cloth, [[ambergris]] and [[porcelain]] being the main commodities of the trade.<ref>Chinese Porcelain Marks from Coastal Sites in Kenya: aspects of trade in the Indian Ocean, XIV-XIX centuries. Oxford: British Archaeological Reports, 1978 pg 2</ref> In addition, giraffes, zebras and incense were exported to the [[Ming Dynasty
column5: Ming Empire]] of China, making Somali merchants leaders in the commerce between Asia and Africa.<ref>East Africa and its Invaders pg.37</ref> and influencing the [[Mandarin Chinese
column6: Chinese language]] on Somali in the process. [[Hindu]] merchants from [[Surat]] and Southeast African merchants from [[Pate Island
column7: Pate]] seeking to bypass both the Portuguese blockade and [[Omani]] interference used the Somali ports of Merca and Barawa (which were out of the two powers' jurisdiction) to conduct their trade in safety and without interference.<ref>Gujarat and the Trade of East Africa pg.45</ref>

column6: Sequin coins]] from the [[Venetian Empire]] in Europe.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Ajuran sultanate relied on agriculture and trade for most of its income. Major agricultural towns were located on the [[Shebelle River
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Shebelle]] and [[Jubba river]]s, including [[Kismayo]] and [[Afgooye]]. Situated at the junction of some of the busiest medieval trade routes, the Ajuran and its clients were active participants in the East African [[Gold
column5: trade in the Indian Ocean]], and commercial enterprise as far as [[East Asia]].

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Ajuran Sultanate also minted its own [[Ajuran currency]]. Many ancient [[bronze]] coins inscribed with the names of Ajuran Sultans have been found in the coastal Benadir province, in addition to pieces from Muslim rulers of [[Southern Arabia]] and [[Persia]].<ref name=\"Stgi\">{{cite book
column6: publisher=Ministry of Information and National Guidance, Somali Democratic Republic
column10: Mogadishan coins]] have been found as far as the [[United Arab Emirates]] in the [[Middle East]]. Trading routes dating from the ancient and early medieval periods of [[Maritime history of Somalia
column11: Somali maritime enterprise]] were strengthened or re-established, and foreign trade and commerce in the coastal provinces flourished with ships sailing to and coming from a myriad of kingdoms and empires in [[East Asia]], [[South Asia]], [[Europe]], the [[Near East]], [[North Africa]] and the [[Horn of Africa]].<ref name=\"Shapes\"/> Through the use of commercial vessels, compasses, multiple port cities, light houses and other technology, the merchants of the Ajuran Sultanate did brisk business with traders from the following states:

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": ! Trading countries in Asia !! Imports !! Exports

column4: The [[Ajuran Empire]] maintained commercial ties with the [[Ming dynasty]] and other kingdoms.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": With their maritime pursuits and history, the Sultanate established trading and diplomatic ties across the old world, especially in Asia – from being a close ally to the grand power of the [[Ottomans]] to having cordial ties to the mighty [[Ming Dynasty]], even having their merchants following of the greatest maritime expedition in their history as far as [[Java]] and [[Vietnam]].<ref name=\"Shelley2013\">{{cite book
column3: title=Nation Shapes: The Story Behind the World's Borders

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Somali]] Ajuran Empire sent ambassadors to [[China]] to establish diplomatic ties, creating the first ever recorded African community in China and the most notable [[Somali people
column3: Somali]] ambassador in medieval China was [[Sa'id of Mogadishu]] who was the first African man to set foot in [[China]]. In return, Emperor Yongle, the third emperor of the [[Ming Dynasty]] (1368–1644), dispatched one of the largest fleets in history to trade with the Somali nation. The fleet, under the leadership of the famed Hui Muslim [[Zheng He]], arrived at [[Mogadishu]] the capital of Ajuran Empire while the city was at its zenith. Along with [[gold]], [[frankincense]] and [[fabric]]s, Zheng brought back the first ever African wildlife to China, which included [[hippo]]s, [[giraffe]]s and [[gazelle]]s.<ref>Wilson, Samuel M. \"The Emperor's Giraffe\", ''Natural History'' Vol. 101, No. 12, December 1992 {{cite web
column14: title=Chinese archaeologists' African quest for sunken ship of Ming admiral
column18: title=Could a rusty coin re-write Chinese-African history?
column21: title=Zheng He'S Voyages to the Western Oceans 郑和下西洋

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Ajuran State was an influential Somali kingdom that held sway over several cities and towns in central and southern Somalia during the Middle Ages. With the [[Ajuran Sultanate#Decline and successor states
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: fall of the Sultanate]], a number of these settlements continued to prosper, eventually becoming [[List of Somali cities by population
column3: major cities]] in present-day Somalia. A few of these cities and towns were also abandoned or destroyed:

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": *[[Merca]] (port city in the [[Lower Shebelle]] region of Somalia)
*[[Mogadishu]] (harbor city and current capital of Somalia)
*[[Hobyo]] (harbor city in the [[Mudug]] region of Somalia
*[[Kismayo]] (port city in the [[Lower Juba]] region of Somalia)
*[[Barawa]] (port town in the [[Lower Shebelle]] region of Somalia)
*[[Warsheikh]] (port town in the [[Middle Shebelle]] region of Somalia)
*[[Afgooye]] (town in the [[Lower Shebelle]] region of Somalia)
*[[Gondershe]] (Abandoned, but now a popular tourist attraction site)
The Ajurans facilitated a rich culture with various forms of [[Culture of Somalia
column4: art]] evolving and flourishing during this period. The majority of the inhabitants were ethnic [[Somali people
column5: Somali]], but there was also a [[Yemen]]i, [[Persian people
column7: Turkish]] minority. The vast majority of the population also adhered to [[Sunni]] [[Islam]] with a [[Shia]] minority (mostly those of Persian descent). Somali was the most commonly used language of government and social life while [[Arabic language
column8: Arabic]] was most prominently used for [[Madrasa

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The most famous Somali scholar of Islam from the Ajuraan period is [[Sheikh Hussein (saint)]] of [[Merca]] , sheikh Hussein was born in [[Merca]] one of the power jurisdiction and cultural centers of Ajuran Empire.<ref>{{Cite journal
column12: title=Some Records of Ethiopia, 1593–1646: Being Extracts from 'The History of High Ethiopia or Abassia' by Manoel de Almeida, Together with Bahrey's 'History of the Galla'
column19: jstor=1791718}}</ref> And is credited for converting the [[Sidama people
column20: Sidamo]] people living in the area of what is now the [[Bale Province, Ethiopia]] to [[Islam]] . He is also credited for establishing a dynasty that ruled the [[Sultanate of Bale]].<ref>{{Cite journal
column24: title=Contemporary Ethiopia. By David A. Talbot. New York: Philosophical Library. 1952. xxi+267 pages. – Islam in Ethiopia. By J. Spencer Trimingham. London: Geoffrey Cumberlege, Oxford University Press, 1952. iv+299 pages.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": He's tomb lies in the town of [[Sheikh Hussein]] in what is the most sacred place in the country for Ethiopian Muslims mostly [[Oromo people
column4: title=Islamic History and Culture in Southern Ethiopia: Collected Essays

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Somali [[martial art]] [[Istunka]], also known as Dabshid, was born during their reign. An annual tournament is held every year for it in [[Afgooye]].{{sfnp
column4: page=28}} Carving, known in Somali as ''qoris'', was practiced in the coastal cities of the state. Many wealthy urbanites in the medieval period regularly employed the finest wood and marble carvers in Somalia to work on their interiors and houses. The carvings on the [[mihrab]]s and [[Column
column5: pillar]]s of ancient Somali [[mosque]]s are some of the oldest on the continent, with [[Fakr ad-Din Mosque
column6: Masjid Fakhr al-Din]] being the 7th oldest mosque in Africa.<ref>{{cite web
column12: archivedate=7 June 2007 }} ArchNet – Masjid Fakhr al-Din</ref> Artistic carving was considered the province of men similar to how the Somali textile industry was mainly a women's business. Amongst the [[nomad]]s, carving, especially [[woodwork]], was widespread and could be found on the most basic objects such as spoons, combs and bowls, but it also included more complex structures such as the portable nomadic tent, the ''aqal''.<ref>Culture and customs of Somalia By Mohamed Diriye Abdullahi pg 97</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": During its tenure, the sultanate left an extensive [[Somali architecture
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: architectural legacy]], being one of the major medieval Somali powers engaged in castle and [[fortress]] building. Many of the ruined fortifications dotting the landscapes of southern Somalia today are attributed to the Ajuran Sultanate's engineers.<ref name=\"Shs\"/> These structures include a number of pillar tomb fields, [[necropolis]]es, castles, fortresses and ruined cities built in that era.<ref name=\"His 40\"/> In the Marca area, various pillar tombs exist, which local tradition holds were built in the 16th century, when the Ajuran Sultanate's [[Somali aristocratic and court titles

column5: Many [[Arab]] and [[Persia]]n families would call the Ajuran realm their home.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The late 15th and 17th centuries saw the arrival of Muslim families from [[Arabia]], [[Persia]], [[India]] and [[Spain]] to the Ajuran Sultanate, the majority of whom settled in the coastal provinces. Some migrated because of the instability in their respective regions,{{sfnp
column4: p=18}} as was the case with the [[Hadhrami people
column5: Hadhrami]] families from the [[Yemen]] and the Muslims from Spain fleeing the [[Spanish Inquisition
column6: Inquisition]].<ref>The origins and development of Mogadishu pg. 34 by Ahmed Dueleh Jama</ref> Others came to conduct business or for religious purposes. Due to their strong tradition in religious learning, the new Muslim communities also enjoyed high status among the Somali ruling elite and commoners,{{sfnp
column9: p=18}} and were frequently employed as religious advisers or received administrative positions, or served in the Ajuran army as soldiers and commanders.

column5: Somali merchants from Mogadishu established a colony in [[Mozambique]] to extract gold from the mines in [[Sofala]].<ref name=\"ReferenceA\">pg 4 – The quest for an African Eldorado: Sofala, By Terry H. Elkiss</ref>]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": [[Sofala]] is located on the [[Sofala Bank]] in [[Sofala Province]] of [[Mozambique]]. It was founded by [[Somali people
column3: merchants and seafarers]]. Sofala in [[Somali language
column4: Somali]] literally means \"Go dig\". This name was given because the area is rich with resources.<ref name=\"Horizon History 143\">''The Horizon History of Africa'', vol. 1, p. 143.</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": One of the oldest harbours documented in [[Southern Africa]], medieval Sofala was erected on the edge of a wide estuary formed by the [[Buzi River (Mozambique)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Buzi River]] (called ''Rio de Sofala'' in older maps). By the [[Somali people
column3: Somali]] merchants from Mogadishu, the capital of the [[Ajuran Empire]], established a colony in [[Mozambique]] to extract gold from the mines in Sofala.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Buzi River connected Sofala to the internal market town of [[Manica, Mozambique
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Manica]], and from there to the gold fields of [[Great Zimbabwe]]. Sometime in the 10th century, Sofala emerged as a small trading post and was incorporated into the greater global Somali trade network. In the 1180s, Sultan Suleiman Hassan of [[Kilwa Kisiwani
column3: Kilwa]] (in present-day [[Tanzania]]) seized control of Sofala, and brought Sofala into the [[Kilwa Sultanate]] and the [[Swahili culture
column4: Swahili]] cultural sphere.the man behind the conquest: Mogadishu merchants had long kept Sofala a secret from their Kilwan rivals, who up until then rarely sailed beyond Cape Delgado. One day, a fisherman caught a large bite off Kilwa and was dragged by the fish around Cape Delgado, through the Mozambique Channe, all the way down to the Sofala banks. The fisherman made his way back up to Kilwa to report to the Sultan Suleiman Hassan what he had seen. Hearing of the gold trade, the sultan loaded up a ship with cloth and immediately raced down there, guided by the fisherman. The Kilwan sultan offered a better deal to the Mwenemutapa, and was allowed to erect a Kilwan factory and colony on the island and nudge the Mogadishans permanently out.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": <ref>Portuguese chronicler [[João de Barros]] (Dec. I, Lib. 10, Cap. 2 (p. 388 ff.) relates the fable behind the conquest: Mogadishu merchants had long kept Sofala a secret from their Kilwan rivals, who up until then rarely sailed beyond [[Cape Delgado]]. One day, a fisherman caught a large bite off Kilwa and was dragged by the fish around Cape Delgado, through the [[Mozambique Channel]], all the way down to the Sofala banks. The fisherman made his way back up to Kilwa to report to the Sultan Suleiman Hassan what he had seen. Hearing of the gold trade, the sultan loaded up a ship with cloth and immediately raced down there, guided by the fisherman. The Kilwan sultan offered a better deal to the Mwenemutapa, and was allowed to erect a Kilwan factory and colony on the island and nudge the Mogadishans permanently out.
</ref> The Swahili strengthened its trading capacity by having, among other things, rivergoing [[dhow]]s ply the Buzi and [[Save River (Africa)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Save]] rivers to ferry the gold extracted in the hinterlands to the coast.<ref>{{cite book
column7: publisher=reprinted in Theal, vol. 7, p. 3 ff}}</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The first king of the [[Republic of the Maldives
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Maldivian]] [[Hilaalee dynasty]] was proclaimed king in the year 1388 AD. [[Hilaalee dynasty]] was a [[Somali people
column3: Somali]] Dynasty. Some historical writing and some folklores reveal that this Dynasty is from [[Somali people
column4: Somali]] descent. It seems they were travellers and traders of [[Ajuran Empire]] where they established a colony in [[Maldive]] islands. They settled in Hlhule' in Male' atoll. Some historical documents reveal that Hilali Kalo Hassan dethroned King Uthman Rasgefaan, who reveal the ruling King at that time and outcast him and all his ministers. After his Hilai Kalo Hassan started the Hilai Dynasty. The [[Hilaalee dynasty]] was a sub-dynasty of [[Garen Dynasty]].<ref name=\"ReferenceB\">Dhivehi raajje: a portrait of Maldives By Adrian Neville pg 6</ref><ref name=\"Maldivian Links with Eastern Africa\">{{Cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": [[Abd al-Aziz of Mogadishu]] was a Somali governor of Maldives islands and a famous member of the [[Hilaalee dynasty]].
The presence and high position of Abd al-Aziz in this region highlights the close connections between [[History of the Maldives
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: medieval Maldives]] and the Somali seamen from [[Mogadishu]] sailing the [[Indian Ocean]]. They supplied Maldivian traders with exotic animals and [[musk]], and contributed to the [[ethnogenesis]] of the Maldivian population.<ref name=\"ReferenceB\"/><ref name=\"Maldivian Links with Eastern Africa\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In 1346, Abd al-Aziz welcomed [[Ibn Battuta]] at his court and entertained him before giving him a barque to continue his journey.<ref>The voyage of François Pyrard of Laval: to the East Volume 2, Part 2 By François Pyrard pg 467</ref>
The Ajuran State had a standing army with which the Garen imams and the governors ruled and protected their subjects. The bulk of the army consisted of [[mamluke]] soldiers,{{sfnp
column4: p=90}} who did not have any loyalties to the traditional Somali clan system, thereby making them more reliable. The soldiers were recruited from the inter-riverine area; other recruits came from the surrounding nomadic region. [[Arab]], [[Persian people
column6: Turkish]] mercenaries were at times employed as well.{{sfnp
column13: title=Portuguese rule and Spanish crown in South Africa, 1581–1640

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In the early Ajuran period, the army's weapons consisted of traditional Somali weapons such as [[sword]]s, [[dagger]]s, [[spear]]s, [[battle axe]], and [[bow (weapon)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: bows]]. The Sultanate received assistance from its close ally the [[Ottoman Empire]], and with the import of [[firearms]] through the Muzzaffar port of [[Mogadishu]], the army began acquiring [[muskets]] and [[cannons]]. The Ottomans would also remain a key ally during the [[Ajuran Sultanate#Ajuran-Portuguese wars
column3: Ajuran-Portuguese wars]]. Horses used for military purposes were also raised in the interior, and numerous stone fortifications were erected to provide shelter for the army in the coastal districts.{{sfnp
column6: p=92}} In each province, the soldiers were under the supervision of a military commander known as an [[emir]],{{sfnp
column9: p=90}} and the coastal areas and the [[Indian ocean]] trade were protected by a [[navy]].{{sfnp

column5: The Ottomans regularly aided the Ajurans in their struggles with the Portuguese in the [[Indian Ocean]].]]
During the Battle of [[Barawa]], ''[[Tristão da Cunha]]'' was wounded and requested to be [[knight]]ed by [[Afonso de Albuquerque
column6: Albuquerque]].<ref>Maritime Discovery: A History of Nautical Exploration from the Earliest Times pg 198</ref>]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The [[Europe]]an [[Age of discovery]] brought Europe's then [[superpower]] the [[Portuguese empire]] to the coast of East Africa, which at the time enjoyed a flourishing trade with foreign nations. The wealthy southeastern city-states of [[Kilwa Kisiwani
column3: Pate]] and [[Lamu]] were all systematically sacked and plundered by the Portuguese. [[Tristão da Cunha]] then set his eyes on Ajuran territory, where the battle of [[Barawa]] was fought. After a long period of engagement, the Portuguese soldiers burned the city and looted it. However, fierce resistance by the local population and soldiers resulted in the failure of the Portuguese to permanently occupy the city, and the inhabitants who had fled to the interior would eventually return and rebuild the city. After Barawa, Tristão would set sail for [[Mogadishu]], which was the richest city on the East African coast. But word had spread of what had happened in Barawa, and a large troop mobilization had taken place. Many horsemen, soldiers and battleships in defense positions were now guarding the city. Nevertheless, Tristão still opted to storm and attempt to conquer the city, although every officer and soldier in his army opposed this, fearing certain defeat if they were to engage their opponents in battle. Tristão heeded their advice and sailed for [[Socotra]] instead.<ref>The History of the Portuguese, During the Reign of Emmanuel pg.287</ref> After the battle the city of Barawa quickly recovered from the attack.<ref>The book of Duarte Barbosa – Page 30</ref>

column6: Portuguese]] in [[Mombasa]] surrendered to a joint [[Somali people
column7: Somali]]-[[Oman]]i force.<ref>Tanzania notes and records: the journal of the Tanzania Society pg 76</ref>]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Over the next several decades Somali-[[Portugal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Portuguese]] tensions would remain high and the increased contact between Somali [[sailors]] and [[Ottoman Empire
column4: corsairs]] worried the Portuguese who sent a punitive expedition against Mogadishu under [[João de Sepúlveda]], which was unsuccessful.<ref>The Portuguese period in East Africa – p. 112</ref> Ottoman-Somali cooperation against the Portuguese in the [[Indian Ocean]] reached a high point in the 1580s when Ajuran clients of the Somali coastal cities began to sympathize with the [[Arabs]] and [[Swahili people
column5: Swahilis]] under Portuguese rule and sent an envoy to the Turkish corsair [[Mir Ali Bey]] for a joint expedition against the Portuguese. He agreed and was joined by a Somali [[Naval fleet
column6: fleet]], which began attacking Portuguese colonies in [[Swahili Coast

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Somali-Ottoman offensive managed to drive out the Portuguese from several important cities such as [[Pate Island
column3: Kilwa]]. However, the Portuguese governor sent envoys to [[Portuguese India]] requesting a large Portuguese fleet. This request was answered and it reversed the previous offensive of the Muslims into one of defense. The Portuguese armada managed to re-take most of the lost cities and began punishing their leaders, but they refrained from attacking Mogadishu, securing the city's autonomy in the Indian Ocean.<ref name=\"Cites\"/><ref>Four centuries of Swahili verse: a literary history and anthology – p. 11</ref> Ajuran's Somali forces would eventually militarily defeat the Portuguese. The Ottoman Empire would also remain an economic partner of the Somalis.<ref name=\"Shapes\"/> Throughout the 16th and 17th centuries successive Somali Sultans defied the Portuguese economic monopoly in the [[Indian Ocean]] by employing a new coinage which followed the Ottoman pattern, thus proclaiming an attitude of economic independence in regard to the Portuguese.<ref>COINS FROM MOGADISHU, c. 1300 to c. 1700 by G. S. P. Freeman-Grenville pg 36</ref>

column6: Somali maritime enterprise]] took a significant hit after the collapse of the Ajuran Sultanate. However, other [[Somali people
column7: Somali]] polities such as the Warsangali Sultanate, the [[Geledi Sultanate]], the [[Majeerteen Sultanate]], the [[Dervish state]] and the [[Sultanate of Hobyo]] ensured its continuity.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In the mid-17th century, the [[Oromo people
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Oromo]] Nation began expanding from its homeland around [[Lake Abaya]] in southern [[Ethiopia]] towards the southern Somali coast at the time when the Ajuran was at the height of its power.{{sfnp
column5: p=114}}<ref>Cerulli, Somalia 1: 65–67</ref> The Garen rulers conducted several military expeditions known as the ''Gaal Madow'' wars against the Oromo warriors, converting those that were captured to [[Islam]]. The Ajuran military supremacy forced the Oromo conquerors to reverse their migrations towards the [[Christianity
column8: Adalites]], devastating the two warring empires in the process.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Ajuran Sultanate slowly declined in power at the end of the 17th century, which paved the way for the ascendance of new Somali powers. The most prominent setbacks against the state were the dethronement of the [[Sultanate of Mogadishu
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Muzzaffar]] clients in [[Mogadishu]] and other coastal cities by the [[Hawiye]] Hiraab [[King]],{{sfnp
column5: page=37}} and the defeat of the [[Silcis
column6: Silis Kingdom]] by a former Ajuran general, [[Ibrahim Adeer]], in the interior of the state who then established the [[Gobroon dynasty]]. Taxation and the practice of primae noctis were the main catalysts for the revolts against Ajuran rulers. The loss of port cities and fertile farms meant that much needed sources of revenue were lost to the rebels.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": [[Category:States and territories established in the 13th century]]
[[Category:States and territories disestablished in the 17th century]]
[[Category:Former sultanates in the medieval Horn of Africa]]
[[Category:Early Modern history of Somalia]]","{{Use dmy dates

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: flag_p1                = French map of Somalia in early 18th century.png
image_flag                = Muzzaffar (Mogadishu area) flag according to 1576 Portuguese map.svg
image_map_caption                = The Ajuuraan Empire in the 15th century

column3: دولة الأجورانيون}}), also spelled '''Ajuuraan Empire''',<ref name=\"His 40\">{{cite book
column12: page=40}}</ref> and often simply as '''Ajuran''',<ref>{{Cite web
column16: Somali]] [[empire]] in the medieval times that dominated the Indian ocean trade. They belonged to the [[Somali people
column21: title=Somali Sultanate: the Geledi city-state over 150 years
column26: page=17}}</ref><ref>Luc Cambrézy, Populations réfugiées: de l'exil au retour, p.316</ref><ref>{{cite journal
column29: title=The Emergence and Role of Political Parties in the Inter-River Region of Somalia from 1947–1960
column35: year=1989 }}</ref> that ruled over large parts of the [[Horn of Africa]] in the [[Medieval
column36: Middle Ages]]. Through a strong centralized administration and an aggressive military stance towards invaders, the Ajuran Empire successfully resisted an [[Oromo people
column38: invasion]] from the west and a [[Portuguese Empire
column39: Portuguese]] incursion from the east during the Gaal Madow and the [[Ajuran Sultanate#Ajuran-Portuguese wars
column40: Ajuran-Portuguese wars]]. Trading routes dating from the ancient and early medieval periods of [[Maritime history of Somalia
column41: Somali maritime enterprise]] were strengthened or re-established, and foreign trade and commerce in the coastal provinces flourished with ships sailing to and coming from many kingdoms and empires in [[East Asia]], [[South Asia]], [[Europe]], the [[Near East]], [[North Africa]] and [[East Africa]].<ref name=\"Shapes\">{{cite book
column44: title=Nation Shapes: The Story behind the World's Borders

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The empire left an extensive [[Somali architecture
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: architectural legacy]], being one of the major medieval Somali powers engaged in castle and [[fortress]] building. Many of the ruined fortifications dotting the landscapes of southern Somalia today are attributed to the Ajuran Empire's engineers,<ref name=\"Shs\">{{cite book
column6: title=The Shaping of Somali Society: Reconstructing the History of a Pastoral People, 1600–1900
column11: url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mlhyAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA101}}</ref> including a number of the [[pillar tomb]] fields, [[necropolis]]es and [[ruin
column12: ruined cities]] built in that era. During the Ajuran period, many regions and people in the southern part of the [[Horn of Africa]] converted to [[Islam]] because of the [[theocratic]] nature of the government.<ref name=\"Cultural\">{{cite encyclopedia
column16: title=Cultural Sociology of the Middle East, Asia, and Africa: An Encyclopedia
column20: isbn=978-1-4129-8176-7}}</ref> The [[royal family]], the House of Garen, expanded its territories and established its hegemonic rule through a skillful combination of [[warfare]], [[trade

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": As an [[hydraulic empire]], the Ajuran monopolized the [[water resources]] of the [[Shebelle River
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Shebelle]] and [[Jubba river]]s. Through [[hydraulic engineering]], it also constructed many of the [[limestone]] [[Water well
column3: wells]] and [[cistern]]s of the state that are still operative and in use today. The rulers developed new systems for agriculture and taxation, which continued to be used in parts of the [[Horn of Africa]] as late as the 19th century.<ref name=\"His 40\"/> The rule of the later Ajuran rulers caused multiple rebellions to break out in the empire, and at the end of the 17th century, the [[Ajuran Sultanate#Decline and successor states
column4: Ajuran state disintegrated]] into several successor kingdoms and states, the most prominent being the [[Geledi Sultanate]].{{sfnp

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Ajuran Empire's sphere of influence in the [[Horn of Africa]] was one of the largest in the region. The empire covered much of southern [[Somalia]],<ref name=\"Shapes\"/><ref name=\"Michigan\">{{cite book
column6: publisher=African Studies Center, Michigan State University
column7: page=115}}</ref> with its domain extending from [[Mareeg]] in the north, to [[Kelafo
column8: Qelafo]] in the west, to [[Kismayo]] in the south.{{sfnp

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The House of Garen was the ruling hereditary [[dynasty]] of the Ajuran Empire.<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=A Modern History of Somalia: Nation and State in the Horn of Africa
column14: title=Horn and Crescent: Cultural Change and Traditional Islam on the East African Coast, 800–1900
column21: isbn=9780521523097 }}</ref> Its origin lies in the Garen Kingdom that during the 13th century ruled parts of the [[Ogaden]], the [[Somali region]] of [[Ethiopia]]. With the migration of Somalis from the northern half of the Horn region to the southern half, new cultural and religious orders were introduced that influenced the administrative structure of the [[dynasty]], a system of governance which began to evolve into an [[Sharia
column23: Baraka]], which came from the saint Balad (who was known to have come from outside the Garen Kingdom),<ref name=\"Dic 35\">{{cite book
column32: page=35}}</ref> the Garen rulers claimed supremacy and religious legitimacy over other groups in the Horn of Africa. Balad's ancestors are said to have come from the historical northern region of [[Barbara (region)

column5: The city of [[Merca]] was one of several prominent [[administrative center]]s of the Ajurans.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Ajuran nobility used many of the typical [[Somali aristocratic and court titles]], with the Garen rulers styled [[Somali aristocratic and court titles#Rulers
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Imam]]. These leaders were the empire's highest authority, and counted multiple [[Sultan]]s, [[Emir]]s, and [[Monarch
column3: Kings]] as clients or [[vassal]]s. The Garen rulers also had seasonal palaces in [[Mareeg]], [[Kelafo
column4: Qelafo]] and [[Merca]], which they would periodically visit to practice ''[[primae noctis]]''.<ref name=\"Crescent\" /> Other important cities in the Empire were Mogadishu and [[Barawa]]. The state religion was [[Islam]], and thus law was based on [[Sharia]].

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Through their control of the region's wells, the Garen rulers effectively held a monopoly over their [[nomadic]] subjects as they were the only [[hydraulic empire]] in Africa during their reign. Large wells made out of [[limestone]] were constructed throughout the state, which attracted [[Somali people
column3: Oromo]] nomads with their livestock. The centralized regulations of the wells made it easier for the nomads to settle disputes by taking their queries to government officials who would act as mediators. Long distance caravan trade, a long-time practice in the Horn of Africa, continued unchanged in Ajuran times. Today, numerous ruined and abandoned towns throughout the interior of Somalia and the Horn of Africa are evidence of a once-booming inland trade network dating from the medieval period.{{sfnp

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": With the centralized supervision of the Ajuran, farms in [[Afgooye]], [[Kismayo]] and other areas in the [[Jubba Valley
column3: Shabelle]] valleys increased their productivity. A system of irrigation ditches known locally as ''Kelliyo'' fed directly from the [[Shebelle River
column4: Shebelle]] and [[Jubba river]]s into the plantations where [[sorghum]], [[maize]], beans, grain and cotton were grown during the ''gu'' ([[Spring (season)
column5: Spring]] in Somali) and ''xagaa'' ([[Summer]] in Somali) seasons of the [[Somali calendar]]. This irrigation system was supported by numerous [[Levee
column6: dikes]] and dams. To determine the average size of a farm, a land measurement system was also invented with ''moos'', ''taraab'' and ''guldeed'' being the terms used.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The State collected [[tribute]] from the farmers in the form of harvested products like [[durra]], sorghum and bun, and from the nomads, cattle, camels and goats. The collecting of tribute was done by a [[Vizier
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: wazir]]. Luxury goods imported from foreign lands were also presented as gifts to the Garen rulers by the coastal [[sultan]]s of the state.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": A political device that was implemented by the Garen rulers in their realm was a form of ''[[ius primae noctis]]'',{{Citation needed
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: date=October 2016}} which enabled them to create marriages that enforced their [[Hegemony
column3: hegemonic]] rule over all the important groups of the empire. The rulers would also claim a large portion of the bride's wealth, which at the time was 100 camels.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": For trade, the Ajuran Empire minted its own [[Ajuran currency]].<ref name=\"Stgi\"/> It also utilized the [[Mogadishu currency
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Mogadishan currency]] originally minted by the [[Sultanate of Mogadishu]], which later became incorporated into the Ajuran Empire.<ref name=\"Cites\">{{cite book
column10: title=Cities of the Middle East and North Africa: A Historical Encyclopedia
column15: page=253}}</ref> Mogadishan coins have been found as far away as the present-day country of the [[United Arab Emirates]] in the [[Middle East]].<ref name=\"Ncaaroth\">{{cite book
column18: title=An Archaeological Reconnaissance in the Horn: The British-Somali Expedition, 1975

column5: Medieval [[Kismayo]] was used by Ajuuran state to utilize the [[Jubba River]] for its plantations.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The urban centers of [[Merca]], [[Mogadishu]], [[Barawa]], and their respective ports became profitable trade outlets for commodities originating from the interior of the State. The farming communities of the hinterland brought their products to the coastal cities, where they were sold to local merchants who maintained a lucrative foreign commerce with ships sailing to and coming from [[Arabia]], [[India]], [[Venetian Republic
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Venice]],<ref>Journal of African History pg.50 by John Donnelly Fage and Roland Anthony Oliver{{Full citation needed
column3: date=October 2016}}</ref> [[Persia]], [[Egypt]], [[Portugal]], and as far away as [[China]]. [[Vasco Da Gama]], who passed by Mogadishu in the 15th century, noted that it was a large city with houses of four or five storeys high and big palaces in its centre and many mosques with cylindrical minarets.<ref>Da Gama's First Voyage pg.88{{Full citation needed
column4: date=October 2016}}</ref> In the 16th century, [[Duarte Barbosa]] noted that many ships from the Kingdom of [[History of Gujarat#Muslim Period
column5: Cambaya]] sailed to Mogadishu with cloths and spices for which they in return received [[gold]], [[wax]] and [[ivory]]. Barbosa also highlighted the abundance of meat, wheat, barley, horses, and fruit on the coastal markets, which generated enormous wealth for the merchants.<ref>East Africa and its Invaders pg.38{{Full citation needed
column6: date=October 2016}}</ref> Mogadishu, the center of a thriving weaving industry known as ''toob benadir'' (specialized for the markets in Egypt and [[Syria]]),<ref>{{cite journal
column8: title=Gujarat and the Trade of East Africa, c. 1500–1800
column11: journal=The International Journal of African Historical Studies
column17: jstor=217389}}</ref> together with Merca and Barawa also served as transit stops for [[Swahili people
column18: Swahili]] merchants from [[Mombasa]] and [[Malindi]] and for the gold trade from [[Kilwa Kisiwani
column22: title=The Return of Cosmopolitan Capital: Globalization, the State and War
column28: Hormuz]] also brought their Indian textile and fruit to the Somali coast in exchange for [[grain]] and wood.<ref>{{cite book
column31: title=The Arabian Seas: The Indian Ocean World of the Seventeenth Century: The Indian Ocean World of the Seventeenth Century

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Trading relations were established with [[Malacca]] in the 15th century,{{sfnp
column4: page=30}} with cloth, [[ambergris]] and [[porcelain]] being the main commodities of the trade.<ref>Chinese Porcelain Marks from Coastal Sites in Kenya: aspects of trade in the Indian Ocean, XIV-XIX centuries. Oxford: British Archaeological Reports, 1978 pg 2</ref> In addition, giraffes, zebras and incense were exported to the [[Ming Dynasty
column5: Ming Empire]] of China, making Somali merchants leaders in the commerce between Asia and Africa.<ref>East Africa and its Invaders pg.37</ref> and influencing the [[Mandarin Chinese
column6: Chinese language]] on Somali in the process. [[Hindu]] merchants from [[Surat]] and Southeast African merchants from [[Pate Island
column7: Pate]] seeking to bypass both the Portuguese blockade and [[Omani]] interference used the Somali ports of Merca and Barawa (which were out of the two powers' jurisdiction) to conduct their trade in safety and without interference.<ref>Gujarat and the Trade of East Africa pg.45</ref>

column6: Sequin coins]] from the [[Venetian Empire]] in Europe.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Ajuran Empire relied on agriculture and trade for most of its income. Major agricultural towns were located on the [[Shebelle River
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Shebelle]] and [[Jubba river]]s, including [[Kismayo]] and [[Afgooye]]. Situated at the junction of some of the busiest medieval trade routes, the Ajuran and its clients were active participants in the East African [[Gold
column5: trade in the Indian Ocean]], and commercial enterprise as far as [[East Asia]].

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Ajuran Empire also minted its own [[Ajuran currency]]. Many ancient [[bronze]] coins inscribed with the names of Ajuran Sultans have been found in the coastal Benadir province, in addition to pieces from Muslim rulers of [[Southern Arabia]] and [[Persia]].<ref name=\"Stgi\">{{cite book
column6: publisher=Ministry of Information and National Guidance, Somali Democratic Republic
column10: Mogadishan coins]] have been found as far as the [[United Arab Emirates]] in the [[Middle East]]. Trading routes dating from the ancient and early medieval periods of [[Maritime history of Somalia
column11: Somali maritime enterprise]] were strengthened or re-established, and foreign trade and commerce in the coastal provinces flourished with ships sailing to and coming from a myriad of kingdoms and empires in [[East Asia]], [[South Asia]], [[Europe]], the [[Near East]], [[North Africa]] and the [[Horn of Africa]].<ref name=\"Shapes\"/> Through the use of commercial vessels, compasses, multiple port cities, light houses and other technology, the merchants of the Ajuran Empire did brisk business with traders from the following states:

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": ! Trading countries in Asia !! Imports !! Exports

column4: The [[Ajuran Empire]] maintained commercial ties with the [[Ming dynasty]] and other kingdoms.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": With their maritime pursuits and history, the Empire established trading and diplomatic ties across the old world, especially in Asia – from being a close ally to the grand power of the [[Ottomans]] to having cordial ties to the mighty [[Ming Dynasty]], even having their merchants following of the greatest maritime expedition in their history as far as [[Java]] and [[Vietnam]].<ref name=\"Shelley2013\">{{cite book
column3: title=Nation Shapes: The Story Behind the World's Borders

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Somali]] Ajuran Empire sent ambassadors to [[China]] to establish diplomatic ties, creating the first ever recorded African community in China and the most notable [[Somali people
column3: Somali]] ambassador in medieval China was [[Sa'id of Mogadishu]] who was the first African man to set foot in [[China]]. In return, Emperor Yongle, the third emperor of the [[Ming Dynasty]] (1368–1644), dispatched one of the largest fleets in history to trade with the Somali nation. The fleet, under the leadership of the famed Hui Muslim [[Zheng He]], arrived at [[Mogadishu]] the capital of Ajuran Empire while the city was at its zenith. Along with [[gold]], [[frankincense]] and [[fabric]]s, Zheng brought back the first ever African wildlife to China, which included [[hippo]]s, [[giraffe]]s and [[gazelle]]s.<ref>Wilson, Samuel M. \"The Emperor's Giraffe\", ''Natural History'' Vol. 101, No. 12, December 1992 {{cite web
column14: title=Chinese archaeologists' African quest for sunken ship of Ming admiral
column18: title=Could a rusty coin re-write Chinese-African history?
column21: title=Zheng He'S Voyages to the Western Oceans 郑和下西洋

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Ajuran State was an influential Somali kingdom that held sway over several cities and towns in central and southern Somalia during the Middle Ages. With the [[Ajuran Sultanate#Decline and successor states
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: fall of the Sultanate]], a number of these settlements continued to prosper, eventually becoming [[List of Somali cities by population
column3: major cities]] in present-day Somalia. A few of these cities and towns were also abandoned or destroyed:

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": *[[Merca]] (port city in the [[Lower Shebelle]] region of Somalia)
*[[Mogadishu]] (harbor city and current capital of Somalia)
*[[Hobyo]] (harbor city in the [[Mudug]] region of Somalia
*[[Kismayo]] (port city in the [[Lower Juba]] region of Somalia)
*[[Barawa]] (port town in the [[Lower Shebelle]] region of Somalia)
*[[Warsheikh]] (port town in the [[Middle Shebelle]] region of Somalia)
*[[Afgooye]] (town in the [[Lower Shebelle]] region of Somalia)
*[[Gondershe]] (Abandoned, but now a popular tourist attraction site)
The Ajurans facilitated a rich culture with various forms of [[Culture of Somalia
column4: art]] evolving and flourishing during this period. The majority of the inhabitants were ethnic [[Somali people
column5: Somali]], but there was also a [[Yemen]]i, [[Persian people
column7: Turkish]] minority. The vast majority of the population also adhered to [[Sunni]] [[Islam]] with a [[Shia]] minority (mostly those of Persian descent). Somali was the most commonly used language of government and social life while [[Arabic language
column8: Arabic]] was most prominently used for [[Madrasa

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The most famous Somali scholar of Islam from the Ajuraan period is [[Sheikh Hussein (saint)]] of [[Merca]] , sheikh Hussein was born in [[Merca]] one of the power jurisdiction and cultural centers of Ajuran Empire.<ref>{{Cite journal
column12: title=Some Records of Ethiopia, 1593–1646: Being Extracts from 'The History of High Ethiopia or Abassia' by Manoel de Almeida, Together with Bahrey's 'History of the Galla'
column19: jstor=1791718}}</ref> And is credited for converting the [[Sidama people
column20: Sidamo]] people living in the area of what is now the [[Bale Province, Ethiopia]] to [[Islam]] . He is also credited for establishing a dynasty that ruled the [[Sultanate of Bale]].<ref>{{Cite journal
column24: title=Contemporary Ethiopia. By David A. Talbot. New York: Philosophical Library. 1952. xxi+267 pages. – Islam in Ethiopia. By J. Spencer Trimingham. London: Geoffrey Cumberlege, Oxford University Press, 1952. iv+299 pages.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": He's tomb lies in the town of [[Sheikh Hussein]] in what is the most sacred place in the country for Ethiopian Muslims mostly [[Oromo people
column4: title=Islamic History and Culture in Southern Ethiopia: Collected Essays

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Somali [[martial art]] [[Istunka]], also known as Dabshid, was born during their reign. An annual tournament is held every year for it in [[Afgooye]].{{sfnp
column4: page=28}} Carving, known in Somali as ''qoris'', was practiced in the coastal cities of the state. Many wealthy urbanites in the medieval period regularly employed the finest wood and marble carvers in Somalia to work on their interiors and houses. The carvings on the [[mihrab]]s and [[Column
column5: pillar]]s of ancient Somali [[mosque]]s are some of the oldest on the continent, with [[Fakr ad-Din Mosque
column6: Masjid Fakhr al-Din]] being the 7th oldest mosque in Africa.<ref>{{cite web
column12: archivedate=7 June 2007 }} ArchNet – Masjid Fakhr al-Din</ref> Artistic carving was considered the province of men similar to how the Somali textile industry was mainly a women's business. Amongst the [[nomad]]s, carving, especially [[woodwork]], was widespread and could be found on the most basic objects such as spoons, combs and bowls, but it also included more complex structures such as the portable nomadic tent, the ''aqal''.<ref>Culture and customs of Somalia By Mohamed Diriye Abdullahi pg 97</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": During its tenure, the Empire left an extensive [[Somali architecture
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: architectural legacy]], being one of the major medieval Somali powers engaged in castle and [[fortress]] building. Many of the ruined fortifications dotting the landscapes of southern Somalia today are attributed to the Ajuran Empire's engineers.<ref name=\"Shs\"/> These structures include a number of pillar tomb fields, [[necropolis]]es, castles, fortresses and ruined cities built in that era.<ref name=\"His 40\"/> In the Marca area, various pillar tombs exist, which local tradition holds were built in the 16th century, when the Ajuran Empire's [[Somali aristocratic and court titles

column5: Many [[Arab]] and [[Persia]]n families would call the Ajuran realm their home.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The late 15th and 17th centuries saw the arrival of Muslim families from [[Arabia]], [[Persia]], [[India]] and [[Spain]] to the Ajuran Empire's, the majority of whom settled in the coastal provinces. Some migrated because of the instability in their respective regions,{{sfnp
column4: p=18}} as was the case with the [[Hadhrami people
column5: Hadhrami]] families from the [[Yemen]] and the Muslims from Spain fleeing the [[Spanish Inquisition
column6: Inquisition]].<ref>The origins and development of Mogadishu pg. 34 by Ahmed Dueleh Jama</ref> Others came to conduct business or for religious purposes. Due to their strong tradition in religious learning, the new Muslim communities also enjoyed high status among the Somali ruling elite and commoners,{{sfnp
column9: p=18}} and were frequently employed as religious advisers or received administrative positions, or served in the Ajuran army as soldiers and commanders.

column5: Somali merchants from Mogadishu established a colony in [[Mozambique]] to extract gold from the mines in [[Sofala]].<ref name=\"ReferenceA\">pg 4 – The quest for an African Eldorado: Sofala, By Terry H. Elkiss</ref>]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": [[Sofala]] is located on the [[Sofala Bank]] in [[Sofala Province]] of [[Mozambique]]. It was founded by [[Somali people
column3: merchants and seafarers]]. Sofala in [[Somali language
column4: Somali]] literally means \"Go dig\". This name was given because the area is rich with resources.<ref name=\"Horizon History 143\">''The Horizon History of Africa'', vol. 1, p. 143.</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": One of the oldest harbours documented in [[Southern Africa]], medieval Sofala was erected on the edge of a wide estuary formed by the [[Buzi River (Mozambique)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Buzi River]] (called ''Rio de Sofala'' in older maps). By the [[Somali people
column3: Somali]] merchants from Mogadishu, the capital of the [[Ajuran Empire]], established a colony in [[Mozambique]] to extract gold from the mines in Sofala.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Buzi River connected Sofala to the internal market town of [[Manica, Mozambique
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Manica]], and from there to the gold fields of [[Great Zimbabwe]]. Sometime in the 10th century, Sofala emerged as a small trading post and was incorporated into the greater global Somali trade network. In the 1180s, Sultan Suleiman Hassan of [[Kilwa Kisiwani
column3: Kilwa]] (in present-day [[Tanzania]]) seized control of Sofala, and brought Sofala into the [[Kilwa Sultanate]] and the [[Swahili culture
column4: Swahili]] cultural sphere.the man behind the conquest: Mogadishu merchants had long kept Sofala a secret from their Kilwan rivals, who up until then rarely sailed beyond Cape Delgado. One day, a fisherman caught a large bite off Kilwa and was dragged by the fish around Cape Delgado, through the Mozambique Channe, all the way down to the Sofala banks. The fisherman made his way back up to Kilwa to report to the Sultan Suleiman Hassan what he had seen. Hearing of the gold trade, the sultan loaded up a ship with cloth and immediately raced down there, guided by the fisherman. The Kilwan sultan offered a better deal to the Mwenemutapa, and was allowed to erect a Kilwan factory and colony on the island and nudge the Mogadishans permanently out.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": <ref>Portuguese chronicler [[João de Barros]] (Dec. I, Lib. 10, Cap. 2 (p. 388 ff.) relates the fable behind the conquest: Mogadishu merchants had long kept Sofala a secret from their Kilwan rivals, who up until then rarely sailed beyond [[Cape Delgado]]. One day, a fisherman caught a large bite off Kilwa and was dragged by the fish around Cape Delgado, through the [[Mozambique Channel]], all the way down to the Sofala banks. The fisherman made his way back up to Kilwa to report to the Sultan Suleiman Hassan what he had seen. Hearing of the gold trade, the sultan loaded up a ship with cloth and immediately raced down there, guided by the fisherman. The Kilwan sultan offered a better deal to the Mwenemutapa, and was allowed to erect a Kilwan factory and colony on the island and nudge the Mogadishans permanently out.
</ref> The Swahili strengthened its trading capacity by having, among other things, rivergoing [[dhow]]s ply the Buzi and [[Save River (Africa)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Save]] rivers to ferry the gold extracted in the hinterlands to the coast.<ref>{{cite book
column7: publisher=reprinted in Theal, vol. 7, p. 3 ff}}</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The first king of the [[Republic of the Maldives
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Maldivian]] [[Hilaalee dynasty]] was proclaimed king in the year 1388 AD. [[Hilaalee dynasty]] was a [[Somali people
column3: Somali]] Dynasty. Some historical writing and some folklores reveal that this Dynasty is from [[Somali people
column4: Somali]] descent. It seems they were travellers and traders of [[Ajuran Empire]] where they established a colony in [[Maldive]] islands. They settled in Hlhule' in Male' atoll. Some historical documents reveal that Hilali Kalo Hassan dethroned King Uthman Rasgefaan, who reveal the ruling King at that time and outcast him and all his ministers. After his Hilai Kalo Hassan started the Hilai Dynasty. The [[Hilaalee dynasty]] was a sub-dynasty of [[Garen Dynasty]].<ref name=\"ReferenceB\">Dhivehi raajje: a portrait of Maldives By Adrian Neville pg 6</ref><ref name=\"Maldivian Links with Eastern Africa\">{{Cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": [[Abd al-Aziz of Mogadishu]] was a Somali governor of Maldives islands and a famous member of the [[Hilaalee dynasty]].
The presence and high position of Abd al-Aziz in this region highlights the close connections between [[History of the Maldives
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: medieval Maldives]] and the Somali seamen from [[Mogadishu]] sailing the [[Indian Ocean]]. They supplied Maldivian traders with exotic animals and [[musk]], and contributed to the [[ethnogenesis]] of the Maldivian population.<ref name=\"ReferenceB\"/><ref name=\"Maldivian Links with Eastern Africa\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In 1346, Abd al-Aziz welcomed [[Ibn Battuta]] at his court and entertained him before giving him a barque to continue his journey.<ref>The voyage of François Pyrard of Laval: to the East Volume 2, Part 2 By François Pyrard pg 467</ref>
The Ajuran State had a standing army with which the Garen imams and the governors ruled and protected their subjects. The bulk of the army consisted of [[mamluke]] soldiers,{{sfnp
column4: p=90}} who did not have any loyalties to the traditional Somali clan system, thereby making them more reliable. The soldiers were recruited from the inter-riverine area; other recruits came from the surrounding nomadic region. [[Arab]], [[Persian people
column6: Turkish]] mercenaries were at times employed as well.{{sfnp
column13: title=Portuguese rule and Spanish crown in South Africa, 1581–1640

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In the early Ajuran period, the army's weapons consisted of traditional Somali weapons such as [[sword]]s, [[dagger]]s, [[spear]]s, [[battle axe]], and [[bow (weapon)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: bows]]. The Empire received assistance from its close ally the [[Ottoman Empire]], and with the import of [[firearms]] through the Muzzaffar port of [[Mogadishu]], the army began acquiring [[muskets]] and [[cannons]]. The Ottomans would also remain a key ally during the [[Ajuran Sultanate#Ajuran-Portuguese wars
column3: Ajuran-Portuguese wars]]. Horses used for military purposes were also raised in the interior, and numerous stone fortifications were erected to provide shelter for the army in the coastal districts.{{sfnp
column6: p=92}} In each province, the soldiers were under the supervision of a military commander known as an [[emir]],{{sfnp
column9: p=90}} and the coastal areas and the [[Indian ocean]] trade were protected by a [[navy]].{{sfnp

column5: The Ottomans regularly aided the Ajurans in their struggles with the Portuguese in the [[Indian Ocean]].]]
During the Battle of [[Barawa]], ''[[Tristão da Cunha]]'' was wounded and requested to be [[knight]]ed by [[Afonso de Albuquerque
column6: Albuquerque]].<ref>Maritime Discovery: A History of Nautical Exploration from the Earliest Times pg 198</ref>]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The [[Europe]]an [[Age of discovery]] brought Europe's then [[superpower]] the [[Portuguese empire]] to the coast of East Africa, which at the time enjoyed a flourishing trade with foreign nations. The wealthy southeastern city-states of [[Kilwa Kisiwani
column3: Pate]] and [[Lamu]] were all systematically sacked and plundered by the Portuguese. [[Tristão da Cunha]] then set his eyes on Ajuran territory, where the battle of [[Barawa]] was fought. After a long period of engagement, the Portuguese soldiers burned the city and looted it. However, fierce resistance by the local population and soldiers resulted in the failure of the Portuguese to permanently occupy the city, and the inhabitants who had fled to the interior would eventually return and rebuild the city. After Barawa, Tristão would set sail for [[Mogadishu]], which was the richest city on the East African coast. But word had spread of what had happened in Barawa, and a large troop mobilization had taken place. Many horsemen, soldiers and battleships in defense positions were now guarding the city. Nevertheless, Tristão still opted to storm and attempt to conquer the city, although every officer and soldier in his army opposed this, fearing certain defeat if they were to engage their opponents in battle. Tristão heeded their advice and sailed for [[Socotra]] instead.<ref>The History of the Portuguese, During the Reign of Emmanuel pg.287</ref> After the battle the city of Barawa quickly recovered from the attack.<ref>The book of Duarte Barbosa – Page 30</ref>

column6: Portuguese]] in [[Mombasa]] surrendered to a joint [[Somali people
column7: Somali]]-[[Oman]]i force.<ref>Tanzania notes and records: the journal of the Tanzania Society pg 76</ref>]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Over the next several decades Somali-[[Portugal
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Portuguese]] tensions would remain high and the increased contact between Somali [[sailors]] and [[Ottoman Empire
column4: corsairs]] worried the Portuguese who sent a punitive expedition against Mogadishu under [[João de Sepúlveda]], which was unsuccessful.<ref>The Portuguese period in East Africa – p. 112</ref> Ottoman-Somali cooperation against the Portuguese in the [[Indian Ocean]] reached a high point in the 1580s when Ajuran clients of the Somali coastal cities began to sympathize with the [[Arabs]] and [[Swahili people
column5: Swahilis]] under Portuguese rule and sent an envoy to the Turkish corsair [[Mir Ali Bey]] for a joint expedition against the Portuguese. He agreed and was joined by a Somali [[Naval fleet
column6: fleet]], which began attacking Portuguese colonies in [[Swahili Coast

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Somali-Ottoman offensive managed to drive out the Portuguese from several important cities such as [[Pate Island
column3: Kilwa]]. However, the Portuguese governor sent envoys to [[Portuguese India]] requesting a large Portuguese fleet. This request was answered and it reversed the previous offensive of the Muslims into one of defense. The Portuguese armada managed to re-take most of the lost cities and began punishing their leaders, but they refrained from attacking Mogadishu, securing the city's autonomy in the Indian Ocean.<ref name=\"Cites\"/><ref>Four centuries of Swahili verse: a literary history and anthology – p. 11</ref> Ajuran's Somali forces would eventually militarily defeat the Portuguese. The Ottoman Empire would also remain an economic partner of the Somalis.<ref name=\"Shapes\"/> Throughout the 16th and 17th centuries successive Somali Sultans defied the Portuguese economic monopoly in the [[Indian Ocean]] by employing a new coinage which followed the Ottoman pattern, thus proclaiming an attitude of economic independence in regard to the Portuguese.<ref>COINS FROM MOGADISHU, c. 1300 to c. 1700 by G. S. P. Freeman-Grenville pg 36</ref>

column6: Somali maritime enterprise]] took a significant hit after the collapse of the Ajuran Empire. However, other [[Somali people
column7: Somali]] polities such as the Warsangali Sultanate, the [[Geledi Sultanate]], the [[Majeerteen Sultanate]], the [[Dervish state]] and the [[Sultanate of Hobyo]] ensured its continuity.]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In the mid-17th century, the [[Oromo people
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Oromo]] Nation began expanding from its homeland around [[Lake Abaya]] in southern [[Ethiopia]] towards the southern Somali coast at the time when the Ajuran was at the height of its power.{{sfnp
column5: p=114}}<ref>Cerulli, Somalia 1: 65–67</ref> The Garen rulers conducted several military expeditions known as the ''Gaal Madow'' wars against the Oromo warriors, converting those that were captured to [[Islam]]. The Ajuran military supremacy forced the Oromo conquerors to reverse their migrations towards the [[Christianity
column8: Adalites]], devastating the two warring empires in the process.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Ajuran Empire slowly declined in power at the end of the 17th century, which paved the way for the ascendance of new Somali powers. The most prominent setbacks against the state were the dethronement of the [[Sultanate of Mogadishu
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Muzzaffar]] clients in [[Mogadishu]] and other coastal cities by the [[Hawiye]] Hiraab [[King]],{{sfnp
column5: page=37}} and the defeat of the [[Silcis
column6: Silis Kingdom]] by a former Ajuran general, [[Ibrahim Adeer]], in the interior of the state who then established the [[Gobroon dynasty]]. Taxation and the practice of primae noctis were the main catalysts for the revolts against Ajuran rulers. The loss of port cities and fertile farms meant that much needed sources of revenue were lost to the rebels.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": [[Category:States and territories established in the 13th century]]
[[Category:States and territories disestablished in the 17th century]]
