revenue          = (All divisions) £26 million (UK Companies House 2015 Financials)

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The '''Morgan Motor Company''' is a British [[automobile
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: motor car]] manufacturer, owned by the Italian Investindustrial since March of 2019. It was founded in 1910 by [[H.F.S. Morgan

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Morgan is based in [[Malvern Link]], an area of Malvern, Worcestershire, and employs approximately 220 people. Morgan has stated that they produce 850 cars per year, all assembled by hand.<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=5 March 2019}}</ref> The waiting list for a car is approximately six months, and has sometimes been as long as ten years.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Morgan cars are unusual because wood has been used in their construction for a century, and is still used in the 21st century for framing the body shell.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Let the Wood (and Aluminum) Times Roll: A Tour of Morgan Motor Company’s Factory
column5: accessdate=4 January 2018}}</ref> A visitor centre and museum have exhibits about the company's history from Edwardian times until the present day, developments in automobile technology, and a display of automobiles. There are also guided tours of the factory.

column3: Single-seat Morgan Runabout, similar to HFS Morgan's 1909 car]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": H.F.S. Morgan quit the [[Great Western Railway]] in 1904 and co-founded a motor sales and servicing garage in Malvern Link. In 1909 he designed and built a car for his own use. Previously he developed the first independent front suspension in

the engineering shop of [[Malvern College]].<ref name=\"Leng-Ward\"/> He began production a year later and the company prospered. Production of three wheelers approached 1000 by WW1 and quickly resumed with both racing and touring models. Morgan's first four wheeler came in 1935 with three wheelers phased out in 1952. Morgan continued to run it until he died at age 77 in 1959.<ref name=Motor197005>{{cite journal

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Peter Morgan]], son of HFS, ran the company until a few years before his death in 2003. He was replaced as chairman by Alan Garnett, a non-family director, from 2003 to 2006. After Garnett's resignation, a four-man management team was set up.

Charles Morgan]] (son of Peter), Matthew Parkin, Tim Whitworth and Steve Morris made up the new management team, and in 2010, after Parkin's resignation, Charles Morgan was named managing director. In January, 2013, Morgan was removed as managing director, replaced by Morris, but continued as strategy director until October 2013 when he was removed both as an employee and member of the board of directors.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Charles Morgan describes distress at being ousted from board role
column12: title=Charles Morgan removed from world-famous UK car firm
column17: title=Historic British sports car maker Morgan faces backlash after ousting the founder's final family member from the board

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": At the end of 2013, the shareholders appointed Andrew Duncan, a local solicitor, as chairman. In 2016, he resigned as chairman and company director and was replaced as chairman by a new director, Dominic Riley.{{citation needed
For most of its history, the company was owned by the Morgan family.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Britain’s last domestically owned motor company has been sold to Italian investors
column7: access-date=2020-03-21}}</ref> A press release dated 5 March 2019 announced the acquisition of a majority stake in Morgan Motor Company Ltd by the Italian investment group Investindustrial.<ref name=acquisition>{{cite press release
column9: title=Investindustrial acquired majority stake in Morgan Motor Company
column11: date=5 March 2019}}</ref> As part of Investindustrial's investment, management and staff were rewarded with shares in the company. The Morgan family retain a minority shareholding and continue to be involved in the company.<ref>{{Cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The early cars were two-seat or four-seat [[three-wheeler]]s, and are therefore considered to be [[cyclecar]]s. Three-wheeled vehicles avoided the British tax on cars by being classified as [[motorcycle]]s. Competition from small cars like the [[Austin 7]] and the original [[Morris Minor (1928)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Morris Minor]], with comparable economy and price and better comfort, made cyclecars less attractive.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": H.F.S. Morgan's first car design was a single-seat three-wheeled [[Runabout (car)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: runabout]], which was fabricated for his personal use in 1908, with help from William Stephenson-Peach, the father of friends, and the engineering master at [[Malvern College]].<ref name=\"Leng-Ward\"/><ref name=\"auto\"/><ref name=Morgan100>{{cite book
column22: abbr=on}}<ref>Boddy, William. \"Morgan: An Ageless Thoroughbred\", in Ward, Ian, Executive Editor. ''The World of Automobiles'', Volume 12 (London: Orbis, 1974), p.1410.</ref> Peugeot twin cylinder engine (from an abandoned [[motorcycle]] project), the car had a backbone chassis, an idea retained for all following Morgan three-wheelers, and used as little material and labour as Morgan could manage.<ref name=\"auto\">Boddy, p.1410.</ref> A single-seat three-wheeler with coil-spring<ref name=\"auto\"/> independent front suspension, unusual at the time, the driveshaft ran through the backbone tube to a two-speed transmission (with no reverse),<ref name=\"auto\"/> and [[chain drive]] to each of the rear wheels.<ref name=\"auto1\">Boddy, p.1411.</ref> The steering was by tiller, and it had band brakes.<ref name=\"auto1\"/> It also had no body.<ref name=\"auto1\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": With financial help from his father and his wife,<ref name=\"auto1\"/> the car was put into production at premises in Pickersleigh Road,<ref>Boddy, p.1416.</ref> Malvern Link. Three single-seater cars were exhibited at the 1910 Motor Show at Olympia in London. In spite of great interest being shown, only a few orders were taken, and Morgan decided a two-seater was needed to meet market demand. This was built in 1911, adding a bonnet, windscreen, wheel steering, and crank starting; it was displayed at the 1911 Motor Cycle Show.<ref name=\"auto1\"/> An agency was taken up by the [[Harrod's]] department store in London, with a selling price of [[Pound sterling
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: £]]65.<ref name=\"auto1\"/> The Morgan became the only car ever to appear in a shop window at Harrods.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Interest in his runabout led him to patent his design and begin production. While he initially showed single-seat and two-seat versions of his runabout at the 1911 [[Olympia, London
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Olympia]] Motor Exhibition, he was convinced at the exhibition that there would be greater demand for a two-seat model.<ref name=\"Morgan 3-Wheeler - History\">{{cite web
column10: url-status=live}}</ref> The Morgan Motor Company was registered as a [[Limited company
column11: limited private company]] only in 1912 with H.F.S. Morgan as managing director and his father, who had invested in his son's business, as its first chairman.<ref name=Motor197005/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In 1912, Morgan set out to win the trophy offered by ''The Light Car & Cyclecar'' for greatest distance covered in an hour, at [[Brooklands]]. The single-seater covered {{convert
column5: abbr=on}}, only to be narrowly beaten by a [[GWK (car)
column6: GWK]]; Morgan returned later the same year, reaching nearly {{convert

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Morgan established its reputation via competition such as winning the 1913 Cyclecar Grand Prix at [[Amiens]] in France, driven by [[W. G. McMinnies]], with an average speed of {{convert
column9: abbr=on}} distance.<ref name=\"auto1\"/> This became the basis for the 'Grand Prix' model of 1913 to 1926, from which evolved the 'Aero', and 'Sports' models.<ref name=\"Morgan 3-Wheeler - Models\">{{cite web
column16: url-status=live}}</ref> Morgan himself won the \"very tough\" ACU Six Days' Trial in 1913, in the [[sidecar]] class.<ref name=\"auto1\"/> The same year, the company entered the MCC reliability trial, which it continued to do until 1975.<ref name=\"auto1\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Racing success led to demand the company proved unable to meet.<ref>Boddy, p.1411-12.</ref>
These models used air-cooled or liquid-cooled variations of motorcycle engines.<ref name=\"Morgan 3-Wheeler - Engines\">{{cite web
column3: title= Engines used in the Morgan Three-wheeler
column8: url-status=live}}</ref> The engine was placed ahead of the axis of the front wheels in a chassis made of steel tubes brazed into cast lugs.<ref name=\"Morgan 3-Wheeler - Technical\">{{cite web
column10: title=– Technical Details of the Morgan Three-wheelers

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: First World War]], the company introduced an easily changed rear wheel, which customers had been seeking for several years.<ref name=\"auto2\">Boddy, p.1412.</ref> The 1921 Popular, powered by an {{convert
column8: poplar]], sold for £150.<ref name=\"auto2\"/> It was a sales success, the price dropping to £128, and the name changing to Standard, by 1923, when a [[Blackburne (motorcycles)
column9: Blackburne]] engine was also available.<ref name=\"auto2\"/> The Grand Prix was priced £155, and the Family (with two notional child seats behind the front bench, setting a standard [[2+2 (car body style)
column10: 2+2s]] would follow for generations) was £148 with air-cooled engine, or £158 with water-cooled engine. The [[Anzani]]-powered Aero was also available, for £148.<ref name=\"auto2\"/> MAG engines were also optional.<ref name=\"auto2\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Morgan's racing efforts suffered a blow in 1924, when E. B. Ware's JAP-engined car rolled at the JCC {{convert
column5: abbr=on}} at Brooklands; Ware was seriously hurt, leading to a ban on three-wheelers competing as cars.<ref name=\"auto2\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Electric headlamps were made available in 1924, at an £8 cost.<ref name=\"auto3\">Boddy, p.1413.</ref> The Popular, powered by a {{convert
column10: abbr=on}} Aero for £148, and the one-seater £160.<ref name=\"auto3\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Like motorcycles, Morgans had hand throttles, Bowden-wire control mechanisms, and drip lubrication.<ref name=\"auto4\">Boddy, p.1414.</ref>

column5: abbr=on}} Blackburne-engined special, with 3.33:1 top gear and a {{convert
column14: abbr=on}} in a one-hour trial at Brooklands, with a peak speed of over {{convert

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In 1925, the Standard's price had dropped to £95, and the Aero £130, compared to £149 for an [[Austin Chummy]].<ref name=\"auto4\"/> Electric lighting by [[dynamo]] became standard that year.<ref name=\"auto4\"/>

Front-wheel brakes and electric start (a £10 option) became available in 1927, while the Standard's price fell to £89, complete with a double-thickness windscreen and \"electric hooter\".<ref name=\"auto4\"/> By year's end, the Standard was even cheaper, £85, while the new Super Sports debuted, with an [[overhead valve engine
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: overhead valve]] JAP 10/40 water-cooled vee-twin, priced £155.<ref name=\"auto4\"/> The 10/40 engine was also available in the Aero, at £132, while a more sedate air-cooled JAP-powered Aero went for £119.<ref name=\"auto4\"/> The Family was priced at £102 (air-cooled) or £112 (water-cooled).<ref name=\"auto4\"/> These new, lower prices persisted through 1928.<ref>Boddy, p.1414-15.</ref> They would be lower still in 1929: the Standard and Family at £87 10[[shilling
column3: s]], the Aero £110, and the Super Sports £145.<ref name=\"auto5\">Boddy, p.1415.</ref> In 1933, the Family was priced at only £80.<ref name=\"auto5\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Morgan's racing program in 1927 earned the marque eleven gold medals and three silvers from fourteen entrants at MCC's London-Edinburgh Trials alone.<ref name=\"auto4\"/> The team was joined by [[Clive Lones (racing driver)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Clive Lones]] and [[C. T. Jay]], who won the 1929 Cyclecar ''Grand Prix'' at Brooklands, driving a {{convert
column6: abbr=on}} Morgan-JAP, with an average speed of {{convert
column11: Gwenda Stewart]] turned in a speed of {{convert
column15: abbr=on}} in a race-tuned Super Sports.<ref name=\"auto5\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Morgan three-wheelers benefitted from an annual tax of just £4, half the tax on the [[Austin 7]],<ref>Boddy, p.1412-13.</ref> provided they remained under 8 [[Hundredweight

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: licence-built]] in France by [[Darmont]].<ref>Boddy, p.1412 caption.</ref>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": By 1930, however, inexpensive four-wheeled cars were proliferating, led by the £100 [[Ford Model Y
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Ford Popular]].<ref name=\"auto5\"/> Morgan, and partner [[George Goodall]], countered by putting the {{convert
column19: Ford engine]] in their own cars.<ref name=\"auto5\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Morgan's last vee-twins were powered by [[Matchless]] engines displacing {{convert
column5: abbr=on}}; they were delivered to Australia after the [[World War Two

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The vee-twin models were not returned to production after World War II.
The Morgan F-4 was introduced in 1933 at the Olympia Motor Cycle Show.<ref name=\"Hillp13_14\">{{cite book
column24: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The F-4 had a new pressed-steel chassis<ref name=\"Morgan 3-Wheeler - Technical\" /> the four-cylinder [[Ford Sidevalve engine]] used in the [[Ford Model Y
column25: Model Y]], and a four-seat body.<ref name=\"Morgan 3-Wheeler - Models\" /><ref name=\"Hillp13_14\" /> The F-4 was supplemented by the two-seat F-2 in 1935 and the more sporting F Super, with cycle-type wings and louvred bonnet tops, in 1937. Production of the Ford-engined three-wheelers continued until 1952.<ref name=\"Morgan 3-Wheeler - Models\" /><ref name=\"Hillp13_14\" /><ref name=\"Leng-Ward\">{{cite web
column28: title=Guide to the historical records of the British motor car industry

column3: cylinder]] engine and four wheels, was released to the public in 1936.<ref name=\"auto6\">Boddy, p.1417.</ref> Powered by a {{convert
column12: abbr=on}} [[Coventry Climax]] engine, and carrying a pair of rear-mounted spare wheels, the new two-seater 4–4 sold for 185 [[Guinea (coin)
column14: s]]).<ref name=\"auto6\"/> It proved popular, and a four-place model was added in 1937, joined by a £236 [[Convertible

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Coventry Climax eventually ceased making engines available, so Morgan switched to a tuned {{convert
In 1938, a 4–4 was entered at [[24 Hours of Le Mans
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Le Mans]].<ref name=\"auto6\"/> This led to production of factory replicas, with fold-down windscreen, [[cycle fenders]], smaller-[[Engine displacement
column3: displacement]] engine, and single spare wheels, with a price of £250.<ref name=\"auto6\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The [[Morgan +4]] was introduced in 1950 as a larger-engined (\"plus\") car than the 4/4. The +4 initially used the {{convert
column4: abbr=on}} [[Standard Vanguard]] engine and at introduction sold for £625 (two-seater) or £723 (coupé).<ref name=\"auto6\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The +4 used [[Triumph TR2]] (in 1953),<ref name=\"auto7\">Boddy, p.1418.</ref> [[Triumph TR3
column3: TR4A]] engines (until 1969). Plus 4 production was suspended in 1969 but brought back in 1985 with a Fiat engine (1985–1988) and then a 4-cylinder Rover engine (1988–2000). Production was again suspended and the Plus 4 returned once more in 2004 with a {{convert

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": From October 1965 to April 1967 Morgan produced the two-seat +4 Competition, of which only 42 were built, about 11 of which survive.{{citation needed
A limited edition Plus 4 was re-introduced in 2014 as the [[Morgan +4
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Plus 4]] Super Sports. Only 60 cars were made available, all right-hand-drive.{{citation needed

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": A version of the +4, the +4+, was made from 1964 to 1967 with a fibreglass coupé body. The light weight and reduced drag improved the performance of the +4+ over the standard +4 in every aspect. However, traditional Morgan enthusiasts did not embrace this departure from Morgan custom, and mainstream enthusiasts did not embrace the seemingly archaic +4 chassis. Fifty were planned, but only 26 were built.<ref>Boddy, p.1416 caption.</ref>

Production of the 4-4 was halted during World War II but resumed afterwards as the 4/4. Production halted again in 1950 when the Standard engine ceased to be available, but resumed in 1955 when a suitable replacement, the side-valve 1,172 cc Ford 100E engine was found, and has continued ever since.
The 4/4 now uses the +8 chassis and a Ford engine.

Faced with the decreasing availability of large four-cylinder engines for use in their +4 models, Morgan began to install the recently available [[Rover V8 engine]] in their cars in 1968, giving these cars the model designation \"+8\".

The engine displacement jumped from the 2.3 L of the Triumph TR4 engine to 3.5 L, then 3.9 L (1990), 4.0 (1998–2004) with an optional 4.6L (1996–2000) all based on the same Land Rover block. However, this V-8 was no heavier than the Triumph engine. These features made the +8 accelerate much more quickly than the early +4 and also improved its road-holding capability.

Horsepower (143–204 bhp), weight and performance varied with emission and structural laws through its history. Thus powered, the car could accelerate from 0–60 mph in 5.6 seconds. In its final form, the GEMS Land Rover V8 produced {{convert

In 2004, Morgan came out with a traditional styled model to replace the departing Plus 8. The Mk I Roadsters with the Ford UK Mondeo V6 produced 223 bhp (166 kW, 226 PS) at 6150 rev/min. It had a [[Magna PT
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Getrag]] gearbox with direct drive in 5th with a 3.08 axle ratio. Later Marks had a Ford gearbox with direct drive in 4th with a 3.73 axle ratio. The overall gearing is virtually the same. The later Roadsters were powered by a Ford UK Mondeo V6 producing {{convert
column7: abbr=on}}. In 2007, the Mondeo engine was replaced by a US-specification version of the same engine in the Roadster II. In 2011–12, the engine was replaced by the 3.7 Duratec Cyclone engine and output increased to {{convert
column12: abbr=on}}. The company calls this latest model the Roadster 3.7.

column3: A Modern Morgan Aero 8 at the [[Scarsdale Concours]]]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In 2000, the Morgan Aero 8 was introduced and, as always, the wooden body substructure was [[Ash tree
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: ash]]. (Contrary to popular myth, however, the [[chassis]] is metal; [[aluminium]] for the Aero 8.) The Aero 8, with a [[BMW]] [[V8 engine]] in a car weighing less than a [[BMW Z4]] and considerably less than a [[BMW M3]], (though more than traditional Morgans) is even faster than the Plus 8, delivering what ''[[Autoweek]]'' magazine termed [[supercar]] performance. The newest Aero 8 (series V), presented in March 2015, puts out {{convert
column5: abbr=on}} at 6100 rpm with the company suggesting a top speed of over {{convert
column9: abbr=on}}. Due to the Aero 8's light weight it can do 0–62 mph (100 km/h) in 4.5 seconds.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": During its customer production lifetime (2002–2009), the Aero was configured in five official versions, (I, II, III, IV, the Aero America and V) with mild variations in styling, engines, transmissions, braking and suspension. The company canceled the model in 2009 but relaunched it in 2015 for 2016 deliveries. The year of highest production for any Aero variation was 2002.

column3: Morgan AeroMax, showing distinct boat tail rear]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Aero was followed by the Aeromax, a limited edition of 100 units produced between 2008 and early 2010. The Aeromax was a coupé variation of the Aero 8. Customers have included [[Richard Hammond]], [[Rowan Atkinson]] and [[Paul O'Grady]].
The Morgan Aero SuperSports is a [[Targa top
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: targa-roofed]] version of the AeroMax, sharing its bonded aluminium chassis and lower bodywork with the coupe.<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=16 July 2017}}</ref> It was launched at the 2009 Pebble Beach car show in California. Its cancellation was announced in March 2015.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Morgan Aero Coupé is a hard top version of the Aero SuperSports, sharing its bonded aluminium chassis, bodywork, suspension and engine. It was launched at the end of 2011. It is not available in the United States. Its cancellation was announced in March 2015.

The new Morgan Plus 8 is a classic body version of the Aero SuperSports and Aero Coupé, sharing their bonded aluminium chassis, bodywork, suspension and engine. It was launched at the end of 2011. It is not available in the United States. In 2019, Morgan announced its cancellation.
The Morgan Plus E is an electric version of a classical Morgan, a joint project of Morgan with [[Zytek]] and Radshape (Radshape Sheet Metal Ltd.),<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Morgan Plus E Electric Roadster: Modern Battery In Classic Car
column5: accessdate=16 July 2017}}</ref> funded by the UK government. It was displayed at the 2012 [[Geneva Motor Show]].<ref>[http://www.morgan-motor.co.uk/mmc/downloads/pressreleases/plusegenevapressrelease.pdf THE NEW MORGAN PLUS E] ''morgan-motor.co.uk'', accessed 2 June 2019</ref><ref>[http://newatlas.com/something-old-something-new-the-morgan-plus-e/21736/ something-old-something-new-the-morgan-plus-e] ''newatlas.com'', accessed 2 June 2019</ref> It has never been produced and the project was abandoned.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Based on the same chassis as the Aero Supersports, the Eva GT would have been a 2+2 grand tourer, and as such it would be longer in the body. The Eva GT would use [[BMW N54]] twin-turbo straight-6 producing 302 bhp, Euro-6 emissions compliant. Shown at Pebble Beach in clay in 2010 and expected to go on sale in 2012, deposits have been taken since 2010. At the end of 2011, Morgan announced that it would use new magnesium technology for the body and therefore it would not be represented until 2014 with deliveries after that. In 2013 dealers confirmed that the EvaGT had been cancelled.
The Morgan Motor Company announced that they would launch the \"3 Wheeler\" in 2011<ref name=\"EIL20101104\">{{cite news
column41: accessdate=29 Mar 2019}}</ref> at the [[Geneva Motor Show]].<ref name=\"Car20101103\" /><ref name=\"AE20101104\" /> The 3 Wheeler was initially said to have a [[Harley-Davidson]] ''Screaming Eagle'' V-twin engine and a [[Mazda]] 5-speed manual transmission,<ref name= \"EIL20101104\" /><ref name=\"Car20101103\" /><ref name=\"AE20101104\" /><ref name=\"AW20101103\" /><ref name= \"WR20101103\">{{cite news
column49: accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref> and was estimated to deliver {{cvt
column53: 0}}<ref name=\"EIL20101104\" /><ref name=\"AE20101104\" /><ref name=\"AW20101103\" /><ref name= \"WR20101103\" /> at the rear wheel.<ref name=\"AW20101103\" /><ref name=\"WR20101103\" /> However, the prototype that was shown at Geneva had an [[S&S Cycle
column54: S&S]] engine. Production three-wheelers turned out to have S&S engines.<ref name=\"NYT20110225\">{{cite news
column62: quote=It was announced to have an 81-horsepower V-twin motorcycle engine built by S & S, the same company that builds motors for so-called Harley clone choppers, and is closely based on late-model Harley-Davidson power plants. However, the UK test the final bhp at 81 bhp.}}</ref><ref name=\"CaD_M3W\">{{cite news
column71: quote=This S&S-supplied powerplant is a bit more modern, though: It produces 81 hp, is fuel-injected, and is mated to a Mazda-sourced five-speed gearbox.

column79: 0}},<ref name= \"EIL20101104\" /><ref name= \"Car20101103\" /><ref name= \"AE20101104\" /><ref name= \"WR20101103\" /> but the final weight was tested at {{cvt
column87: 0}} was estimated by Morgan as 4.5 seconds, with an (estimated) top speed of {{cvt
column91: 0}}.<ref name= \"EIL20101104\"/><ref name=\"Car20101103\"/><ref name=\"AE20101104\"/><ref name=\"AW20101103\"/><ref name=\"WR20101103\"/> The three-wheeler is to be [[homologation
column92: homologated]] as a motorcycle in the United States.<ref name=\"EIL20101104\"/><ref name= \"WR20101103\"/> The company states that 850 deposits have been taken since the announcement in 2011. Customer deliveries began in Europe in February 2012. US deliveries were not expected before June 2012, when the first imported three-wheeler was displayed in New York City and at the Greenwich Concours d'Elegance. The Morgan 3 Wheeler was featured in a Series 18 episode of UK motoring show ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)
column93: Top Gear]]'' where presenter [[Richard Hammond]] selected the Morgan 3 Wheeler in a comparison of track-day cars. The 3 Wheeler won the \"Not-A-Car of the Year 2011\" in [[Top Gear (magazine)

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Morgan Plus Six was announced in March 2019 at the [[Geneva Motor Show]]. Instead of the traditional Morgan ladder frame and sliding-pillar suspension, it has a new bonded aluminium chassis and all-independent suspension design, with double wishbones at the front and a multi-link system for the rear. The Plus Six is powered by a [[BMW]] B58 turbocharged in-line six-cylinder petrol engine, producing 335 bhp, coupled to an eight-speed ZF automatic transmission.<ref name=\"autocar-plus6\">{{cite web
column4: title=Morgan Plus Six is marque's first all-new model in 19 years

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": For part of the 1950s and 1960s, the United States provided the company with its largest market worldwide, taking up to 85% of all production.<ref>Laban, Brian. ''Morgan: First and Last of the Real Sports Cars.'' London: Virgin Books, 2000, page number not cited.</ref> This ended with the first wave of US safety and emission regulations in 1971. For many years (1974 to 1992), all Morgans imported into the United States were converted to run on propane as fuel to pass the US [[emission standard
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: emissions regulations]]. However, this conversion, along with bringing the cars into compliance with US vehicle safety legislation, was carried out by the dealership, and not by the factory, making the cars [[grey import vehicles
column5: title=Reprint of Car & Driver article, January 1977

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": However, when the [[Rover Group]] re-certified their V8 engine for use in the [[Range Rover]] [[Sport utility vehicle
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: 4x4]] sold in the US, Morgan was able to use the same engine for a fully US-compliant stock Morgan from 1992 to 1996,{{Citation needed
column3: date=September 2008}} and again from 1998 to 2004.{{Citation needed
column4: date=September 2008}} In 2005, the engine was replaced with the US-version of another traditionally shaped model (with a V6), called the Roadster.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In 2002, Morgan centralised its international compliancy development and regulatory interaction in-house.{{Citation needed
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: date=September 2008}} In 2005, its right to import its classic models ceased when supplies of its necessary airbag were exhausted and no replacement was developed. In 2006, a request for an airbag exemption to the US [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] was refused, and the import of classic Morgans ceased.<ref>http://frwebgate5.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/waisgate.cgi?WAISdocID=959721101393+0+0+0&WAISaction=retrieve{{dead link

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In 2005, the new Morgan Aero 8 model (versions 2 and 3) received a three-year exemption from rear impact non-compliance,<ref>http://frwebgate4.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/waisgate.cgi?WAISdocID=959367106968+0+0+0&WAISaction=retrieve{{dead link
column4: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> along with a separate exemption for compliance with \"advanced airbag requirements\".<ref>http://frwebgate4.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/waisgate.cgi?WAISdocID=959366106946+0+0+0&WAISaction=retrieve{{dead link
column7: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The rear-impact exemption lapsed in May 2008 without further application. Morgan has indicated to its US dealers that it plans to re-apply for US certification for some model at as yet an undetermined date in the future.{{Citation needed

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In April 2012, the new Morgan 3-Wheeler was showcased at the New York International Auto Show, at the Jacob Javits Center, by Bobby Singh and Gideon Lang-Laddie of Manhattan Motorsports. This was the first time in 10 years that Morgan had had a presence at the largest of the American car shows and was the first US specification Morgan 3-Wheeler in the United States. The Morgan 3 Wheeler was voted one of the \"Hottest Cars Of The Show\" by G4TV.<ref>{{cite web

In May 2012, Manhattan Motorsports took delivery of Charles Morgan's Superdry edition Morgan 3-Wheeler and prepared it for its first major American trial. This vehicle was driven across the States, from New York to Los Angeles by Charles Morgan and his wife, covering 3000 miles, in the [[Gumball 3000]]. At the end of the seven-day drive, the Morgan 3 Wheeler was awarded the \"Spirit of Gumball\" prize.
In spite of their traditional design, Morgans have always had sporting or \"sports car\" performance, due to their extremely low weight.
Among their enthusiasts, Morgans are affectionately known as \"Moggies\".

H.F.S. Morgan's 1909 runabout used [[sliding pillar suspension]], an [[independent front suspension]] system with each front wheel mounted on a stub axle able to slide up and down a fixed pillar that also acts as the [[kingpin (automotive part)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: kingpin]] and supported by a spring and external shock absorber (damper). One advantage is reduced unsprung weight, theoretically allowing the tyre and wheel to better respond to road surface irregularities. The Morgan system is described as an 'inverted' sliding pillar, as the pillar is fixed and the hub carrier slides over it. Earlier systems had the wheel carried on the pillar, sliding through a bush on the axle.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Morgan used developments of this suspension system throughout its existence, and it is still used on Morgan's \"classic\" line, although not on the Aero 8 or its derivatives. It has been cancelled, along with all the Morgan Classic line, in 2019. However, some \"classics\", shipped in parts to avoid the need for normal compliancy, will be shipped to the USA, and assembled there for an indefinite period.

Morgan cars can be found in many areas of motorsport, from club and historic racing to more prominent examples, including the Le Mans 24hr race. A notable Morgan racecar was the Aero 8 GT car that campaigned in 2008 Britcar races and the 2008 Britcar 24hrs at Silverstone, prepared and run by Mark Bailey Racing.

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Le Mans Prototype]] as a Morgan for the [[2012 24 Hours of Le Mans]], partly to mark the 50th anniversary of a class victory for a Morgan Plus Four Super Sports at Le Mans.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=British Sportscar Maker Morgan to Race LMP2 Car at Le Mans
description=1928 Morgan Super Aero at Goodwood Festival of Speed 2009}}

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The '''Morgan Motor Company''' is a British [[automobile
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: motor car]] manufacturer, owned by the Italian Investindustrial since March of 2019. It was founded in 1910 by [[H.F.S. Morgan

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Morgan is based in [[Malvern Link]], an area of Malvern, Worcestershire, and employs approximately 220 people. Morgan has stated that they produce 850 cars per year, all assembled by hand.<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=5 March 2019}}</ref> The waiting list for a car is approximately six months, and has sometimes been as long as ten years.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Morgan cars are unusual because wood has been used in their construction for a century, and is still used in the 21st century for framing the body shell.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Let the Wood (and Aluminum) Times Roll: A Tour of Morgan Motor Company’s Factory
column5: accessdate=4 January 2018}}</ref> A visitor centre and museum have exhibits about the company's history from Edwardian times until the present day, developments in automobile technology, and a display of automobiles. There are also guided tours of the factory.

column3: Single-seat Morgan Runabout, similar to HFS Morgan's 1909 car]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": H.F.S. Morgan quit the [[Great Western Railway]] in 1904 and co-founded a motor sales and servicing garage in Malvern Link. In 1909 he designed and built a car for his own use. Previously he developed the first independent front suspension in

the engineering shop of [[Malvern College]].<ref name=\"Leng-Ward\"/> He began production a year later and the company prospered. Production of three wheelers approached 1000 by WW1 and quickly resumed with both racing and touring models. Morgan's first four wheeler came in 1935 with three wheelers phased out in 1952. Morgan continued to run it until he died at age 77 in 1959.<ref name=Motor197005>{{cite journal

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Peter Morgan]], son of HFS, ran the company until a few years before his death in 2003. He was replaced as chairman by Alan Garnett, a non-family director, from 2003 to 2006. After Garnett's resignation, a four-man management team was set up.

Charles Morgan]] (son of Peter), Matthew Parkin, Tim Whitworth and Steve Morris made up the new management team, and in 2010, after Parkin's resignation, Charles Morgan was named managing director. In January, 2013, Morgan was removed as managing director, replaced by Morris, but continued as strategy director until October 2013 when he was removed both as an employee and member of the board of directors.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Charles Morgan describes distress at being ousted from board role
column12: title=Charles Morgan removed from world-famous UK car firm
column17: title=Historic British sports car maker Morgan faces backlash after ousting the founder's final family member from the board

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": At the end of 2013, the shareholders appointed Andrew Duncan, a local solicitor, as chairman. In 2016, he resigned as chairman and company director and was replaced as chairman by a new director, Dominic Riley.{{citation needed
For most of its history, the company was owned by the Morgan family.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Britain’s last domestically owned motor company has been sold to Italian investors
column7: access-date=2020-03-21}}</ref> A press release dated 5 March 2019 announced the acquisition of a majority stake in Morgan Motor Company Ltd by the Italian investment group Investindustrial.<ref name=acquisition>{{cite press release
column9: title=Investindustrial acquired majority stake in Morgan Motor Company
column11: date=5 March 2019}}</ref> As part of Investindustrial's investment, management and staff were rewarded with shares in the company. The Morgan family retain a minority shareholding and continue to be involved in the company. <ref>{{Cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The early cars were two-seat or four-seat [[three-wheeler]]s, and are therefore considered to be [[cyclecar]]s. Three-wheeled vehicles avoided the British tax on cars by being classified as [[motorcycle]]s. Competition from small cars like the [[Austin 7]] and the original [[Morris Minor (1928)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Morris Minor]], with comparable economy and price and better comfort, made cyclecars less attractive.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": H.F.S. Morgan's first car design was a single-seat three-wheeled [[Runabout (car)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: runabout]], which was fabricated for his personal use in 1908, with help from William Stephenson-Peach, the father of friends, and the engineering master at [[Malvern College]].<ref name=\"Leng-Ward\"/><ref name=\"auto\"/><ref name=Morgan100>{{cite book
column22: abbr=on}}<ref>Boddy, William. \"Morgan: An Ageless Thoroughbred\", in Ward, Ian, Executive Editor. ''The World of Automobiles'', Volume 12 (London: Orbis, 1974), p.1410.</ref> Peugeot twin cylinder engine (from an abandoned [[motorcycle]] project), the car had a backbone chassis, an idea retained for all following Morgan three-wheelers, and used as little material and labour as Morgan could manage.<ref name=\"auto\">Boddy, p.1410.</ref> A single-seat three-wheeler with coil-spring<ref name=\"auto\"/> independent front suspension, unusual at the time, the driveshaft ran through the backbone tube to a two-speed transmission (with no reverse),<ref name=\"auto\"/> and [[chain drive]] to each of the rear wheels.<ref name=\"auto1\">Boddy, p.1411.</ref> The steering was by tiller, and it had band brakes.<ref name=\"auto1\"/> It also had no body.<ref name=\"auto1\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": With financial help from his father and his wife,<ref name=\"auto1\"/> the car was put into production at premises in Pickersleigh Road,<ref>Boddy, p.1416.</ref> Malvern Link. Three single-seater cars were exhibited at the 1910 Motor Show at Olympia in London. In spite of great interest being shown, only a few orders were taken, and Morgan decided a two-seater was needed to meet market demand. This was built in 1911, adding a bonnet, windscreen, wheel steering, and crank starting; it was displayed at the 1911 Motor Cycle Show.<ref name=\"auto1\"/> An agency was taken up by the [[Harrod's]] department store in London, with a selling price of [[Pound sterling
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: £]]65.<ref name=\"auto1\"/> The Morgan became the only car ever to appear in a shop window at Harrods.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Interest in his runabout led him to patent his design and begin production. While he initially showed single-seat and two-seat versions of his runabout at the 1911 [[Olympia, London
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Olympia]] Motor Exhibition, he was convinced at the exhibition that there would be greater demand for a two-seat model.<ref name=\"Morgan 3-Wheeler - History\">{{cite web
column10: url-status=live}}</ref> The Morgan Motor Company was registered as a [[Limited company
column11: limited private company]] only in 1912 with H.F.S. Morgan as managing director and his father, who had invested in his son's business, as its first chairman.<ref name=Motor197005/>

column5: abbr=on}}, only to be narrowly beaten by a [[GWK (car)
column6: GWK]]; Morgan returned later the same year, reaching nearly {{convert

column9: abbr=on}} distance.<ref name=\"auto1\"/> This became the basis for the 'Grand Prix' model of 1913 to 1926, from which evolved the 'Aero', and 'Sports' models.<ref name=\"Morgan 3-Wheeler - Models\">{{cite web
column16: url-status=live}}</ref> Morgan himself won the \"very tough\" ACU Six Days' Trial in 1913, in the [[sidecar]] class.<ref name=\"auto1\"/> The same year, the company entered the MCC reliability trial, which it continued to do until 1975.<ref name=\"auto1\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Racing success led to demand the company proved unable to meet.<ref>Boddy, p.1411-12.</ref>
These models used air-cooled or liquid-cooled variations of motorcycle engines.<ref name=\"Morgan 3-Wheeler - Engines\">{{cite web

New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: First World War]], the company introduced an easily changed rear wheel, which customers had been seeking for several years.<ref name=\"auto2\">Boddy, p.1412.</ref> The 1921 Popular, powered by an {{convert

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In 1925, the Standard's price had dropped to £95, and the Aero £130, compared to £149 for an [[Austin Chummy]].<ref name=\"auto4\"/> Electric lighting by [[dynamo]] became standard that year.<ref name=\"auto4\"/>

Front-wheel brakes and electric start (a £10 option) became available in 1927, while the Standard's price fell to £89, complete with a double-thickness windscreen and \"electric hooter\".<ref name=\"auto4\"/> By year's end, the Standard was even cheaper, £85, while the new Super Sports debuted, with an [[overhead valve engine
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: overhead valve]] JAP 10/40 water-cooled vee-twin, priced £155.<ref name=\"auto4\"/> The 10/40 engine was also available in the Aero, at £132, while a more sedate air-cooled JAP-powered Aero went for £119.<ref name=\"auto4\"/> The Family was priced at £102 (air-cooled) or £112 (water-cooled).<ref name=\"auto4\"/> These new, lower prices persisted through 1928.<ref>Boddy, p.1414-15.</ref> They would be lower still in 1929: the Standard and Family at £87 10[[shilling
column3: s]], the Aero £110, and the Super Sports £145.<ref name=\"auto5\">Boddy, p.1415.</ref> In 1933, the Family was priced at only £80.<ref name=\"auto5\"/>

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The vee-twin models were not returned to production after World War II.
The Morgan F-4 was introduced in 1933 at the Olympia Motor Cycle Show.<ref name=\"Hillp13_14\">{{cite book
column24: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The F-4 had a new pressed-steel chassis<ref name=\"Morgan 3-Wheeler - Technical\" /> the four-cylinder [[Ford Sidevalve engine]] used in the [[Ford Model Y
column25: Model Y]], and a four-seat body.<ref name=\"Morgan 3-Wheeler - Models\" /><ref name=\"Hillp13_14\" /> The F-4 was supplemented by the two-seat F-2 in 1935 and the more sporting F Super, with cycle-type wings and louvred bonnet tops, in 1937. Production of the Ford-engined three-wheelers continued until 1952.<ref name=\"Morgan 3-Wheeler - Models\" /><ref name=\"Hillp13_14\" /><ref name=\"Leng-Ward\">{{cite web
column28: title=Guide to the historical records of the British motor car industry

column14: s]]).<ref name=\"auto6\"/> It proved popular, and a four-place model was added in 1937, joined by a £236 [[Convertible

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": A version of the +4, the +4+, was made from 1964 to 1967 with a fibreglass coupé body. The light weight and reduced drag improved the performance of the +4+ over the standard +4 in every aspect. However, traditional Morgan enthusiasts did not embrace this departure from Morgan custom, and mainstream enthusiasts did not embrace the seemingly archaic +4 chassis. Fifty were planned, but only 26 were built.<ref>Boddy, p.1416 caption.</ref>

Production of the 4-4 was halted during World War II but resumed afterwards as the 4/4. Production halted again in 1950 when the Standard engine ceased to be available, but resumed in 1955 when a suitable replacement, the side-valve 1,172 cc Ford 100E engine was found, and has continued ever since.
The 4/4 now uses the +8 chassis and a Ford engine.

Faced with the decreasing availability of large four-cylinder engines for use in their +4 models, Morgan began to install the recently available [[Rover V8 engine]] in their cars in 1968, giving these cars the model designation \"+8\".

The engine displacement jumped from the 2.3 L of the Triumph TR4 engine to 3.5 L, then 3.9 L (1990), 4.0 (1998–2004) with an optional 4.6L (1996–2000) all based on the same Land Rover block. However, this V-8 was no heavier than the Triumph engine. These features made the +8 accelerate much more quickly than the early +4 and also improved its road-holding capability.

Horsepower (143–204 bhp), weight and performance varied with emission and structural laws through its history. Thus powered, the car could accelerate from 0–60 mph in 5.6 seconds. In its final form, the GEMS Land Rover V8 produced {{convert

In 2004, Morgan came out with a traditional styled model to replace the departing Plus 8. The Mk I Roadsters with the Ford UK Mondeo V6 produced 223 bhp (166 kW, 226 PS) at 6150 rev/min. It had a [[Magna PT
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: Getrag]] gearbox with direct drive in 5th with a 3.08 axle ratio. Later Marks had a Ford gearbox with direct drive in 4th with a 3.73 axle ratio. The overall gearing is virtually the same. The later Roadsters were powered by a Ford UK Mondeo V6 producing {{convert
column7: abbr=on}}. In 2007, the Mondeo engine was replaced by a US-specification version of the same engine in the Roadster II. In 2011–12, the engine was replaced by the 3.7 Duratec Cyclone engine and output increased to {{convert
column12: abbr=on}}. The company calls this latest model the Roadster 3.7.

column3: A Modern Morgan Aero 8 at the [[Scarsdale Concours]]]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In 2000, the Morgan Aero 8 was introduced and, as always, the wooden body substructure was [[Ash tree
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: ash]]. (Contrary to popular myth, however, the [[chassis]] is metal; [[aluminium]] for the Aero 8.) The Aero 8, with a [[BMW]] [[V8 engine]] in a car weighing less than a [[BMW Z4]] and considerably less than a [[BMW M3]], (though more than traditional Morgans) is even faster than the Plus 8, delivering what ''[[Autoweek]]'' magazine termed [[supercar]] performance. The newest Aero 8 (series V), presented in March 2015, puts out {{convert
column5: abbr=on}} at 6100 rpm with the company suggesting a top speed of over {{convert
column9: abbr=on}}. Due to the Aero 8's light weight it can do 0–62 mph (100 km/h) in 4.5 seconds.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": During its customer production lifetime (2002–2009), the Aero was configured in five official versions, (I, II, III, IV, the Aero America and V) with mild variations in styling, engines, transmissions, braking and suspension. The company canceled the model in 2009 but relaunched it in 2015 for 2016 deliveries. The year of highest production for any Aero variation was 2002.

column3: Morgan AeroMax, showing distinct boat tail rear]]

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Aero was followed by the Aeromax, a limited edition of 100 units produced between 2008 and early 2010. The Aeromax was a coupé variation of the Aero 8. Customers have included [[Richard Hammond]], [[Rowan Atkinson]] and [[Paul O'Grady]].
The Morgan Aero SuperSports is a [[Targa top
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: targa-roofed]] version of the AeroMax, sharing its bonded aluminium chassis and lower bodywork with the coupe.<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=16 July 2017}}</ref> It was launched at the 2009 Pebble Beach car show in California. Its cancellation was announced in March 2015.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Morgan Aero Coupé is a hard top version of the Aero SuperSports, sharing its bonded aluminium chassis, bodywork, suspension and engine. It was launched at the end of 2011. It is not available in the United States. Its cancellation was announced in March 2015.

The new Morgan Plus 8 is a classic body version of the Aero SuperSports and Aero Coupé, sharing their bonded aluminium chassis, bodywork, suspension and engine. It was launched at the end of 2011. It is not available in the United States. In 2019, Morgan announced its cancellation.
The Morgan Plus E is an electric version of a classical Morgan, a joint project of Morgan with [[Zytek]] and Radshape (Radshape Sheet Metal Ltd.),<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Morgan Plus E Electric Roadster: Modern Battery In Classic Car
column5: accessdate=16 July 2017}}</ref> funded by the UK government. It was displayed at the 2012 [[Geneva Motor Show]].<ref>[http://www.morgan-motor.co.uk/mmc/downloads/pressreleases/plusegenevapressrelease.pdf THE NEW MORGAN PLUS E] ''morgan-motor.co.uk'', accessed 2 June 2019</ref><ref>[http://newatlas.com/something-old-something-new-the-morgan-plus-e/21736/ something-old-something-new-the-morgan-plus-e] ''newatlas.com'', accessed 2 June 2019</ref> It has never been produced and the project was abandoned.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Based on the same chassis as the Aero Supersports, the Eva GT would have been a 2+2 grand tourer, and as such it would be longer in the body. The Eva GT would use [[BMW N54]] twin-turbo straight-6 producing 302 bhp, Euro-6 emissions compliant. Shown at Pebble Beach in clay in 2010 and expected to go on sale in 2012, deposits have been taken since 2010. At the end of 2011, Morgan announced that it would use new magnesium technology for the body and therefore it would not be represented until 2014 with deliveries after that. In 2013 dealers confirmed that the EvaGT had been cancelled.
The Morgan Motor Company announced that they would launch the \"3 Wheeler\" in 2011<ref name=\"EIL20101104\">{{cite news
column41: accessdate=29 Mar 2019}}</ref> at the [[Geneva Motor Show]].<ref name=\"Car20101103\" /><ref name=\"AE20101104\" /> The 3 Wheeler was initially said to have a [[Harley-Davidson]] ''Screaming Eagle'' V-twin engine and a [[Mazda]] 5-speed manual transmission,<ref name= \"EIL20101104\" /><ref name=\"Car20101103\" /><ref name=\"AE20101104\" /><ref name=\"AW20101103\" /><ref name= \"WR20101103\">{{cite news

However, the UK test the final bhp at 81 bhp.}}</ref><ref name=\"CaD_M3W\">{{cite news

column92: homologated]] as a motorcycle in the United States.<ref name=\"EIL20101104\"/><ref name= \"WR20101103\"/> The company states that 850 deposits have been taken since the announcement in 2011. Customer deliveries began in Europe in February 2012. US deliveries were not expected before June 2012, when the first imported three-wheeler was displayed in New York City and at the Greenwich Concours d'Elegance. The Morgan 3 Wheeler was featured in a Series 18 episode of UK motoring show ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)
column93: Top Gear]]'' where presenter [[Richard Hammond]] selected the Morgan 3 Wheeler in a comparison of track-day cars. The 3 Wheeler won the \"Not-A-Car of the Year 2011\" in [[Top Gear (magazine)

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The Morgan Plus Six was announced in March 2019 at the [[Geneva Motor Show]]. Instead of the traditional Morgan ladder frame and sliding-pillar suspension, it has a new bonded aluminium chassis and all-independent suspension design, with double wishbones at the front and a multi-link system for the rear. The Plus Six is powered by a [[BMW]] B58 turbocharged in-line six-cylinder petrol engine, producing 335 bhp, coupled to an eight-speed ZF automatic transmission.<ref name=\"autocar-plus6\">{{cite web
column4: title=Morgan Plus Six is marque's first all-new model in 19 years

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": For part of the 1950s and 1960s, the United States provided the company with its largest market worldwide, taking up to 85% of all production.<ref>Laban, Brian. ''Morgan: First and Last of the Real Sports Cars.'' London: Virgin Books, 2000, page number not cited.</ref> This ended with the first wave of US safety and emission regulations in 1971. For many years (1974 to 1992), all Morgans imported into the United States were converted to run on propane as fuel to pass the US [[emission standard
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: emissions regulations]]. However, this conversion, along with bringing the cars into compliance with US vehicle safety legislation, was carried out by the dealership, and not by the factory, making the cars [[grey import vehicles
column5: title=Reprint of Car & Driver article, January 1977

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": However, when the [[Rover Group]] re-certified their V8 engine for use in the [[Range Rover]] [[Sport utility vehicle
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: 4x4]] sold in the US, Morgan was able to use the same engine for a fully US-compliant stock Morgan from 1992 to 1996,{{Citation needed
column3: date=September 2008}} and again from 1998 to 2004.{{Citation needed
column4: date=September 2008}} In 2005, the engine was replaced with the US-version of another traditionally shaped model (with a V6), called the Roadster.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In 2002, Morgan centralised its international compliancy development and regulatory interaction in-house.{{Citation needed
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: date=September 2008}} In 2005, its right to import its classic models ceased when supplies of its necessary airbag were exhausted and no replacement was developed. In 2006, a request for an airbag exemption to the US [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] was refused, and the import of classic Morgans ceased.<ref>http://frwebgate5.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/waisgate.cgi?WAISdocID=959721101393+0+0+0&WAISaction=retrieve{{dead link

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In 2005, the new Morgan Aero 8 model (versions 2 and 3) received a three-year exemption from rear impact non-compliance,<ref>http://frwebgate4.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/waisgate.cgi?WAISdocID=959367106968+0+0+0&WAISaction=retrieve{{dead link
column4: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> along with a separate exemption for compliance with \"advanced airbag requirements\".<ref>http://frwebgate4.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/waisgate.cgi?WAISdocID=959366106946+0+0+0&WAISaction=retrieve{{dead link
column7: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The rear-impact exemption lapsed in May 2008 without further application. Morgan has indicated to its US dealers that it plans to re-apply for US certification for some model at as yet an undetermined date in the future.{{Citation needed

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In April 2012, the new Morgan 3-Wheeler was showcased at the New York International Auto Show, at the Jacob Javits Center, by Bobby Singh and Gideon Lang-Laddie of Manhattan Motorsports. This was the first time in 10 years that Morgan had had a presence at the largest of the American car shows and was the first US specification Morgan 3-Wheeler in the United States. The Morgan 3 Wheeler was voted one of the \"Hottest Cars Of The Show\" by G4TV.<ref>{{cite web

In May 2012, Manhattan Motorsports took delivery of Charles Morgan's Superdry edition Morgan 3-Wheeler and prepared it for its first major American trial. This vehicle was driven across the States, from New York to Los Angeles by Charles Morgan and his wife, covering 3000 miles, in the [[Gumball 3000]]. At the end of the seven-day drive, the Morgan 3 Wheeler was awarded the \"Spirit of Gumball\" prize.
In spite of their traditional design, Morgans have always had sporting or \"sports car\" performance, due to their extremely low weight.
Among their enthusiasts, Morgans are affectionately known as \"Moggies\".

H.F.S. Morgan's 1909 runabout used [[sliding pillar suspension]], an [[independent front suspension]] system with each front wheel mounted on a stub axle able to slide up and down a fixed pillar that also acts as the [[kingpin (automotive part)
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: kingpin]] and supported by a spring and external shock absorber (damper). One advantage is reduced unsprung weight, theoretically allowing the tyre and wheel to better respond to road surface irregularities. The Morgan system is described as an 'inverted' sliding pillar, as the pillar is fixed and the hub carrier slides over it. Earlier systems had the wheel carried on the pillar, sliding through a bush on the axle.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Morgan used developments of this suspension system throughout its existence, and it is still used on Morgan's \"classic\" line, although not on the Aero 8 or its derivatives. It has been cancelled, along with all the Morgan Classic line, in 2019. However, some \"classics\", shipped in parts to avoid the need for normal compliancy, will be shipped to the USA, and assembled there for an indefinite period.

Morgan cars can be found in many areas of motorsport, from club and historic racing to more prominent examples, including the Le Mans 24hr race. A notable Morgan racecar was the Aero 8 GT car that campaigned in 2008 Britcar races and the 2008 Britcar 24hrs at Silverstone, prepared and run by Mark Bailey Racing.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The '''2020 coronavirus pandemic in Saskatchewan''' is an [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: ongoing viral pandemic]] of [[coronavirus disease 2019]] (COVID-19), a novel infectious disease caused by [[severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2]] (SARS-CoV-2). {{As of
column6: df=US}}, 19,276 tests have been conducted, with 296 confirmed and 2 presumptive cases, 164 recoveries, and 4 deaths in [[Saskatchewan]].<ref name=\"saskcovid19\">{{cite web
column8: title=Cases and Risk of COVID-19 in Saskatchewan (updated daily)
column9: website=Government of Saskatchewan}}</ref> While a number of cases are still under investigation, 129 cases have been linked to travel, 112 have been the result of contact/community gatherings with other COVID-19 victims, and 25 cases have been from unidentified local exposures.<ref>{{Cite web
column15: reason=The authorities have not stated whether the travel cases include domestic travel in addition to international travel, nor have they stated whether the mass gatherings include out-of-province events such as the Edmonton curling tournament or the Vancouver dental conference.}} The area of [[Saskatoon]] has seen the most reported cases.<ref>{{Cite web
column17: title=25 health-care workers among Sask. COVID-19 cases
column24: access-date=2020-04-08}}</ref>  The coronavirus pandemic in Saskatchewan is part of the [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in Canada]].

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": On March 13, 2020, following the second presumptive case in the province, the Saskatchewan government announced restrictions on gatherings of more than 250 people in contiguous indoor space, as well as gatherings of more than 50 people if they include participants who had recently travelled internationally.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=COVID-19 live updates: Second presumptive case found in Sask.
column10: title=Gatherings of 250 people or more banned in Sask. as second presumptive COVID-19 case confirmed
column16: url-status=live}}</ref> Exceptions are permitted for retail shops.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column18: title=Hospital visitor restrictions, casinos closing part of coronavirus prevention
column22: title=\"Saskatchewan officials provide COVID update after second presumptive casecfound in province\", CBC News, March 13, 2020.
column26: url-status=live }}</ref> An exception for faith-based organizations was removed March 16.<ref name=\":0\" /> The government sharply reduced inter-provincial and international travel by any provincial employees on government business. It also provided that provincial employees who have travelled outside the country, whether on government business or personal travel, must self-isolate for 14 days upon their return.<ref name=\"Sask-update-March13\" />

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": On March 17, 2020, the government announced that it was delaying the introduction of the provincial budget, because the government revenue forecasts underlying it were no longer reliable, in light of the current situation.  The Government would announce the planned spending, including for the health care sector, which would see an increase in funding.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=\"Sask. government postpones full budget, will release spending plans Wednesday\", Adam Hunter, CBC News, March 17, 2020.
column7: url-status=live }}</ref> The same day, the Legislature passed amendments to provincial employment law, to provide unpaid job security to employees during the pandemic.  The amendments passed with the support of both parties.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=COVID-19: Sask. introduces unpaid job protected leave
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> The next day, the Legislature adjourned its spring sitting, with the consent of the Opposition.<ref>{{Cite web
column19: title=\"Saskatchewan legislative sitting abruptly adjourned amid COVID-19 pandemic\", Adam Hunter, CBC News, March 19, 2020.

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Saskatchewan declared a state of emergency on March 18, which included a ban of all gatherings of 50 people or more, restricting capacity of restaurants and similar venues to a maximum of 50 or half their normal capacity (whichever was lower), mandatory closure of all fitness facilities, casinos, and bingo halls, shifting all provincial government entities and crown corporations to remote work on March 23, authorizing the [[Saskatchewan Health Authority]] to \"redeploy nurses and other staff and ensure medical supplies and personal protective equipment are available when needed and reduce risk of further exposure to our care providers and patients\", and advising against non-essential travel outside of the province.<ref name=\":9\">{{Cite web
column3: title=COVID-19: Sask. declares state of emergency, additional measures, after announcing 8 new cases
column11: title=New restrictions announced as Sask. COVID-19 cases rise to 6
column16: title=Saskatchewan declares state of emergency as coronavirus concerns grow

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": On March 20, Premier Moe signed an order allowing regulations issued pursuant to the state of emergency, whether by the government or the chief medical officer, to be enforceable under provincial law. Law enforcement agencies, including the [[RCMP]], were granted the authority to enforce these measures under penalties of fines or arrest.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Saskatchewan premier signs order enforcing measures protecting against spread of COVID-19
column9: url-status=live}}</ref> The government subsequently announced that residents returning from any international travel, those who have tested positive,<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Woman ticketed for violating public health order tests positive for COVID-19: Regina police
column14: access-date=2020-04-08}}</ref> and those identified as recent contacts of someone who had tested positive, would be required by law to self-isolate for 14 days, with those breaking quarantine subject to a $2,000 fine.<ref name=\":10\" /> Essential travellers such as working crews, transport workers and health care workers were exempt.<ref name=\":10\">{{Cite web
column16: title=Mandatory self-isolation after travel now law as Sask. announces 6 more COVID-19 cases
column23: }}</ref> Premier Moe cited concerns over those not following its previous self-isolation recommendations as justification for the legal measure;<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column25: title='This is now the law': Here are the new measures announced in Sask.
column34: access-date=2020-03-24}}</ref> indeed, on April 6, a COVID-19-infected individual who had violated the mandatory self-isolation order received the first fine under the new legal measure, issued by the [[Regina Police Service]] in the amount of {{Currency
column38: title=Regina woman issued $2,800 ticket for violating public health order

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Additional restrictions were also announced on March 20, to take effect on March 23.  All restaurants, bars, and nightclubs were restricted to take-out service only (bars and nightclubs could only do so if customers were capable of maintaining a distance of 2 metres from each other). All art galleries, museums, and other recreational, entertainment, and personal service facilities were ordered closed, and certain types of medical clinics (chiropractors, dentists, optometrists, [[Podiatrist
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: podiatrists]], and registered massage therapists) were restricted to non-elective appointments only. All gatherings of 25 people or more were prohibited unless all patrons were capable of maintaining a distance of 2 metres from each other.<ref name=\":10\" /><ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=COVID-19 in Sask: Premier threatens international travellers who don't self-isolate with arrest, fines

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": On March 25, Saskatchewan announced that beginning March 26, all gatherings must be limited to 10 people, and all businesses not considered essential by the province were required to close to the public.  Examples of \"non-allowable business services\" included but were not limited to ATV, boat, and snowmobile retailers, clothing, shoe, accessory, and jewellery stores, electronics, entertainment, and toy stores, flower shops, book, gift, and stationary stores, sporting goods stores, pawn shops, and travel agencies.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=14 new COVID-19 cases in Sask. as province limits gatherings to 10
column12: title=Government Clarifies Allowable Business Services, Limits Gatherings To 10 Person Maximum

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": [[Alert Ready]] has been activated several times to provide notice of the self-isolation order, first on March 20,<ref name=\":10\" /> and again March 27.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Emergency alert for travelers issued by province of Saskatchewan due to COVID-19

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": On March 18, a Sangster's health store in [[Lawson Heights, Saskatoon]] was closed after multiple visits by a customer who stated that she had recently returned from international travel to [[Hawaii]], and that multiple passengers on the flight had felt ill. The store's local owner criticized the customer for breaking recommended self-quarantine, even though she had displayed no symptoms herself.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=COVID-19: After brush with 'irresponsible' customer Saskatoon business closes to in-person traffic

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": On March 20, [[Regina Transit]] and [[Saskatoon Transit]] suspended fares for all bus service, but with reduced service.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=COVID-19: Saskatoon Transit for 'essential travel only' city says
column14: title=Saskatoon city council passes special measures to deal with COVID-19 pandemic
column22: title=Regina Transit to keep operating, but with changes

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": In early April, Restaurants Canada, an industry organisation, announced that 25,000 restaurant jobs have been lost in Saskatchewan since March 1.  It also reported that approximately 10% of restaurants in Canada have closed permanently, and estimated that another 18% would close if the situation has not changed in a month's time.  Local restaurant operators expressed concerns whether they would be able to re-open.<ref>[https://leaderpost.com/news/local-news/saskatchewan-restaurant-industry-sees-25k-jobs-lost-due-to-covid-19/ \"Saskatchewan restaurant industry sees 25K jobs lost due to COVID-19\"], Mark Melnychuk< ''Regina Leader-Post'', April 3, 2020.</ref>
=== Municipal orders with measures contrary to provincial measures ===

The municipal governments of [[Gravelbourg]] and Regina declared their own states of emergency with stricter restrictions than those enforced by the province. Regina announced an intent to ban all public meetings larger than 5 people or more (outside of home, workplaces, or as part of essential services), and order the closure of retail stores in specific categories to in-person shopping (including clothing, furniture, games, sporting goods, and toys) effective March 23.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Regina declares local state of emergency, limiting size of gatherings
column9: access-date=2020-03-22}}</ref>  Gravelbourg similarly ordered that all businesses be closed to the public for 14 days (delivery and curbside pickup would still be allowed, and there were special operating requirements planned for the local [[Federated Co-operatives
column10: Co-op]] store), and that only a maximum of five employees could be in a building at any one time.<ref>{{Cite web
column12: title=Here's what the state of local emergency in Gravelbourg, Sask. means for residents
column21: access-date=2020-03-23}}</ref> Mayor of Regina [[Michael Fougere]] argued that Saskatchewan's initial restrictions were not strict enough, arguing that meetings of 50 people were too large to avoid possible community transmission, and that restaurants and bars should have been ordered to close rather than limit capacity.<ref>{{Cite web
column23: title=COVID-19: Mayor of Regina calling for even stricter regulations

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": On March 22, the province stated that it would take steps to ensure that its emergency measures maintain precedence over municipal orders that include \"contrary standards\".<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Saskatchewan municipalities can’t make up their own coronavirus regulations: province
column9: access-date=2020-03-23}}</ref> Minister of Government Relations Lori Carr explained that \"during this time of great uncertainty, it is of the utmost importance that we provide certainty to Saskatchewan residents and make every effort to minimize confusion\", and cited Regina's attempts to close retail stores as an example of a restriction where provincial decisions take precedence.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Here's some clarification on the conflicting orders made by the province and the City of Regina
column20: title=Government to review, cancel City of Regina emergency order

The [[University of Regina]] and [[University of Saskatchewan]] voluntarily suspended in-person classes on March 16, and switched to online courses for the remainder of the semester.<ref>{{cite web

No academic penalties would be  issued for students that do not attend school during the week of March 20, final grades will be issued based on existing progress, and eligible Grade 12 students will be able to graduate.<ref>{{Cite web

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": The '''2020 coronavirus pandemic in Saskatchewan''' is an [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic
New Orleans-class heavy cruiser}}: ongoing viral pandemic]] of [[coronavirus disease 2019]] (COVID-19), a novel infectious disease caused by [[severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2]] (SARS-CoV-2). {{As of
column6: df=US}}, 19,276 tests have been conducted, with 296 confirmed and 2 presumptive cases, 164 recoveries, and 4 deaths in [[Saskatchewan]].<ref name=\"saskcovid19\">{{cite web
column8: title=Cases and Risk of COVID-19 in Saskatchewan (updated daily)
column9: website=Government of Saskatchewan}}</ref> While a number of cases are still under investigation, 129 cases have been linked to travel, 112 have been the result of contact/community gatherings with other COVID-19 victims, and 25 cases have been from unidentified local exposures.<ref>{{Cite web
column15: reason=The authorities have not stated whether the travel cases include domestic travel in addition to international travel, nor have they stated whether the mass gatherings include out-of-province events such as the Edmonton curling tournament or the Vancouver dental conference.}} The area of [[Saskatoon]] has seen the most reported cases.<ref>{{Cite web
column17: title=25 health-care workers among Sask. COVID-19 cases
column24: access-date=2020-04-08}}</ref>  The coronavirus pandemic in Saskatchewan is part of the [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in Canada]].

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": Saskatchewan's Chief Medical Officer Saqib Shahab announced the first presumptive case of in the province on March 12, a person in their 60s that had recently returned from [[Egypt]], who was tested on March 9, and was in self-isolation at their home.<ref name=\"first\">{{cite news
column4: title=Saskatchewan confirms first presumptive case of novel coronavirus
column9: date=March 12, 2020}}</ref> By March 16, the number of presumptive cases in the province had increased to seven.<ref name=\"cases316\">{{cite news
column12: title=Saskatchewan reports 7th presumptive case of coronavirus
column20: url-status=live }}</ref> On March 17, one new case was reported.<ref name=\"case317\">{{cite news
column23: title=COVID-19: Sask. records eighth case of coronavirus
column31: url-status=live }}</ref> On the same day, the College of Dental Surgeons of Saskatchewan recommended that those who attended the 2020 Pacific Dental Conference in [[Vancouver]] to self-isolate after many cases, including two in Saskatchewan, were linked to the event.<ref name=\"dentistemergency\">{{cite news
column34: title=Sask. dentists asked to consider limiting work to emergencies only

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": On March 18, 8 new cases were reported.<ref name=\"emergency\">{{cite news
column4: title=Sask. declares state of emergency after eight new coronavirus cases
column12: url-status=live }}</ref> On March 19, four new cases were reported, bringing the provincial total to 20.<ref name=\"cases319\">{{cite news
column15: title=COVID-19: Sask. reports four new coronavirus cases, bringing total to 20
column23: url-status=live }}</ref> On March 20, six new cases were reported, and 8 were confirmed.<ref name=\"cases320\">{{cite news
column26: title=Number of COVID-19 cases in Saskatchewan rises to 26, 8 confirmed
column34: url-status=live }}</ref> On March 21, 2020, 18 new cases were reported,<ref name=\"cases321\">{{cite news
column37: title=Coronavirus: Saskatchewan reports 18 new COVID-19 cases, province totals 44
column45: url-status=live }}</ref> including 11 healthcare workers who attended a physicians' bonspiel at a curling club in [[Edmonton]] on the week of March 11.<ref>{{Cite web
column47: title=11 Sask. healthcare workers test positive for COVID-19 after curling bonspiel in Alta.
column54: url-status=live}}</ref> On March 22, 8 more cases were reported.<ref name=\"cases 322\">{{cite news
column57: title=8 new cases of COVID-19 in Sask., total at 52

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": On March 23, 14 new cases were reported, and only one was still presumptive.<ref name=\"cases323\">{{cite news
column4: title=Coronavirus: Saskatchewan reports 14 new COVID-19 cases, bringing total to 66
column12: url-status=live }}</ref> On March 24, six new confirmed cases were reported, totalling 72 confirmed cases. This includes four cases thought to possibly be the result of community transmission, pending a full investigation.<ref name=\"cases324\">{{cite news
column15: title=Coronavirus: Saskatchewan reports 6 new COVID-19 cases, bringing total to 72
column24: url-status=live }}</ref> Another new 14 cases were announced on March 25. On March 26 and 27, 9 new cases were reported each.<ref>{{Cite web
column26: title=9 new coronavirus cases reported in Saskatchewan; PPE goes missing from health authority
column35: title=Coronavirus: 9 new COVID-19 cases reported in Saskatchewan, total rises to 95

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": On March 28, Saskatchewan announced the largest single-day increase in cases, at 30. The spike, especially in northern and central Saskatchewan, was attributed to 18 cases involving attendees of a snowmobile rally in [[Christopher Lake]] on March 14.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Saskatchewan sees biggest jump in COVID-19 cases, 30 reported Saturday
column11: title=30 new cases of COVID-19 in Sask., 6 people in hospital
column20: access-date=2020-03-29}}</ref> The [[Saskatchewan Health Authority]] (SHA) initially announced two positive cases (including a participant, and a server at an associated dinner) on March 25, and has advised self-isolation for anyone who had attended.<ref>{{Cite web
column22: title=Two people who attended Christopher Lake snowmobile rally test positive for COVID-19: SHA
column33: title=14 new COVID-19 cases in Sask. as province limits gatherings to 10 people

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": On March 30, the confirmed case count rose to 176, and Saskatchewan also reported its first deaths from COVID-19. Both people were in their 70s and were from separate parts of the province.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=COVID-19 in Sask: Province marks 'sad milestone' of first 2 deaths

→‎Pearl Harbor attack,safe,Jerry Kruth,": By April 6, Saskatchewan had 253 cases and 81 recoveries. For the first time, the number of new recoveries (14) exceeded the number of new cases (4).<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=4 new COVID-19 cases in Sask., province encourages downloading SaskAlert app
column7: access-date=2020-04-08}}</ref> Seven new cases and recoveries were announced the next day.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=Saskatchewan reaches 260 COVID-19 cases, 7 new recoveries
column13: access-date=2020-04-08}}</ref>  The total number of cases continued to rise, reaching 289 on April 11, though the remaining active cases fell to 138 — dropping for the first time below the number of recoveries (which rose to 147).<ref>{{Cite web
column15: title=Sask. now has more COVID-19 recoveries than active cases
